SESSION.HEADER.PARA: FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY‐EIGHTH PARLIAMENT
The Senate, on 27 March 1977, adjourned to 6 May 1997, unless the President fixed an earlier day of meeting.
Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate passed on 27 March 1977, the Senate met on Tuesday, 6 May 1997 at 12.30 p.m.

PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received, through the Governor‐General, from the Governor of New South Wales, the original certificate of the choice of the Houses of the New South Wales Parliament of Senator Marise Ann Payne to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Robert Woods. I table the documents.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Marise Ann Payne made and subscribed the affirmation of allegiance.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPUTY PRESIDENT AND CHAIRMAN OF COMMITTEES: RESIGNATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received a letter from Senator Colston resigning as Deputy President and Chairman of Committees. I table the letter.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPUTY PRESIDENT AND CHAIRMAN OF COMMITTEES: ELECTION

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In those circumstances I remind the Senate that it should now choose one of its members to be Deputy President and Chairman of Committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to the Senate for its Deputy President and Chairman of Committees Senator West, and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senator West be appointed Deputy President and Chair of Committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further nominations? There being no further nominations, I declare Senator West elected Deputy President and Chairman of Committees, in accordance with the standing orders.
—I would like to congratulate Senator West—
—More front than Myer's!
—Order!
—on her unanimous election, Senator Carr, you may have noticed. It is an important position. Not only does it hold an important public profile but it is also—
—You put up Mal. Just remember we followed the conventions. Knowing what you know, you put him up.
—Order, Senator Vanstone!

—It is also, Senator West, a difficult job to manage the Senate in the course of its committee debates—quite complex debates. We know that you will take on this role according to the principle that partisanship is left behind and that you will be fair and objective, as some of your predecessors have been, in order that you can maintain the confidence of those on all sides of this chamber. As I said, we are confident that you will approach the job in that light. Certainly, on that basis, we wish you well in the position and offer you our support as the government parties in this place.

BREAK.PARA: Can I also put on record appreciation for the work conducted by Senator Colston as Deputy President and Chairman of Committees. I do not think there is any dispute, even from the Labor Party, that in Senator Colston's work as Chairman of Committees he has performed properly and fairly—and very ably, I might say. I trust that the matters that overshadow Senator Colston at the moment might be resolved to his satisfaction, and I am sure that will be a happier day for all of us present in this Senate. We appreciate that he has chosen to stand down in the circumstances so that there should not be a shadow over one of the senior office bearers of this place, and for that action we express our appreciation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, can I say to Senator West that I think she has a very great responsibility. The very important office of Deputy President and Chairman of Committees of the Senate has taken a great battering over recent months. The arrangements that were arrived at last year have diminished this office very significantly in the eyes of the Australian community. I think it has diminished the standing of all parliamentarians, I think it has diminished the standing of the Senate, and I think it has diminished the standing of the parliament.

BREAK.PARA: I say to Senator West that I think she has a crucial role in rebuilding the confidence of the Australian community in our parliament. I say to Senator West that I think she has the necessary qualifications to enable her to do just that. Sue, I think you are competent, I think you are fair, I think you are straightforward and, above all, Sue, you are honest. Sue, even though your election to this position may have taken some nine months longer than we on this side of the chamber would have liked, I think it represents a triumph of political principle in your case.

I want to make clear again, as I have said in recent debates in relation to the positions of Deputy President and President of the Senate, that the opposition is committed to the convention that the President of the Senate represent the party of government and that the Deputy President be a member of the opposition.

I know, Sue, as a fellow member of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party, that your career has not always been easy. I remember particularly your great victory for Labor in the 1990 half‐Senate election. Nearly 3½ million votes were cast in that election and your victory over Senator Puplick, then of course a senior coalition frontbencher, was incredibly close—just 490 votes. That was very important to the Labor Party. I suppose I should say that last year you lost another close ballot by four votes, that being for the Deputy Presidency of the Senate.

But today, Sue, we right that wrong. Can I say to you on behalf of the Australian Labor Party—not only my parliamentary colleagues in the Senate and other members of caucus, but also, very broadly, the membership of the Australian Labor Party—congratulations. Sue, you will do this office great credit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to congratulate Senator West who was the candidate the Australian Democrats supported in the first ballot. It is good to see that history has offered you a second chance, Senator West. I am glad to be here to see the consequences of history in this circumstance, and to be able to speak at this time.

BREAK.PARA: The Democrats expect you to honour the position of Deputy President with impartiality, with dignity and with a judicious sense of humour, which I think has served many people in that position well in previous years.
I think it is worth noting that we have a two‐woman team. It is an historic occasion for the Senate, and it more appropriately reflects the number of women present in this upper house.
I also point out that it is with some relief that I will not have to stand in every division and ask you to declare whether you intend to vote and, if so, how you intend to vote.
Might I also add that I believe Senator Colston has taken the appropriate action in resigning, albeit at 12.28 this afternoon.

Also, for the record of this place, as distinct from the public record elsewhere, I might add that I hope with Senator West's election we can do a great deal to remedy the enormous damage which has been done to the important position of Deputy President, to the reputations of most, if not all, senators, and to the wider dignity of parliament. In the longer term, it is up to the Senate to restore its public reputation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking all senators in this chamber for bestowing upon me the very great honour of being Deputy President of the Senate. It is a humbling experience to be selected by my peers to hold this office of service to this chamber and, indeed, to this parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to thank all for the support I have been given today. I can assure you I will work hard to fulfil my obligations and duties as Deputy President of the Senate. I look forward to working with you, Madam President, and indeed with all senators, to ensure the smooth and efficient operation of the Senate. I thank you all very much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present to the Senate a statement dated 8 April 1997 by Mrs Christine Smith, and a covering letter of the same date from solicitors acting on her behalf. These documents were received in my office and the office of the Clerk of the Senate on that day. Because of the significance of the documents, I directed that they be provided to all party leaders in the Senate and independent senators, and that was done on the same day.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators Margetts and Bolkus have each raised with me, by letters dated 9 and 10 April 1997 respectively, a matter of privilege pursuant to standing order 81. The essence of the matter they have raised is that, if the statement by Mrs Christine Smith dated 8 April 1997 is true, her statement and Senator Colston's statement provided to me and presented to the Senate on 24 March 1997 are both false and would have been known to be false by both Senator Colston and Mrs Smith. This raises the possibility that false and misleading statements have been deliberately made to the Senate.

I am required by standing order 81 to determine whether a motion relating to the matter should have precedence, having regard to criteria set out in the Senate's privilege resolution no. 4. These criteria are:

(a) the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for Senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate; and
(b) the existence of a remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt.

Rulings of my predecessors have held that a matter should be given precedence if it is capable of being held by the Senate as conforming to criterion (a). The Senate and the Standing Committee of Privileges have always taken very seriously any suggestion that the Senate or its committees have been presented with false or misleading information, and there are a number of relevant reports of the Standing Committee of Privileges which have been endorsed by the Senate.

In relation to criterion (b), I am advised that there is no remedy other than an inquiry by the Senate in relation to this matter. The reason for this is that the statements by Senator Colston and Mrs Smith, having been presented to the Senate and their publication authorised by the Senate pursuant to standing order 167, those statements are proceedings in parliament within the meaning of section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 and, therefore, cannot be used in evidence in any substantive way before any court or tribunal. I am advised that there is, therefore, no remedy available through any legal proceedings, if the statements were false or misleading. Criterion (b) is, therefore, clearly met. I have, therefore, determined that a motion to refer this matter to the Standing Committee of Privileges may have precedence over other business, in accordance with standing order 81.

The question has been raised whether any inquiry by the Senate into this matter should await the outcome of police investigations of Senator Colston's travelling allowance claims and any consequent legal proceedings. That is a question for the Senate to determine. I table letters from Senators Margetts and Bolkus, and the advice I received from the Clerk of the Senate. Senator Margetts and Senator Bolkus may now give a notice of motion which will have precedence over all other business on the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Bolkus and Senator Margetts, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges:

Whether statements by Senator Colston and Mrs C Smith, relating to payments of travelling allowances to Senator Colston, tabled in the Senate on 24 March and 6 May 1997, were false or misleading in any particular, and, if so, whether a contempt of the Senate was committed by the making of those statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge (Assessment and Collection) Bill 1997 as a whole. There is now a revised running sheet, compiled by Senator Sherry. The question is that amendments 1‐5, 13‐21, 28‐45, 48 and 49, previously moved and as renumbered, be agreed to, and clauses 11 and 12 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make sure we have all the renumbering and amendments. We are quite happy for Senator Sherry to speak, but I am anxious that my advisers have all the material on hand and have a copy of the running sheets, so that we have a chance to examine them and make sure we are debating the correct material.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that they have been circulated.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator SHERRY (Tasmania—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (12.52 p.m.)—On the issue we are dealing with, there are a range of amendments we have moved in respect of the advance instalment. We had, I think, when we last left this issue, commenced some discussion about the advance instalment provisions. The advance instalment provision, in our view, represents one of the most atrocious aspects of this ongoing saga—shambles—of the superannuation tax provisions. If an individual has to pay the advance instalment, that is, 7½ per cent of the 15 per cent tax, the provisions require the individual to pay the following year's tax liability in advance. In other words, the government is collecting half its revenue from the second year in the first year.

It also assumes that an individual will have an ongoing tax liability. Before I explain why this is outrageous from an equitable point of view, I would like to make a few other comments. The government is attempting to bring half its revenue from the second year forward into the first year. Of course, the effect of pushing back the dates when the surcharge debt for 1996‐97 is payable, in conjunction with the advance instalment, has led to one outcome—a huge amount of revenue being collected in the year 1999‐200. It strikes me that it is not coincidence that the government is manipulating its revenue in this way.

The government is manipulating—fiddling, if you like—its revenue. It is seeking to raise the maximum amount of revenue in 1999‐2000 that it possibly can. Something exciting may happen in the 1999‐2000 financial year and that will be an election. So the government is trying to manipulate, in our view, its revenue collection for the purposes of its political campaign that is more than likely to fall during that period. Of course, it does not hurt the government that a large part of the revenue that would have been raised in 1996‐97 will not now be collected until 1997‐98. It inflates the budget bottom line in that year as well.

We note that the government does not propose to insert a line item in the budget statements indicating the amount of money that the commissioner will have to refund due to the incorrect collection of moneys. We would note strongly that, should our amendments on advance instalments fail, the government should be required to put this liability to refund Australians' superannuation money, which should not have been collected in the first place, with interest as a separate line item in the budget. This is particularly true in the context of the government's alleged commitment to budget honesty.

Going on to the equity issues associated with the problems that a consequent of this advance instalment provision: how can this be a fair tax on superannuation when individuals who should not be required to pay the tax in the first place are required also to pay an advance instalment?

We know, from all the evidence given to us—and the government has not been able to rebut it—that there will be at least one million lower and middle income earners who will be required to pay the superannuation tax in the first year, that is, 15 per cent of their superannuation contributions of lower and middle income earners in the first year, on top of the existing 15 per cent tax, with another 7½ per cent advance instalment on top of that. And the number of people, particularly in the first year of the superannuation tax, who should not have to pay the tax but will end up paying the tax will be very significant indeed.

These people are, in the main, going to be part‐time, casual, itinerant workers for which funds do not have tax file numbers—they do not have, at the moment, any tax file numbers for the purpose of this legislation—and they are going to be hit with, as I said, that 15 per cent existing tax, another full 15 per cent tax on top of the existing tax, plus another 7½ per cent instalment tax; and it gets worse. That money, which is effectively being taxed at the rate of 37½ per cent, will also be taxed at the rate of 15 per cent when members collect their money on reaching age 55 or whatever their retirement age is. That is a total of 52½ per cent tax on lower and middle income earners' superannuation contributions—52½ per cent, more than half.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got that, Kempie?

—Senator Kemp has got it because he is looking forward to the windfall in revenue that is going to accrue to the government as a consequence. It also magnifies dramatically the effect on individuals who receive a once‐off payment such as an eligible termination payment—or payments from the proceeds of a book, the sale of a farm, payment for an art work, whatever it may be—where their payment is artificially pushed above the $70,000 threshold, the so‐called higher income bracket that is supposed to be caught by these new tax provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Once they have accrued the original tax debt, they will be liable to pay the advance instalment tax until they can prove to the commissioner that they are no longer above the income threshold level for payment of the 15 per cent tax on superannuation. So we have an incredible position where the government says it does not want to hit these particular people, but many of them will be hit by this new superannuation tax. Then they have to go along to the taxation commissioner and prove why the tax should not have been collected in the first place.

I stress that where an individual does not provide their tax file number in the first year in particular this is a dramatic problem. Since we last considered this legislation I have had cause to talk to the secretary, I think, of the motor industry superannuation fund, which has about 225,000 members. They have been, for other purposes—not for the purposes of this legislation—circulating letters to members to try to collect tax file numbers and, unfortunately, they have had a response from only a few thousand of the 225,000 members of that fund.

Certainly, if this legislation passes the Senate in its current form, the funds are going to wage a very vigorous campaign between May and effectively November, because the tax is payable in December and they have to start processing the collection of the tax. But we do know that, in the case of the fund covering the motor industry, of those 225,000 people, most of whom earn less than $70,000, about half will be hit with this new tax in the first year, because they will not realise the importance of the tax file number. And if that is any indication, the figure of one million lower and middle income earners being affected in the first year is conservative. This is one million people who earn less than $70,000 being hit with this new tax.

Another issue I wish to raise with respect to this advance instalment of the surcharge concerns the fact that Australians do believe that privacy is very important. The latest survey showed that 70 per cent of Australians believe that it is a very important issue. The imposition of a penalty tax is far different from the refusal of benefits in regard to the providing of tax file numbers.

I do think anyone envisaged, when the tax file system was introduced, that if you failed to produce your tax file number on a `voluntary' basis—I emphasise the inverted commas—you would be hit with a tax. That is your choice: provide the tax file number voluntarily or you are hit with a massive new tax on your superannuation contributions. I submit to the Senate that that is an impossible principle for the government to justify.

Some of the issues I have touched on we will be dealing with a little later, because they go to the heart of our concern about collecting the full 15 per cent tax from people whose tax file numbers are not with the superannuation funds. That will be at least a million people—probably more in the first year. That is more people than are supposed to be hit by this tax who earn more than $70,000.

The effect of the advance instalment in the first year magnifies the effect of this, because people who have to pay the 15 per cent because the funds do not have the tax file numbers will have to pay another 7½ per cent in the first year. The government says, `It's all okay. We don't want to tax these people.' But the reality is that, if the government had any understanding of the structure and nature of the superannuation industry, it would know that these million‐plus lower and middle income earners will be hit by this tax because of the way in which the superannuation industry is structured and, in particular, because the government refuses to call this a tax; it calls it a surcharge.

BREAK.PARA: The government does not want the tax collected directly. It has tried to hide the tax by getting the superannuation funds to collect it for them in the hope that no‐one will notice the tax when they get their statements at the end of this year and the beginning of next year. I think that it is pretty much wishful thinking from the government, frankly, because of their lack of understanding of the industry, that people are not going to notice another 15 per cent tax and another 7½ per cent advance instalment tax on top of the existing 15 per cent tax and watch the bottom line effect on their superannuation benefits. Labor is certainly going to be drawing it to the attention of the millions of Australian taxpayers who have superannuation.

The effect of the advance instalment tax in the first year magnifies dramatically at the worst possible time the effects of this new superannuation tax on those people who should not be paying the tax. It is fundamental in our contention that the advance instalment tax should be removed from the bills. This will not affect the bottom line of the government's revenue. All it is doing is saying, if you want a 15 per cent tax on superannuation, you collect the revenue from those taxpayers in the first year—the 15 per cent—and you collect the 15 per cent in the second year and the third year. It will not affect your forward estimates over the next three years but it will avoid this very serious problem of magnifying the effect on those many lower and middle income earners who are going to have to pay this tax who should not have to pay it.

Of course, that is not to forget the higher income earners who are required to have this advance instalment—higher income earners earning more than $70,000, who were assured by this government that there would be no increases in existing taxes and no introduction of new taxes. You wake up the day after the last budget in August last year and you suddenly find, if you are a higher income earner, that your tax rate on superannuation is moving up from 30 per cent to 45 per cent.

That breached the government's fundamental commitment at the last election. It has had serious consequences for the superannuation industry. The government says, `Don't worry. This is all clear. There are no problems.' We have been hearing that for the last nine months, and the problems keep piling on the problems. More legal problems were mentioned last week by Justice Davies, a sitting Federal Court judge, in respect of the legality of all of this. But if the government persists and this is passed we will see what the courts have to say.

We do not believe that higher income earners should have to pay an advance instalment of a tax when they were told at the last election that there would be no new tax at all. As I say, they will wake up the day after the budget and their tax rate on super will have moved from 30 per cent to 45 per cent, with another 7½ per cent advance instalment this year. It is absolutely outrageous. I have not met—and Senator Watson well knows; we have had to sit through the hearings of the Senate superannuation committee—any lawyer, accountant, superannuation expert or tax expert who thinks this is a good approach on tax policy. But the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) assures us, when he looks Australians in the eye, that this is not a tax; it is a surcharge. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments seek to delete the provisions in the bill allowing the collection of advanced instalments on future surcharge liability. The advance payment system will commence only in the second year of operation of the surcharge and, where a member has paid the surcharge the previous year, an advance instalment will be levied at the rate applicable in the previous year. The advance payments will not be finalised until 15 June in the year of income. That is to say that, by then, the vast bulk of contributions will have already been paid into the funds.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand the concerns which the funds expressed about the cost of administering the advance payment system, and, of course, the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation found those arguments to be very strong. However, against that, the government has advised that this amendment will affect the budget bottom line for next year by some $160 million, even though this amount will be collected the following year. It has also advised of several measures to ameliorate the effects of the payment system.

The government has had the concerns of the Senate committee before it for some weeks now, and it has chosen not to act on them. As recently as this morning, the federal Treasurer (Mr Costello) rang the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) to assure her that the government was prepared to wear all of the flak for any administrative problems caused by this legislation. I wish to make it absolutely clear here today that any problems associated with this bill should be sheeted home to Mr Costello and to Senator Kemp. We have drawn our concerns to the government's attention, and the government has assured us that they do not exist. If they do, I believe that we can say that it is clearly their responsibility.

I seek an assurance from the minister today that he will monitor very closely the impact of the payment system in close consultation with the industry. If we have those assurances, I wish to advise that the Democrats will, with some reluctance, oppose these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a number of remarks in relation to matters which have been raised by honourable senators. In relation to Senator Allison, of course we will monitor the issue very carefully. We recognise this is a new surcharge and we look forward to working with the industry. I wish to make a few preliminary comments in relation to Senator Sherry's remarks.
—It's a funny way of spelling `surcharge'—t-a-x.

—This is a serious debate, Senator. Let me make a couple of remarks in relation to Senator Sherry's comments. This is a surcharge on high income earners. What we have seen is an attempt, by certain interest groups who are opposed to the surcharge, to hide behind low and middle income earners in an attempt to try to defeat the surcharge. I understood that everyone had essentially signed on to the surcharge. In fact, until Senator Sherry's press conference today, Mr Beazley had indicated that the Labor Party would be supporting the surcharge. We recognise that there were qualifications, but essentially that was the Labor Party's position.

SPEECH.PARA: Some wild figures have been thrown around in the last couple of days—Senator Sherry will know exactly what I am talking about—in an attempt to build up a degree of public hysteria to try to defeat the surcharge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tax.

—Senator, why don't you make a contribution for a change. Instead of just sitting over there like a great dodo, why don't you actually make a thoughtful contribution for a change. This is an important issue and it does not deserve to be treated in the trivial way in which you are carrying on.
—Senator Kemp, address the chair and not Senator Murphy.

—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. We are of course conscious of the need to ensure that low and middle income earners do not pay the surcharge. I have stated on many occasions that there is, of course, despite what Senator Sherry says and despite the figures he throws around—
—It's the industry's figures, not mine.
—Well certain sections of the industry are hardly disinterested advocates in this issue, Senator Sherry. I will take you through it, because I think senators—
—The workers of Australia would be very interested.

—The workers of Australia would want to have the tax concessions which are available to high income earners made more equitable. That is what the Labor Party tends to forget. That is what the Keating Labor Party tended to forget. This surcharge is about equity.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take senators through the efforts that will be made to ensure that low and middle income earners are not impacted by the surcharge. I will quote a number of examples which, I think, are important to go on the record. The ATO will be undertaking a range of measures to contact people who have not quoted their tax file number.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?
—Just wait, Senator. These will include: data matching between fund data and ATO data; direct communication to the taxpayers who have not quoted a tax file number—
—The tax department! The tax department will do the job for the super funds.
—Senator Lundy, you can have the call later if you wish to speak.

—They also include notices in the Tax Pack and reminders to taxpayers on the income tax notice of assessment. The ATO will provide information for the funds to send to members with member statements. The ATO will undertake other communication and assessments will be delayed until the May 1998 instalment. I repeat that: the assessments will be delayed until the May 1998 instalment. The ATO will allow superannuation providers to advise the ATO of tax file numbers received after the 15 December reporting deadline.

SPEECH.PARA: This means that providers and members have until around May 1998—that is, 12 months hence—to give their tax file number to the fund or the ATO to avoid a surcharge assessment being raised. Of course, if all fails and a surcharge assessment is raised because of non-quotation of a tax file number, the bill allows for the surcharge to be refunded when they subsequently quote their tax file number.

So I have taken you through the steps which will be taken by the government. Let me just give you an example. With the matching of member data provided by the funds with ATO income tax client records, the common name and address, date of birth criteria will be used to link individual member account details and their ATO recorded tax file number. In turn, of course, the tax return data will be used to establish their taxable income level. The ATO anticipates a very substantial success rate using this method. Of course, this does depend upon either a member's full name and address or employer details being supplied to the fund.

I am putting to you that we will be making very great efforts to ensure that those who have not supplied their tax file numbers are contacted. In the end, it is their choice whether to supply their tax file number, but I have outlined in some detail the efforts which will be taken. I believe that should provide considerable comfort to members and senators and shows the approach that the government and the tax office will be taking to this issue. Senator Sherry got up and said this is absolutely without precedent, I think.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I said it was the biggest mess I have seen in a long time.
—Senator, you have shown a capacity, I must say, to run the lines of the special interest groups on this with considerable vigour.
—Experts!

—But, Senator Sherry, have we never seen anything like this done before? You will recall the Labor government introduced a measure that where a person fails to quote their tax file number to a bank they may have their tax withheld at the highest marginal rate.
—I remember that.
—Do you remember that, Senator Sherry?
—He's gone quiet.

—Where is the lack of precedent, Senator Sherry, that you were talking about? I would have thought that that was a directly comparable measure that was brought in by your government. So I put it to you that we take this issue very seriously and we will be taking a range of steps to ensure that people have the opportunity to quote their tax file number and to be reminded of the advantages of quoting their tax file number on this matter. But, in the end, it depends on the individual and the individual will make a choice, and I have given Senator Alison the assurances that she was seeking.

SPEECH.PARA: My final point—and perhaps this is the appropriate time to record it—is that a number of new amendments were given to the government today just before 12.30 p.m. We have been in constant communication with Senator Sherry's office and advisers seeking copies of these amendments, which were flagged, so they could be properly analysed so, if there was any room for discussion, constructive discussion could have occurred. Despite the fact that we have had a five‐week break, these amendments were dropped on us just after noon today.

This is a very serious issue. We understand that at times these things are difficult to produce, but I would have thought that, in a reasonable spirit of making sure that this debate could proceed at a reasonable level, the amendments would not have been dropped off at the very last moment, particularly as I have been exhorted from time to time by Senator Sherry in his office to ensure that they have copies of government amendments as quickly and efficiently as possible.

I put that on the table because I do not think that this is a fair way to run this debate. Whatever the Labor Party may have had in mind, it is an approach which makes it very difficult for other non-government senators to consider the implications of what is being put forward. Senator Sherry, I think that you would agree that every time you have contacted me I have bent over backwards to assist, and I think that it is a pity that after five weeks, again, at the very last moment—precisely, I might say, when this bill came on again—the Labor Party produced its amendments.

I know that it is a complex bill and I know that there were difficulties with drafting resources. I certainly did not make a big issue at that time, but I think today it was a pity that we received these amendments so late.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) will support these superannuation bills because they are taxes on the rich, and this is a rarity. We will support them even though they are a very botched effort, rather than leave anyone in doubt that we think it is a good principle. The SCS is a very badly botched effort, and I want to speak a little bit about the issues to make it clear what we think is still wrong with them.

BREAK.PARA: The bills are a mess. The government has taken two essentially simple ideas and made a dog's dinner of them. I will say at the outset that the government called this a surcharge and I will call it a tax. I will continue to call it so. The first simple idea is that the rich are not shouldering a fair portion of their social responsibility. The social structure creates the conditions that allow them to make their wealth, but they are not contributing back enough of the wealth to support that social system. In short, the firs t simple idea is that the rich are not paying enough tax and that they should pay more. This is interesting, because we have just been hearing about more tax breaks in relation to the budget.

The second simple idea is to do something about the way wealthy individuals can minimise their taxes through salary sacrifice packages that entail extra employer contributions to an employee's superannuation. They do this with the cooperation of their employers.

The simple solution to the first issue would be to scrap these bills and increase the tax paid at the top marginal rate or create a further margin. We considered this and had a simple amendment drafted in two versions, one increasing the current top rate to 49 per cent, the other creating a new rate of 49 per cent for those making over $70,000. Unfortunately, we were informed that it is too extensive an amendment for the committee stage. Part of the problem with that is how quickly these bills were rushed through at the end of last session.

The simple solution to the second issue is to eliminate employer deductions for superannuation contributions beyond what is required by law. We were told that we could put this amendment, and we will do so. It makes using superannuation and salary sacrifice much less attractive to the employer and assures it is taxed at at least the full company rate. It will mean that employees opting for salary sacrifice will lose the company rate of 36 per cent plus the surcharge of 15 per cent, or a total of 51 per cent on those specific contributions.

The first complication by the government to these simple ideas is that the government wants to tax the rich indirectly by taxing the superannuation of the rich. It wants to tax all their superannuation rather than just the part that has been done as a salary sacrifice. I suppose this is on the principle that they get a lot of superannuation; they do not need tax incentives to invest or to save for their future.

It then gets immensely more complicated, as others here in the Senate committee have highlighted and will continue to highlight. The government, to collect their tax and not call it a tax, have had to create a whole structure to demand that the superannuation funds collect information, discriminate between contributors on the basis of their notional income by calling employer superannuation contributions employee income, and then the government will collect the taxpayers' tax not from taxpayers but from the superannuation funds.

Having got into this murky world, it then has also to deal with termination payments. The result is seven bills, essentially six new acts, and a raft of consequential changes to other bills, rather than half a dozen lines of text in the Tax Act.

I will not go into the range of problems here. As Senator Sherry said, the most sensible thing would have been to withdraw these bills and redraft them. I do not think this would have been impossible, since I believe that there is general support for dealing with the basic issues. It is the implementation that is the problem and that creates objections.

The fact that these bills were rushed along in the last hours of last session instead of receiving proper consideration and debate has exacerbated the situation. The government did little to work on an acceptable range of amendments to correct bad aspects of these bills, which were almost certainly drafted as they were considered—in a rush that precluded proper consideration.

One of the major problems—the one the ALP amendments before us seek to address—is that, amongst everything else, the government has decided that it is not enough to collect the quasi tax on superannuation contributions. It also wants to collect it on probable future contributions. Just as an aside, it does lend weight to the potential for perhaps putting some issues of very large, complex amendments to very large, complex bills out to further committees so that less of the chamber time might be used. We would have more of these issues sorted out when the matter came back into the chamber.

What should we do? The government is already making a rotten mess out of superannuation, and not only superannuation of the rich. Superannuation funds are expected to penalise everyone who has not registered their tax file number—TFN—making a further mockery of the idea that there was anything remotely voluntary about using a tax file number as a universal identifier or a default Australia Card.

Already, superannuation funds will have to have large cash reserves, tying up assets in a way that should be completely unnecessary in a financial institution based on payouts upon retirement rather than on demand and it will impact on the overall performance of funds. Already with a level of taxation of 15 per cent plus 15 per cent plus 7½ per cent for advances, it is highly unlikely that investments for anyone in such a category would be lucrative. For ordinary employees, the idea of putting in extra money—an employee contribution—starts to be ludicrous. Why bother? After all, the return on superannuation funds currently runs only to about seven per cent per annum on many large funds.

On the tax file number issues generally, the ATO has already had a tax file number for a taxpayer. They are the ones who, on the basis of information from the superannuation funds, do an assessment which the superannuation funds then pay. I cannot understand why, in this situation, the ATO could not supply the tax file number to a superannuation fund or just keep the record to themselves or just provide a nod as to whether or not the income is in the right area. After all, a superannuation fund is basically different to a bank account. People do not simply open and close superannuation funds. They do not draw on them unless they are retired. In most cases it is their employer who is paying the money in and who decides which fund to pay into. Under small accounts legislation, it should be the case that people's superannuation money is consolidated into one account.

What is the excuse for the ATO not making an effort to work out a taxpayer's tax file number? Why can they not work it out based on a taxpayer's name and employer? The employers already will be remitting PAYE tax, so the tax office has some information in its big database. Why is it so necessary to give this tax file number to private companies yet the employee name and that of the employer is enough in most cases for the ATO to establish what the tax file number is? Instead, you seek to penalise people to a huge degree, more than doubling their superannuation tax obligation, because their superannuation company does not supply the Australian Taxation Office with a tax file number.

The whole tax file number issue is important here. It may not matter much if there are all these higher charges on the rich. But in the committee's evidence, Ms Howes of the IFA said that in the first year—before employees who actually read their superannuation statements get a shock from what is on them—there is likely to be only a 40 per cent compliance rate to a request for tax file numbers. Senator Sherry gave much lower figures for one of the major funds. I, for one, think it might be even lower than 40 per cent. In evidence, Ms Howes stated that this will mean that 60 per cent or more of superannuation fund members will be subject to both the 15 per cent surcharge and the five per cent advance, and superannuation funds will be responsible for finding the money and having assets to cover this.

The ATO gave evidence that they will make efforts to reduce this. But, given that few people are good at doing their taxes, I am not certain it will be effective. Certainly, even if it is not 60 per cent, there is likely to be a large number of people making under $70,000 who will not put in their tax file number or will not do so in time in the first year.

There might just be some people who for principle reasons do not feel they should be forced to surrender that private information. Think of that. There might be some who actually do not have the income or who actually believe they should not be required to surrender that information. What kind of a dog's dinner is it going to be when we deal with people who, based on conscience, think that they should not have to surrender it? This is at a time when we are being told that we can no longer expect that governments will keep that information private because it is all going to be privatised anyway.

In such a scenario, it is hard to justify having such a requirement for an advance. In fact, it is hard to justify the superannuation funds having to pay someone else's personal income tax at all. This advance is to be made without many of the safeguards that there are in provisional income tax. There are no mechanisms for variation. Superannuation funds are obliged to pay this tax up front, even borrowing money to do so. This will have an effect on fund outcomes for all members, whether they are rich or not and whether they give their tax file number or not. This is the major issue with advances.

In the last session, and before the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) prematurely moved for progress to be reported, the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) was saying that contributions will have been received from 1 July to 15 June and that the advance instalment is due on 15 June—that is, a collection on contributions already made. Why, then, is it an advance? Why is it based on a number calculated from the previous tax amount? Why not, at the very least, tax people on the contributions they have actually made?

While we are on the subject, why not wait until the normal tax is normally due? Why not base the tax that is due on what is actually due based on real contributions and real income? Do we have another little bit of self‐assessment, and who has costed that out in our community?

No, I do not think Senator Kemp's arguments hold water. I do not think this implication that the amount is known, is in pocket and covers virtually the whole year corresponds with the need for an advance, the need for basing that advance on past income, the need for providing liquid assets or the need for superannuation companies to borrow money at interest which will either be paid to the victims of tax file number mania or the general members of funds. I do not see why there is a need for these advances. I cannot see how this is essential for the functioning of the tax on the rich. We are prepared to support the ALP amendments to remove this particular aspect of the plan.

I urge the government to think about the consequences of moving along this direction without considering some of the checks and balances that have been suggested by the ALP in this regard. We see that part of the consequence is moving from a situation where, as a community, we see pensions as a right. We are moving into a situation of high complexity. We are moving to a situation where somehow the rights of private corporations are overruling the rights of individuals—their right of privacy, their right of being able to make their own decisions about their own lives.

This is amazing coming from a government of so-called free enterprise and free choice. Very little choice is involved here except for the people at the very highest levels of the income scale. The problem—to be as unkind as I am going to be at this stage—started with Labor and the assumption that, if you bring in further superannuation to replace pensions, somehow or other successive governments will not pick this up and turn it against the average person in the street.

This is what has happened. This is what I said a couple of years ago would happen, and I am now saying, `I told you so.' We are losing pension rights. We have a situation where pensions may be the equivalent of the 1930s dole, which is now becoming the 1997 dole: you get it only if you can prove you cannot live otherwise. Maybe we are going to have `work for the pension' in the future along with these ridiculous superannuation schemes. In the meantime, we are prepared to support a fairer superannuation schedule. Please rethink your ridiculous schemes and support the ALP's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of brief issues I want to raise with the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp). Senator Margetts has covered well the issue of tax file numbers in the banking system. Senator Kemp, as you well know that was introduced as a tax avoidance measure, not as a tax collection measure, which is what we have here in front of us today.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the circulation of the amendments, Senator Kemp, the vast bulk of our amendments was circulated some weeks ago. There are two or three additional amendments that you saw this morning. I have a surprise for you—we have a new one. I had a call in respect of a further problem, and we will get to that a little later with this surcharge issue. It is relatively minor in the context of all the problems we face but a very serious problem for people who are military personnel.

Senator Kemp—and Senator Margetts touched on this issue earlier—where a person has a legitimate objection to providing a tax file number because of privacy concerns, has there been any consideration of how they are to be treated when they say, `I do not wish to provide my tax file number for fundamental privacy reasons'?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to go to a couple of points that Senator Kemp made in his earlier contribution because I think they show very clearly and succinctly that, behind the facade of a surcharge, this government is thinking of the application of this legislation in terms of a tax—nothing more, nothing less. You only need to go to his exact words about his government's efforts, which they claim will allow them to closely monitor the implementation of this legislation and promote the need for people to lodge their tax file numbers. Indeed, the government intends to enforce this—in Senator Kemp's words—through the Tax Pack; through the ATO. They have advocated, in response to these amendments and in placating the Democrats, that part of the process will be to delay this to allow the tax department to effectively seek the information from taxpayers in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to ask a number of questions with respect to this. Minister, have you endeavoured to cost out the administration of this side of making this botched up scheme work? Have you taken into account exactly what the imposition, financially, will be upon the taxation department in advocating another layer to make this botched up system work? What is the estimate of the cost of the placating words you have offered the Democrats in return for their opposition to what are, I think, our worthy and sensible amendments? If you could answer that at this point in time, it would be quite useful. I suspect, though, that you will refer the issue back to the tax department and seek information.

I really think that, for all we have heard so far in this debate in the committee stage, there is no other conclusion you can draw except that this is a manipulation of revenue on behalf of the government. Senator Kemp, in his efforts to explain and give something of a response of substance to this chamber, has relied primarily on interjections.

I believe that this government is just going to the next extreme in putting together a piece of legislation that is obviously policy on the hop. The latest process in dealing with some of the Democrats' ideas, again, is essentially quite a fundamental change in their approach. They are now saying that they will delay the collection of TFNs, whereas I do recall, the last time I was in this chamber, that it was absolutely essential for the government to get that information out on the table very quickly.

That goes to the next issue. If we are dealing with a surcharge, why is the government insisting upon the close role of the tax department? There is no explanation other than that this government is trying to utilise a secondary body to collect what they are calling a surcharge but which is indeed a tax. To do this raises a whole lot of other questions with regard to the legality of this legislation and the ability of this government to use funds to collect tax on behalf of their members, not only with respect to the current financial year but also—going to the heart of our amendments—with respect to advance instalments.

To utilise superannuation funds in this way is, as Senator Margetts has said, a complete betrayal of the way superannuation has been introduced to the Australian people. It is a complete betrayal because, in the past, there has been support for superannuation as a viable retirement income option for many Australians. To manipulate taxation on contributions at this point in time will not just leave us with a flawed piece of legislation—which, no doubt, will be an administrative nightmare and unfair in its application, particularly for low‐ and middle‐income earners—it will leave us with a legacy of diminished faith and trust in superannuation as a product for all Australians. This will be the result of the government's willingness to tamper with the application of taxation to superannuation—a tax which the government is still calling a surcharge.

Minister, I would appreciate it if you could give the chamber a response to those questions I asked earlier. Could you tell this committee what the government intends to do to try and restore the damage that has been done to superannuation generally in the eyes of the public and to their faith in superannuation as being a genuine option for retirement savings, whether you are a low‐ or middle‐income earner or, indeed, a high‐income earner. I agree with the point made again by my colleagues supporting these amendments that higher income earners do have other options. Why should they burden themselves with an additional tax? They will look elsewhere; they do have options available.

Once again, you used the word `choice' but you are denying low‐ and middle‐income earners a choice. You are denying them options that would otherwise be there for them in the same way that you used rhetoric about the child care cuts giving more choice to women. That is a fallacy, as were your words about increasing choice for consumers in respect of superannuation. You spoke about `individual choice' with respect to supplying the TFN.

What you said, Senator Kemp, was that members of funds have an individual choice about whether or not they supply their tax file number to their fund and whether or not they are prepared to bear the burden of this 15 per cent tax slug. That is a great choice! It typifies the choice that we have under this government: it is a choice that either you do it or you pay a financial penalty. In this case, you pay an extra 15 per cent. Great choice! With child care, to use an analogy, you either pay the increased child care costs or you leave work. That is the sort of choice we have under this government and it is as unacceptable in this debate as it is in the other debates relating to cuts to other social services. It is not choice; it is financial blackmail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the minister clarify the position with regard to judicial pensions? Could you clarify what the position is with regard to federal and state judges? As I understand it, they are not to be affected by the present legislation. If you could clarify that it would be very helpful, keeping in mind as you would, Senator Kemp, that they work long hours and it is in the public interest that proper attention be given to their retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the judges will note your interest in this issue, Senator Cooney, as a former distinguished member of the bar. I shall come back to the points you raised because they are interesting and important.

SPEECH.PARA: Before it completely escapes my mind, I want to refer to a bit of Senator Lundy's speech. There are a couple of issues which I will address. Essentially, it was a highly political, wide ranging attack which got into child care and a whole host of other issues. You are entitled to make that speech, but I do not propose to respond in great detail.

Senator Lundy, before you get up on one of the hobby horses that you have from time to time, I want to make the point to you that your leader and your party signed on to the 15 per cent surcharge because they believed it would help restore equity in the superannuation system. There was nothing in your speech which gave the slightest hint that you have any knowledge of that whatsoever. I defy you to go back and read your speech. It is one thing to carry on about the way it is—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is one thing to come up with a decent bill.

—You have had your go, Senator Lundy. You had a good whack so I am entitled to respond. There was no recognition in your speech—at least until you mentioned Senator Sherry's press conference today—that this was your party's policy and your party supported it.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I would refer to is the relentless claim that the superannuation industry has been damaged in a couple of ways. You did not demonstrate—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask anyone.

—What you asked is: are the funds flowing into superannuation and are new funds being established? It is all very well to hear people, who have a great self‐interest in this issue, saying that the industry has been damaged. If it has been damaged, it has been damaged because of the somewhat hysterical comments that a number of people have made.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that the funds are flowing very handsomely into superannuation. Just to console you, Senator Lundy, I will read an article from the Business Review Weekly which states:

A century ago Mark Twain sent a cable to Associated Press. It read, `The reports of my death are greatly exaggerated.' In 1997, the do it yourself superannuation industry is putting out the same message.
It goes on a couple of paragraphs later to state:
Despite the doomsdaying, super is even more popular with investors and the number of DIY funds is increasing at the rate of about 2,400 a month.

If you are going around saying that superannuation is being damaged, you have to demonstrate, by more than just the rhetorical flourishes, that that is occurring. When you stand up—if you wish to stand up; I am not encouraging you to—maybe you might like to actually produce a fact which demonstrates the very substantive point that you have asserted. I do believe that, on the basis of the statistics at the moment, we are seeing funds flowing into superannuation at increasing rates. I have quoted that recent article from the Business Review Weekly to show that.

In relation to the issue of conscientious objections, which was raised by Senator Margetts, I point out that there are people, and Senator Margetts raised the issue, who have a conscientious objection to quoting a TFN to the funds. I am advised by the tax office that, as an alternative, individuals can come to the Australian Taxation Office directly, quote their TFN and provide the relevant details to the Australian Taxation Office, which can then be used to apply the surcharge threshold properly. So they do not have to give it to the funds. If they wish to not deal with the funds but the tax office directly, that is the advice I have received. This avoids the need for the individual to quote their TFN to the super fund. I think that deals with the—

TALK.START.PARA: —That says it all Senator Kemp. Thank you very much.
—Senator Lundy, I am glad you think—
—It is a tax. I can't understand why you are still persisting.

—Senator Lundy again seems to find it difficult to grab hold of whether or not the surcharge is part of her party's policy, depending on the mood of the moment. I think that deals with that particular issue.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the matter raised by Senator Cooney, I point out that current members of the judiciary appointed to courts established by the Commonwealth will not be subject to the surcharge. For constitutional reasons, as we have outlined, newly appointed judges will be subject to the surcharge. The matter of state judges affected by the application of the surcharge in relation to state schemes is still being considered and discussed by the government—

TALK.START.PARA: —`Still being considered and discussed'? You said, `Still being considered.'
—with the states—
—Have you got a solution yet?
—We have outlined that we will be discussing the issue of other constitutionally protected schemes with the states.
—When is it going to be concluded?

—I have outlined the process for you, Senator Sherry. I think that deals with the issues which have been raised. Senator Lundy was worried about the tax office being used for the surcharge. Senator Lundy, let me assure you that the systems are in place to carry out the very extensive procedures which I have outlined and which I am sure all of us who are concerned with the proper functioning of the system would support.
—Minister, can you please outline the full implications for members of the CSS and PSS in terms of the application of the proposed legislation as it currently stands?
—I think I can do better. I will give you a large press statement that has been issued from time to time on these issues.
—Just a summary. What does it mean for public servants being made redundant?
—I am surprised, Senator, that you have not actually caught up—
—I am asking you, Minister.

—That is all right. You can ask me. You are quite entitled to ask me and I will certainly respond to you, Senator. You would be aware of various press statements which have been issued. For high income earners in the Public Service there will be a surcharge applied and of course low and middle income earners will be exempt. —Minister, just on redundancy, if they get a redundancy this year what is their situation?

—One tries to assist you, Senator. One attempts to give you the information which is factual and accurate. —Chartered accountants.
