ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very important question. It relates to issues that all Australians are concerned about. Those issues concern employment opportunities, interest rates, health costs and so forth.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —These are the major issues for most Australians, Senator Bolkus, the issues which you missed when you were in government. In addressing this question, it is worth comparing our achievements over just one year with those of 13 years of Labor. The record of Labor should always be remembered. Labor gave the people of Australia home interest rates of about 17 per cent, if we think of 1989‐90, credit card interest rates of 25 per cent, the second highest prime interest rate in the world, record foreign debt and, when we came to office, a $10 billion black hole which the leadership of the Australian Labor Party said to the people of Australia during the election did not exist. `The books would be in the black,' the Australian people were told. The truth was a $10 billion black hole. That is what the new Howard government inherited and that is what the Howard government had to address.

ANSWER.PARA: What have we been able to do, springing from the first budget of the Howard government? The answer is: a great deal. First and perhaps foremost is the family tax initiative. We believed it was time to give back to those who had done it hardest under Labor some real benefit. We gave it back to two million eligible families. We gave back $1 billion in tax relief, even though we were at the same time addressing that $10 billion black hole. So those who had suffered most were given that taxation benefit, and it helps them.
Senator Bolkus interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, you do not understand because you are out of touch—$34 a fortnight to families doing it hard is very useful. You would not understand that sort of thing. But that was very important for ordinary Australians. They needed and deserved that and they got it from the Howard government.

BREAK.PARA: The private health insurance incentives scheme will give $600 million back to those who take out private health insurance, and they have got until 1 July to do so. That is very useful. It represents a 20 per cent reduction in health insurance costs—$125 a year for singles, $250 for couples. It is a very significant return to the people of Australia to help them with their health care costs.

Remember business? Business has benefited greatly under the packages that have been brought down under the first Howard government. Do you remember the reduction in the provisional tax uplift factor to six per cent? A promise was made and the promise was delivered. There was the extended capital gains rollover relief to allow those people in small business to roll over to larger businesses without paying capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did Tony O'Leary write this?
—Order! There are too many opposition interjections.
—Remember the capital gains reforms that were designed to help those who were retiring—a benefit of up to $500,000. There was the tax treatment to encourage share ownership—and one could go on.

BREAK.PARA: This government is very conscious of the need to support, in particular, small business, which is the engine of job growth in this country. That is something that Labor never understood. But, Madam President, it is not just small business—pensioners have also done well under Howard. They benefited with self‐funded retirees now enjoying the same tax threshold for their savings as other pensioners. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. Minister, do you agree that it is inappropriate for operational matters which are before the Australian Federal Police to be raised in debates in this chamber or at its committees? Why has the Prime Minister failed to respond to Senator Faulkner's request of 9 April 1997 for a confidential briefing on what operational matters the AFP are considering in relation to Senator Colston? Minister, how can the opposition be expected to avoid raising operational matters when the government has failed to inform us in confidence of which matters to avoid?

—Speaking generally, yes, I do not think that it is appropriate to raise operational matters. Why has Mr Howard failed to respond? I will seek a reply from him on that. Does that excuse the Labor Party from raising operational matters? I would have thought not. It is generally very easy to understand what are operational matters, Madam President, and, if there is any doubt, you normally err on the side of caution. If Senator Ray follows that principle, the whole place will be better off.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am sure we will follow that principle but, if that principle is so easy to observe, Senator Hill, how do you explain the fact that time and time again at the opposition question time tactics meeting, when you were Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, you sanctioned—according to evidence given under oath recently at the CJC inquiry—the raising of operational matters to do with AFP investigations into Operation Wallah in questions here, at estimates committee and at the select committee on uranium waste?

—The premise to that question is, of course, that you should accept as a fact the evidence that has been given before a certain CJC. I suggest, Senator Ray, you should act with caution on that matter.

—My question is addressed to Senator Rod Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, recently we have seen encouraging economic news on a number of fronts, including a lift in retail sales, continuing low inflation and interest rates and, over the March quarter, a lift in the number of job vacancies. Do these support the view that this optimism is the result of important government initiatives which give priority to families and small business and will result in the economy strengthening over the remainder of the year? How will Australian families and business continue to benefit from the government's sound economic management?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Sandy Macdonald for that question. Of course, the underlying assumption in the question is absolutely correct. Earlier this year, in response to a question in the Senate, I said that the government was confident that growth would pick up over the remainder of the year. Madam President, I am pleased to report that recent economic developments support that view.

ANSWER.PARA: Retail trade, a key component of consumption expenditure, rose by a very solid 2.2 per cent in the March quarter. Motor vehicle registrations rose by two per cent in March, and they have now risen by 8.2 per cent over the year. ANZ job advertisements rose by 16.7 per cent in April, as was published in the paper this morning—and that is the largest single monthly increase ever. Even excluding the estimated effects of an early Easter, ANZ made an estimate that vacancies rose by five per cent in April—a sizeable increase by historical standards. This provides further support for the view that the labour market will strengthen over coming months.

We were also very pleased with the excellent CPI result for the March quarter. The headline rate rose by just over 0.2 per cent in the March quarter and by 1.3 per cent over the year to March. The underlying CPI rose by 0.4 per cent in the March quarter and by 2.1 per cent over the year to March. We are very pleased with that result. It was a brilliant out‐turn, and I think was widely welcomed in the community. It makes Australia a very low inflation country indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It only makes up for the climb last month.
—Is there going to be a cut today?

—We are pleased that we have been able to take the pressure off interest rates with a fair fiscal policy. Senator Cook raised the issue of interest rates. Senator Cook, do you know what interest rates rose to under your government? Do you know that they rose to 17 per cent—and were rising? I have never heard you in any of your statements, Senator Cook, apologise for the high interest rate policies that Labor followed.

BREAK.PARA: The Labor Party is synonymous with high interest rates. You are the high interest rate party; the Labor Party is the high interest rate party. The coalition government is a low interest rate government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you guarantee that interest rates will remain down for the term of your government?
—Order! Senator Kemp, direct your remarks through the chair.

—Madam President, I can understand that Senator Cook would get embarrassed when we refer to the interest rate record of the government of which he was a minister. You were not a good minister but there were worse than you, Senator Cook, I have to say. I can never recall you in any way acknowledging to the Australian public the damage that your high interest rate policies were followed by.

BREAK.PARA: Of course, Madam President, by making inroads into Labor's legacy of high deficits—remember your high deficits, Senator Cook?—and exploding government debt in last year's budget, we have assisted in cutting 1.5 percentage points off official interest rates. This cut and intensified competition have meant that home mortgage rates have fallen by almost three percentage points. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. Minister, given the Prime Minister's self-proclaimed adoption of the high moral ground on the Colston affair, why does the government continue to refuse to detail its discussions with Senator Colston prior to his defection from the ALP and his elevation to the deputy presidency of the Senate? Minister, will you give the Senate a clear and strong assurance that there were absolutely no linkages between the government's support for Senator Colston as Deputy President and Senator Colston's support for government legislation?
—There were no linkages between the election—our decision to vote for Senator Colston—and any issue relating to any legislation.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I ask again: why does the government refuse to detail the nature of the discussions it had with Senator Colston prior to his elevation to the deputy presidency? Perhaps you could also assure the Senate that there were no linkages between the prime ministerial decision to upgrade Senator Colston's staffer and Senator Colston's support for government legislation?

—I give you that second assurance that you are seeking. In relation to discussions, if I remember rightly, after the election of Senator Colston, you asked questions of a similar nature at that time and got answers. If the answers were not in the detail that you required, it might be because the facts did not support it.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, three of the world's most powerful leaders have now recently made Australian visits—President Clinton, Prime Minister Hashimoto and now Chancellor Kohl—and each has essentially snubbed your government's greenhouse plans and indeed said that they are not interested in your differentiation model. So I ask: firstly, given that your policy has failed to attract any meaningful support, are you going to continue to pursue it; secondly, are you at all concerned about the risk of trade sanctions or the risk to industries such as our tourism industry that relies on a clean green image to attract people to Australia; and, finally, are you willing to have Australia branded internationally as an isolationist nation and, indeed, as a nation that is a rogue when it comes to major environment issues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —There is, with respect, a lot of nonsense contained within that question. There is no question of being isolationist. In fact, we are negotiating within the Berlin mandate process for an outcome that will achieve a better global result in relation to greenhouse gases, and we are doing so with a commitment that Australia should play its part. I remind the honourable senator that, in fact, Australia is responsible for just over one per cent of international greenhouse gases—
—Globally.
—Globally. So to be quite frank, whatever we do is not going to have a lot of effect on the total picture.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, we accept that we have to play our part and we have to improve our performance. That is why we are vigorously engaged within the greenhouse challenge programs and in other ways in which we are engaging Australian business to operate more efficiently with respect to energy. That has economic benefits as well as greenhouse benefits. The reception, the response, from Australian business in that regard really has been quite tremendous. If the honourable senator were seriously interested in this issue, she might have liked to be in Brisbane last week when some 16 different Australian corporates and business associations joined us in a pledge to do better—but, further than that, actually set out their plans, that now have government sanction, to achieve a better outcome.

So domestically we are doing the right thing, which is actually producing a better result, in terms of percentage change, than a lot of those countries that are criticising us, Senator; and internationally we are supporting an international negotiation that will lead to a better global outcome. So our position is not isolationist.

But the outcome to work must be one that is fair and achievable. It will only be fair and achievable if it, in fact, reflects the different structures of economies. The Europeans to whom I think you are referring have accepted that. They have accepted that between the countries of the European Union they should allow differentiation. In fact, they have said that for 28 of the 36 annex 1 countries differentiation should be allowed—but not for Australia.

We believe that we have an entitlement in these negotiations to consider Australia's economic interests. We want this economy to grow. We want to create more jobs. We are determined to achieve that outcome—but we are also determined to achieve that outcome consistent with a good domestic response on greenhouse. That is the position of this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. What is `isolationist' if it is not being left on one's own? There is no industrialised country left anywhere in the world that is supporting us. I ask: Minister, in saying that you are supporting Australian jobs, are you not referring to a few traditional industries—indeed, the industries that are supporting the development of your policy—and ignoring the potential for the tens of thousands of new jobs in green industries—industries that are actually going to make some real impact on our climate, a positive impact for a change? And, when we look at the Prime Minister making comments that, indeed, he may not send anyone to the meeting in December, surely that is really putting at risk any chance Australia has to come out with a good and positive result for this country.

—Madam President, if differentiation is allowable for 28 out of 36 countries, how can our position be said to be isolationist? We argue for differentiation because it is needed to produce a fair and achievable outcome, and 28 countries agree with that in principle. Some of the countries not included in the 28 also agree with it in principle. I accept they argue that it is complex and that time is against it, but that is not a reason to walk away from the challenge. That is why we are not walking away from it. We are in there vigorously seeking to persuade the countries with whom we are negotiating that what we are proposing is fair and reasonable, and that will continue to be our policy position during the course of this year.

—My question is directed to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, did you, at any stage during March of this year, or did anyone on your behalf, meet or have discussions with Mrs Christine Smith of Senator Colston's office?

—I am not sure of the precise time. I think during the course of that month I did meet Christine Smith but, other than being introduced to her and perhaps a few words being said, I do not think there was any discussion of any substance.
—Really?
—I am simply telling you that the circumstances in which Christine Smith happened to be in Senator Colston's office were not known to me and, as I recall, she simply came in—
—The question is: were you being consulted?

—I happen to visit a number of people in the course of Senate business—I think you would expect that to be the case. There is nothing unusual about having discussions with members of other parties and other independent senators. Indeed, it ought to be patently obvious that there are circumstances in which it is more realistic to be talking to some parties than to others. In other words, if there was a prospect of persuasion, if there was a prospect of exploring amendments, then clearly, as we did with the Labor Party in relation to the package of telecommunications bills, there was a great deal of consultation and it was perfectly proper. The fact is that there is nothing unusual about me speaking to any senators in this chamber or, indeed, any of us having discussions on matters that are of relevance to the business of the Senate.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask Senator Faulkner: what was the nature of the meeting or discussions that took place?
—Nothing of substance.
—If, as Senator Hill interjects, nothing of substance took place, I ask you, Senator Alston: what matters were discussed at your meeting with Mrs Smith?
—Madam President, in relation to Christine Smith, the fact is that it was indicated to me by Senator Colston that he did have a defence to matters—
—So you weren't discussing telecommunications?
—Just a moment. These were matters concerning the business of the Senate, and I would have thought it is very important for us to be made aware of matters that might affect—
—On what day?
—On what day was the discussion?
—Before or after the fix?

—I will treat that with the respect it deserves, Madam President, because there was never any fix of any description. Certainly, if you are inferring that somehow there was any agreement involving our side of the chamber, then I can categorically refute that proposition. Christine Smith was the person who Senator Colston indicated was prepared to support his version of events, in other words, to refute the allegations that were being made against him. I presume that he was—(Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. I ask the minister: what support does he have for his prime constituency in the Wilderness Society, which has been today protesting against the bulk carrier woodchip ship in Burnie exporting 40,000 tonnes of pure rainforest as woodchips to the pulp mills of Japan? Why has the minister agreed to his colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy licensing North Broken Hill, the world's biggest hardwood export woodchipper, to log large tracts of pure rainforest south of Burnie for export to the Northern Hemisphere as woodchips, and why did he advise the minister that no environmental impact statement was required before the destruction of these rainforests? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, in relation to government policy on forests, let me say that we are doing what we committed ourselves to do, that is, providing resource security for Australian industry that will help produce jobs whilst, on the other hand, contributing to development of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system which will be the envy of the world. As you know, going for a target of 15 per cent of that which existed pre‐white settlement in Australia—some 50 per cent above the IUCN recommended level—is a very ambitious, but sensible, I would suggest, Senator Brown, environmental outcome and one which I would have thought you should applaud.

ANSWER.PARA: Furthermore, in relation to the clearing of native vegetation for the re‐establishment of plantations—which, by and large, I think is a good thing and I think the more extensive the plantings of forests in Australia the less pressure there will be on native forests, which, I would have thought, you would say was a good thing as well, in principle—in the tests applying that re‐establishment, we had to be satisfied that it would not be required within the RFA system. We took advice from the CSIRO and we took advice from another authority from Tasmania and, basically, it met the criteria that we had earlier published.

My memory of the matter—it is now some months ago—was that there was very little rainforest involved at all. I would like to re‐check that, but I think that that is the case. And if that is the case, Senator, then you are deliberately misleading the Senate today in order to add a bit of media interest to your story. By and large, I think that that is correct. Therefore, the outcome is consistent with our objective of a world‐class reserve system, an encouragement to the growth of plantation timber and also an allowable harvesting of native forest consistent with all the rules and safeguards that we set out that will enable the higher standards of ecological scrutiny to take place as well as provide job opportunities for Australia—Tasmania in particular, in this instance—and that is part of our goal.

TALK.START.PARA: —My further question to this reprehensible minister—
—Senator, would you rephrase your question.

—No, Madam, the action that is involved here is reprehensible. The minister is involved in reprehensible destruction of rainforests in this country. I ask the minister: why did you ignore the Forest Practices Board report commissioned by the government—
—I raise a point of order, Madam President. I distinctly heard you ask the senator to rephrase his question. He is ignoring you and treating you with contempt. Would you bring him to order.
—I will indeed, yes. Senator, will you continue your question but withdraw the word `reprehensible'.
—Madam, in this situation the word `reprehensible' for the minister's actions is apt.
—Senator, you are debating the issue. I have asked you to withdraw the word. You may debate the issue on another occasion.
—I feel so strongly about this issue that I cannot withdraw that word, Madam President.
—I ask you to withdraw, Senator Brown.
—Madam, I insist that this is an apt description of what the minister is doing to these rainforests in Tasmania.
—You are debating the issue. Are you refusing—
—I cannot withdraw, Madam.

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. If it is any help, it is like being slapped by a feather by this senator. We know what he wants. He wants to make himself another newspaper story. I certainly would not want to be involved in any process—if I might say, with respect, Madam President—that would facilitate his doing that, because he is wrong on the facts in relation to the question, apart from anything else.
—Thank you. Senator Brown, you may continue your question.

—Thank you, Madam President. I say again to the minister who accepts the appellation that the Forest Practices Board told your government that these were intact calindendrous—that is, cathedral like—rainforests in tracts of more than 1,000 hectares, which were floristically intact. I ask you: why did you ignore that advice? Are you saying that the CSIRO endorsed your plan to destroy these rainforests, and why have you picked out Tasmania as the only state in which rainforests may be destroyed? (Time expired)

—In giving advice to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who makes the decision, as the senator knows, I did take into account the advice of the Forest Practices Board and of the CSIRO. But I again say that Senator Brown's recollection of the facts within that advice are very different from my recollection.
—You are wrong.

—I will refresh my memory and it may well be that we will pursue this matter later in estimates. But you do tend to exaggerate grossly, Senator, in order to try to make yourself a media hero, and I think you have done it again here.

—My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, did you at any stage during March this year, or did anyone on your behalf, meet or have discussions with Mrs Christine Smith of Senator Colston's office?

—I do not think I know Christine Smith. Somebody has since told me that she had been working as a receptionist in Senator Colston's office, so I may have met her but I do not recall it. You asked whether anybody acting on my behalf met or had discussions with her: I do not think so—not that I know of.

—I ask a supplementary question. I ask Senator Hill if he met or had discussions with Senator Colston in relation to the statement in which Mrs Smith accepted the blame for the irregularities in Senator Colston's travel allowance claims.
—I regularly have discussions with my colleagues on all sides of the chamber and, unless they authorise me otherwise, I regard those discussions as confidential.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Senator Parer. Minister, are you aware that Labor, both federally and in New South Wales, has embarked on a campaign that is nothing more than political opportunism at the expense of the concern and suffering of families affected by BHP's decision to cease smelting steel in Newcastle? What is the minister's position on Labor's proposal that the government should return to the days of direct intervention in industry? And, Minister, was the previous Labor government aware of the inevitable closures at the BHP steel mill long before this government came to office 14 months ago?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tierney has for many years shown an interest in the Hunter region and Newcastle, as compared, I might say, with the new‐found interest shown by the Labor people on the other side, who showed no interest in this whatsoever.

ANSWER.PARA: While not unanticipated, the BHP announcement has been a shock to Newcastle workers and their families. It is also the end of an era, as Newcastle was the birthplace of Australia's integrated steel industry just over 80 years ago. It is indeed regrettable, as Minister Moore has said, that the reality is that the Newcastle mill is the victim of technology, modern environmental demands and changing markets.

It is also regrettable that the Premier of New South Wales and others seek to make political capital out of those who will suffer as a result of this closure. The Howard government learnt just after coming to office that, for the past two years, BHP had held discussions with the New South Wales Premier, the Newcastle City Council and the unions. Peter Robinson in the Sun‐Herald, who, I might say, is no friend of the coalition, said:
In one breath Premier Bob Carr said: "We knew of the probability of these cuts—the news is not so much a surprise as sad confirmation" . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you know it was coming?
—I will come to that. He goes on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the question remains: if it was all so inevitable, why haven't State—
that is Premier Carr's government—
and local authorities been working for years on alternative employment possibilities?

This is something that has concerned Senator Tierney for a long time. He came to see me last year with BHP people. As a result of that, Minister Moore put together a bipartisan committee made up of both parties which, regrettably, has not yet reported. Do you know why it has not reported, Madam President? I will tell you why. Because Mr Crean dragged his feet on nominating the three Labor representatives. That is why. The demise of the steelworks had been determined well before the Howard government came to power.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the government's response?

—The BHP plan allows of course for a transitional period. It is no good interjecting, Senator Schacht. You might as well listen, because it is important that we do something positive. As the Prime Minister has said:

ANSWER.PARA: We have an opportunity to use that time to assist Newcastle, the workers of BHP and the regional economy to make the transition to a new era. During that period, it is in the interest of all affected parties—the workers, BHP and the government—to concentrate on replacing those jobs with business compatible with the competitive world in which we live. The old union stunt of pulling a strike on BHP operations would be highly irresponsible and certainly not in the interests of those whose jobs are in jeopardy and could in fact endanger other jobs.
Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —`What about a new steel plan' says Senator Cook. Part of the Button plan, Senator, as you would appreciate, was the spending of hundreds of millions of dollars on a new blast furnace at Port Kembla.

ANSWER.PARA: It is significant that the Newcastle‐Hunter region remains one of the major areas of interest for new projects. In my own portfolio, the mining industry has $55 billion worth of committed and proposed developments. Of that, $15 billion is for new mineral projects of which $5.4 billion is in downstream processing. The sum of $480 million was invested in new mines in the Hunter region in the past 12 months. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, can you confirm it was only one meeting you had with Mrs Smith in March this year? Can you inform the Senate as to the details of the discussions you had with Mrs Smith at that meeting? Was Mrs Smith's statement in which she accepted the blame for the irregularities in Senator Colston's travel allowance claims discussed at that meeting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a recollection of having met Christine Smith on any more than one occasion. The occasion on which I did meet her was in the course of a meeting that I think Senator Colston had asked me to come to his room to discuss—I am not sure what it was about, whether it was about the upcoming telecommunications package or anything else.
—You can't remember.

—I know you want to draw all sorts of conclusions. I am simply saying to you that it is not unusual to be invited to see other senators in the course of the business of this chamber. As I recall it, I was simply responding to a request from Senator Colston. In the course of discussions with him, he indicated to me that—and I think that all of us in the chamber would be aware—there were some fairly serious allegations that had been made against him. He indicated to me that he did have an answer to those allegations and that that answer in part at least consisted of a statement from Christine Smith.
—What was the date?
—I do not know, but I would have thought it was probably in the middle of March. I do not have a recollection of it. It is certainly—
—Not the 24th?

—I do not know. Was the 24th the date when the statement was tabled? No, it would have been before that. Certainly, I do not recall any discussion with Christine Smith about the detail of her statement. Indeed, it was not a matter that I was interested in knowing about, other than the fact that there was a plausible defence. It seemed to me that, beyond that point, it was not a matter for us to pass judgment on the merits of what might be said by Christine Smith.

ANSWER.PARA: I can assure the Senate categorically that at no stage did I ever have any suggestion put to me that that statement was anything other than as it appeared to be. I can assure you that, if anything had made me think that there was anything about it that should be of concern, then clearly I would have had a very different view. But I took it at face value. It was simply an explanation which we subsequently in good faith regarded as credible and plausible. That is where the matter remains.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask Senator Alston: when his meeting with Mrs Smith took place, who else was present at the meeting with Mrs Smith? You indicated that you did not have any discussion about the detail of Mrs Smith's statement accepting the blame for the irregularities in Senator Colston's travel allowance claims. Was the issue of Senator Colston's travel allowance claims raised in your discussions with Mrs Smith? Did you discuss that matter?

—I thought I had already indicated that what was being said to me was that, given that I—and presumably everyone else—was aware of potentially serious allegations being made against Senator Colston, he had an answer to those allegations, in the form of a statement by Mrs Christine Smith. What I am saying is that I did not canvass the details or the credibility of that statement with her. She was simply introduced to me. There may have been a brief discussion but, beyond that, it was not of interest to me to test the statement itself or to do anything other than be aware of the fact that that was—
—When did this discussion take place?
—I do not know. I thought I had answered that. I have said to you that this was some time in March, before it was tabled.
—Who else was present?
—I think that perhaps Douglas Colston was present. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Alston, representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. The closure of the BHP plant in Newcastle will result in the loss of at least 2,000 jobs and possibly a further 6,000 ancillary jobs. Two thousand lost jobs and 2,000 consequently on the dole would equate to up to $30 million per year social security costs and, at 8,000 affected employees, would reach up to $120 million per year social security costs. New South Wales needs a second airport, and Newcastle needs jobs. An airport in the Sydney basin, whether it be at Badgerys Creek or Holsworthy or elsewhere in the Sydney basin, is unacceptable on topographical, social, economic and environmental grounds. Has the minister seriously considered Williamtown airport at Newcastle as a viable alternative for a second major airport for New South Wales?

—I am interested to hear that Senator Murray has done his own environmental impact statement and, presumably, can pass on the details of that to Mr Sharp. The government is keen to ensure that these matters are investigated with the greatest thoroughness, and that is why Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy are the subject of very careful scrutiny. If you think that the government ought to be going further afield and looking at places like Williamtown, you are perfectly free to canvass that matter with the minister. I was not quite sure of the logical connection between a second airport for Sydney and the problems besetting Newcastle and the employees of BHP.
—Jobs, dummy!

—All right, you say, `Jobs, dummy.' Jobs can affect a lot of issues and all sorts of projects can be job creating. So, if you are saying to me that you are in favour of any project that creates jobs, I am delighted to hear it. We are probably a bit more discriminating than that, but you have not indicated how you believe that the government can contribute to that process. We are very concerned to create an environment in which more jobs can be created. The latest ANZ survey is very encouraging in that regard and, quite clearly, the people of Newcastle will have to contend with a significant short‐term problem but, to the extent that the government can assist in job creation in the Newcastle region or on the outskirts of Sydney in relation to new airports or any other project, we will be interested in doing that.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question and I apologise for referring to the minister as a dummy. Would the minister also consider the prospect of a high‐speed train from Melbourne to Brisbane, with a first stage linking Sydney and Newcastle as two of its stops?

—I will pass that on, Senator Murray. It clearly has very significant implications. I can say to you that, in talking to one of Chancellor Kohl's assistants last night, he indicated to me that there is a new magnetic levitation train about to be trialled in the German republic which will travel at speeds of up to 500 kilometres per hour and make a tremendous difference to the fast carriage of passengers.
—We already had this evidence three or four years ago.

—As I understood it, this is a world first. This is the rail equivalent of a hydrofoil. It is not the way in which trains operate in France or Japan, where they are regarded as very fast trains; this is super fast. All those technological developments ought to be taken fully into account. If they change the economics of projects in this country, we would be very interested in them. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Alston, Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate. Do you recall a radio interview you did with Neil Mitchell on 9 April this year, during which you struggled to answer a series of questions put to you as to whether you had held a number of telephone conversations with Senator Colston? On 8 April this year, were you informed by Senator Colston or his staff that Senator Colston's staffer, Mrs Smith, had recanted a statement she had made to the Senate? Did you then inform the Prime Minister or his staff of this conversation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I do recall that interview with Neil Mitchell, and the reason I was reluctant to canvass the detail of it was that it seemed to me that, when people make private phone calls, they do not expect them to be blurted out in the public arena. You may have a very different view. I do not know. But information was conveyed to me which did make it clear that there had been a very significant change in circumstances, and I did relay that to the Prime Minister's office. As you are probably aware, I was then dragged out after, I think, the first act of Falstaff , which I had been attending in my capacity as the minister for the arts, although I note that the media all thought I was having a night off, because I had gone to the opera. But the fact is that I did have a conversation with the Prime Minister.
—Were you Falstaff or Henry V?

—You have a few blokes on your side who look a bit more like Falstaff than I do. As a result of the discussion with the Prime Minister, he then took into account the circumstances which had become apparent, and we agreed that he should proceed with a press conference, at which he indicated that he would have the matter referred to the Federal Police. And it ought to be plain that, if there is one difference between our side and your side, it is that back in 1983, when you had a recommendation that certain matters ought to be referred to the Federal Police, you chose not to do that. In fact, on 28 February we had then Senator Evans saying:

ANSWER.PARA: Any decision making was a matter for Special Minister of State Beazley. I have a vague recollection of the matters informally raised with me.
On 6 April, he told Laurie Oakes:
I was not a player. I was in the loop. I was advised. I did express a view.
We now know from the correspondence that in 1983 then Senator Evans as Attorney‐General wrote to Mr Beazley and said:
I believe it would be premature to set in train a police investigation.

Let there be no misunderstanding: your side of politics had the opportunity to respond to advice given to you to refer the matter to the Federal Police. You chose not to do so. You chose to keep the matter very much under wraps. I must say I was almost speechless to hear Mr Beazley say that the reason they did not take any stronger action was that there was no public outcry requiring them to do it. That has to be the most self-serving explanation I have ever heard.

By contrast, on the night of 8 April, Mr Howard did go very public, did call a press conference and did indicate that, in view of the seriousness of the changed circumstances, it was appropriate for the matter to be referred to the Federal Police. That is where the matter stands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator, do you deny the backgrounding version of the events by the Prime Minister's press secretary, Mr Tony O'Leary, which was reported in the Age on 10 April?

—It is a pretty extraordinary performance, isn't it? I am supposed to have an instant recollection of the Age of 10 April. I presume the article itself did not say `according to a background version by Mr Tony O'Leary', so you are really asking me to respond to something when I have not the vaguest idea of its substance. Therefore, I will give you the answer that you have obviously expected.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. Last month you announced stage 1 of the ATSIC‐army community assistance project, which uses the army to help remote Aboriginal communities with the construction of houses, roads, water supply systems and other infrastructure needs. This national initiative will utilise the skills and resources of the Australian Army to deliver urgently needed water and health infrastructure requirements to communities that are disadvantaged by their remote location. The plan has been well received by the indigenous communities. Minister, will you give us details of the other communities to benefit from this program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Heffernan for the question and for his continued interest in Aboriginal affairs. You will recall, Madam President, that Senator Heffernan in his maiden speech drew attention to his knowledge and expertise in this field. I am grateful to him for his continued interest since that time, and this question is consistent with that interest.

ANSWER.PARA: Last month I announced that the communities of Bulla in the Northern Territory and Oak Valley in South Australia would be the first of up to six communities to benefit from the initiative that I originally outlined in the Lyons Memorial Lecture last year. In addition, the army was called in to provide urgent assistance to the community at Oombulgurri in Western Australia, which suffered extensive flood damage recently. The army is currently deployed to the community to undertake repairs to selected infrastructure and to restore services.

The Oak Valley community will benefit with more than a million dollars invested in their health, including the construction of three houses, dust control measures, revegetation, roadworks and the construction of a rubbish tip. Residents of the Bulla community will gain in houses—10 in all—and an upgraded sewerage system to a total cost of $1.76 million.

BREAK.PARA: We have now identified three more communities for the pilot program, all in the Northern Territory. The Milyakburra community is an established community of approximately 190 people located on Bickerton Island, north‐west of Groote Eylandt, and work will include the construction of a sewerage system and possible additional tasks such as the refurbishment of roads and a barge landing site.

The Galiwinku out‐stations consist of 31 recognisable settlements in the north‐east Arnhem region and work will include approximately 10 new houses and upgrades to existing power and water supply systems. Construction is planned for the first half of 1998.

The Kaltukatjara community, or Docker River community as it is more commonly known, consists of approximately 330 people located 520 kilometres west-south-west of Alice Springs and works will include construction of a reticulated sewerage system, improvements to existing road drainage, upgrading of the airstrip and refurbishment of existing roads and the community rubbish tip. Construction is planned for the first half of 1998. Negotiations are also under way with a community in Queensland.

It gives me great pleasure to announce this, but I want you to contrast that with 13 years of the Labor Party being in power where these things could have been addressed. There is constant repetition—and I acknowledge this—of the deleterious state that many indigenous communities have, and this is after 13 years of the previous government. We are not going to sit back and ignore the problems, as was the case previously. Actions speak louder than words, and we are not into the political rhetoric that was always coming from the other side.
Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are doing something about it, Senator Sherry. We are utilising existing resources to do it and, therefore, are minimising the cost. I want to draw that contrast to the Senate's attention because, as I go along in this portfolio, I will be announcing similar projects that we are dealing with. We have identified many other communities and we are putting money into those commu nities, Senator Bolkus. What do you have to show for the 13 years that you were in government where all these things were swept under the carpet and where you pretended that they did not exist?

BREAK.PARA: I have now visited over 60 communities around Australia, some of which did not know of the existence of a minister for Aboriginal affairs. In fact, as I have mentioned previously, I was the first minister ever to visit the ATSIC office in Perth since it has been there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that right? Fair dinkum?
—Yes, I was the first minister ever. After going to those 60 communities, I believe that I am in a position now to assist in this regard. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, on a recent trip to Finke, we discovered that, I think, 80 per cent of the children there have early signs of glaucoma. Could you outline to the Senate the importance of freshwater and sewerage, what we found on that trip and what a great addition to the health of these people this initiative will bring?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Finke community at Apatula was one of the most outstanding communities that I have visited. Despite the rhetoric that we heard from the other side in relation to some communities, I had much pleasure in turning the first sod for the sewerage system that is being installed for the Finke community. There is an 80 per cent retention rate at the school there. It is a dry community, as you know, Senator Heffernan. It has enormous community support within the community itself. They are reconstructing houses there.

ANSWER.PARA: The progress shown within that community is a good example of what can be achieved by Aboriginal communities themselves when they are given self‐empowerment, as I am doing within this portfolio, so that they can take responsibility for determining how the funds should be spent and what the community's needs are. I believe that that is the future that we should approach. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. Did the Prime Minister, prior to his press conference on 8 April, consult the Attorney-General regarding the decision to refer the alleged misuse of entitlements by Senator Colston to the Australian Federal Police? If he did consult the Attorney-General, why did he fail to mention this at the press conference when he only stated that he had consulted with the Minister for Administrative Services and the President of the Senate? Who does have the power to refer matters to the AFP—the Prime Minister, or the Attorney-General?
—I will ask the Prime Minister for a response to the first two parts of the question. Who does have the power to refer matters to the police? It is normally done, as I understand it, by the A‐G.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given the Prime Minister's statement claiming that he referred it, I refer you to a letter to the President of the Senate dated 26 March 1997 when the Attorney-General stated:

QUESTION.PARA: In accordance with the usual procedure for handling an investigation such as this, I ask that if . . . you decide to refer matters to the AFP, the referral be through my office.

Minister, did not the Attorney-General's lame invocation of `usual procedure' in that letter basically count for nothing when political expediency demanded that the Prime Minister act quickly? Does all this not prove that the A‐G's failure to refer this matter to the AFP on 26 March—some two weeks earlier—was nothing but a politically motivated ruse to buy time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The hypocrisy knows no bounds. This is coming from the side on which Mr Beazley and the then Senator Gareth Evans—now the Leader and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition—were advised by the highest law officers in the land to send the matter relating to Senator Colston to the police. And what did they do? They put it under the table—better to keep it secret. There were a number of excuses. They said that Senator Colston was a new boy, that he should be treated gently. He had been here for years. Then we had that appalling excuse that no-one had complained about it. No-one had complained about it, because it was under the table; they were not supposed to know.

ANSWER.PARA: Now you come in here and complain about us sending a matter to the Federal Police. You have got a nerve, Senator Bolkus. You should be embarrassed by this whole matter. What happened after 1983? When you, in 1990, decided to support Senator Colston, you knew about 1983, didn't you? We didn't, because it was under the table. It was your knowledge. You have got a nerve to come in here and attack us.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Will the minister inform the Senate how the government is providing more opportunities for Australian students to enter universities? Will the minister inform the Senate about some of the more enlightened views on the introduction of full fee paying undergraduate places and allay some of the unwarranted concerns about this proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, you may know what pleasure it gives me to answer this question from Senator Payne, who I welcome here today. This government is about creating more opportunities for all Australians. Those on the other side do not like it, but we are increasing the number of government funded undergraduate places at universities. Next year there will be 10,000 extra places over the 1996 levels. We are also giving universities the incentive to provide even more opportunities to Australian students. We are providing universities with the means to do this in two ways.

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, universities will be encouraged to expand their number of HECS funded places after our policy of agreeing to return to them the minimum up-front HECS contribution for each HECS student they over‐enrol. The previous government, when a university over‐enrolled, took the HECS contribution from the student, put it in the government's back pocket and left the university without any money. We have changed that and that will encourage universities to take on more students.
Secondly, universities now have the opportunity to introduce full fee places for Australian students at the undergraduate level.

TALK.START.PARA: —You'll have to do a lot better than that.

—It is very important that people understand that these places can only be offered in a course as additional places and not at the expense of any of the HECS funded—that is, government funded—university admissions.
—You know that's not right.
—Senator Carr, stop interjecting.
—The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee understands this perfectly well. The Executive Director, Stuart Hamilton, confirmed recently:

ANSWER.PARA: The minister has made it clear there is to be no reduction of publicly funded places, and universities have no intention of reducing the number of publicly funded places.

Indeed, for universities to do so would incur severe financial penalties, as the guidelines I released last week made clear. The government has also placed a maximum 25 per cent cap on the number of fee paying places which a university can offer in any one course. That figure is set in concrete not only in the guidelines but also in legislation.

Last week the National Union of Students and the shadow minister, Mark Latham—poor thing—trying hard to get himself a headline, badly misread or misrepresented, one or the other, the guidelines and claimed that the 25 per cent cap was only an interim measure. Talk about the rich and thick! This is the line that the now shadow education spokesperson uses—`rich and thick,' not a line that anybody interested in education should ever use. It is a favourite term of his, presumably to imply his own cleverness. Nonetheless, he completely failed to understand the completely unambiguous wording of the guidelines, which strengthens the operation of the 25 per cent limit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Transitional. That's the word you used.

—And Senator Carr, by his interjection, indicates that he, too, cannot read. Another concern I hear is that the quality of our universities will drop. That is absolute garbage. Contrary to the ranting and raving of senators opposite, full fees will not lower the academic standards of Australian universities. Fee paying students will be treated in the same way as other students in a course. The Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee, which is not always known for agreeing with me, has nonetheless quite happily said, through Professor Fay Gale, that universities would not be chasing dollars without proper regard for the protection of academic standards. Professor Alan Gilbert of the University of Melbourne agrees. He says:

BREAK.PARA: One of the principles we would follow—
I notice Gavin Brown saying the same thing in Sydney—
is that we will not be lowering standards in Melbourne to accommodate fee based programs.
I will quote Professor Niland, the Vice-Chancellor of the University of New South Wales—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister provide any more information to explain the benefits to Australian higher education of allowing fee paying places in addition to government funded places?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can, Senator Payne. Professor Niland, the Vice‐Chancellor of the University of New South Wales, says that to target the thick but rich would be both unethical and bad business. If you do not believe me, just ask the former minister, Peter Baldwin. He as a Labor minister introduced full fees at postgraduate level and for international students at undergraduate level, and we did not hear any complaints on the other side.

ANSWER.PARA: Kim Beazley Senior might agree. In 1983, in an article in the higher education supple‐

BREAK.PARA: ment, he clearly identified that middle‐class welfare was alive and well in the Labor Party. They are happy always to complain about other people getting money but not when their own get it. After 13 years of Labor, that has not changed at all. Our goal is to get more students from all walks of life into university. As Professor Niland put it:

To argue that it is somehow unethical to offer university places on a fee paying basis is like trying to defend public libraries by banning bookshops, because a university education is not like a book. It is like the experience of reading a book. The value of the experience depends on the book and the reader, not the means by which they are bound together.
(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner recently reminded me of a courtesy, that changes to the frontbench be announced in the chamber at the start of question time. He must have forgotten the courtesy on this occasion, because I am looking forward to his telling us how he lost his job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John
