SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add to my answer to Senator Brown's question. As I suspected, his question was false and misleading, which unfortunately is all too often the case. He could have mentioned, for example, that of the 80—
—Madam President, on a point of order: I claim to have been misrepresented by what the minister has just said. I will seek an opportunity, at your discretion, to respond to that accusation.
—That is another matter. I do not think that I have heard sufficient yet to come to any conclusion.

—Firstly, he could have mentioned that in fact North voluntarily excludes some 26,000 hectares of the 85,000‐hectare property. So almost a third of the property is voluntarily excluded. But that would be to give some credit to North, which, of course, he would not wish to do.
—Not rainforests.

—Yes, including rainforests. Just be patient. Secondly, I gave advice to the minister, which was accepted, that a number of categories should be excluded to ensure that they would not be required within CRA. They included areas that contained, within an area with a national wilderness index, a rating of greater than or equal to 12 and also which classified as tall rainforests within the Woolnorth IBRA region on acid indigenous rock below 600 metres elevation. So pristine rainforest was actually excluded on my advice, beyond that it had already been voluntarily withdrawn by North.

SPEECH.PARA: Lastly, he would be aware—if he had been open and frank with us—that the assessment of the Forest Practices Board was to find that the Surrey Hills block was degraded. So all care was taken in relation to rainforest. The other side of the equation was that we believe 112 jobs were secured and an extra 70 jobs would be created by the decision. That is good for all Australians, particularly Tasmanians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to a question without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to the accession of Senator Colston to the Deputy Presidency.

Today we have been treated, yet again, to a very ugly spectacle of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) and the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) ducking and weaving, covering up and doing everything possible to try to extricate themselves from the tangled web that they have woven with Senator Colston.

It all must have seemed so simple for the government just a few months into their term. They were approached, either directly or indirectly, by Senator Colston—a disgruntled senator who was ready to turn his back on the party of which he had been a member for a long time, the party that he had been elected to represent—in order for that senator to gain the trappings of office. Of course, Senator Hill, Senator Alston and Mr Howard just could not believe their luck. They knew how important it was going to be to get that one vote in the Senate—that one vote that gave them control, an assurance about a raft of legislation that would go through the chamber.

I do not doubt for one minute that they knew that in supporting Senator Colston there would be a small amount of collateral damage for the government, but, of course, they were absolutely dazzled by the prospect of getting Senator Colston's vote. We all know how they secured that vote. The record shows how the Liberals secured Senator Colston's vote. Since Senator Colston's defection he has voted with the Liberals on every major piece of legislation, every major issue before this chamber on which his vote was crucial.

In this chamber we have seen the spectacle of Senator Alston going across the chamber, dragging Senator Colston from where he was sitting with the opposition and leading him across the chamber like a trained dog. We have seen Senator Campbell whispering in Senator Colston's ear during a division to ensure that he came across. We have seen Senator Newman, Senator Hill and Senator Alston haranguing Senator Colston to change his vote during divisions on the social security legislation at the end of the sittings last year.

What has Senator Colston done? He has always meekly complied with the government. What we did not know and what we still demand to know is what arrangements the government came to with Senator Colston, what the details were of this sleazy, slimy, underhand deal that Mr Howard and his government did with Senator Colston, and what the arrangements were that enabled the Liberal Party and the Howard government to secure the vote of Senator Colston. It was not just the deputy presidency—or was it? Was it the staff upgrade? Was it the government protection, support and defence in every adversity that came Senator Colston's way? Was it perhaps the promise of some sinecure at the end of Senator Colston's parliamentary career? These are the issues that the government has steadfastly refused to clarify. We are going to pursue them just as steadfastly.

Even today we have had the spectacle of Senator Alston unwilling to outline the nature of discussions that he had that involved Senator Colston and his staffer Mrs Smith. We would be very interested to hear more detail about that. We want to know whether and the extent to which Mr Howard and his henchmen in the chamber Senator Alston and Senator Hill are implicated in this ham‐fisted and dishonest attempt that Senator Colston made to exonerate himself from blame over his incorrect travel allowance claims. There are many issues to be answered. Senator Hill, Senator Alston, Mr Howard and his government have to front up to the fact that this is a sleazy deal and the public are entitled to know. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume that the Senator Colston that Senator Faulkner is referring to is the same Senator Colston as was elected by the Labor Party to fill the office of Deputy President in 1990, that same Senator Colston whom they knew in 1983 had acted in a manner—
—Who knew?

—Are you suggesting you knew nothing about it? Come on, Senator Ray. You cannot tell me that you knew absolutely nothing about it when it is a matter that happened in 1983 and a matter that this same Senator Colston, who, when we talked today about observing a convention—and you broke the convention—
—The Democrats broke the convention. We always contested ballots then.

—You may have always contested ballots, but you want a convention in place now so that someone is elected in the same way as you, Madam Deputy President, have been elected today. This is the same Senator Colston about whom your own Senator Gareth Evans said in 1983 when he wrote to your current leader, Mr Beazley:

SPEECH.PARA: My view is before entering on a police investigation which might have quite profoundly disturbing implications for Senator Colston's apparently delicately balanced family situation, quite apart from causing grave damage, whether unfairly or not, to his reputation in the event that the fact that the investigation became public knowledge, Senator Colston should be asked to provide a full and detailed explanation of the circumstances of his claims and be given time to pursue any documentation required. In all the circumstances, and given in particular that any such possible irregularities are routinely handled in private commercial organisations and other institutional settings, I believe it would be premature to set in train a police investigation.

They were the words of your own Senator Gareth Evans in 1983 when referring to a request to have the matter relating to irregularities by Senator Colston referred to the Australian Federal Police. That is how you handled the situation in 1983—a situation which you now tell us had already occurred in 1982. That is the sort of extent that you would go to to protect a colleague, who at that stage was a member of your government, in order that nothing became public. I think that you are the ones that ought to be embarrassed when you consider that that was the response of Senator Evans to a request to refer the matter to the Federal Police.

The fact is that Mr Beazley had been advised at the time to call in the police. He did not do so because of the efforts of Senator Evans to try to cover up what allegedly took place in 1983. Both Mr Beazley, your current leader, and Senator Evans have been trying to explain away their roles in the Colston affair since that investigation of 14 years was selectively leaked. Mr Beazley said at the time:

What I ordered at the time was the sort of thorough investigation by my department which had not been done when the matter came to me. At the end of the process it was decided, as was the sort of thing you did at the time, that he should be forced to pay back the money. Now I am not completely familiar with that because that happened after I left the position.

Mr Beazley restated that only on 9 April. Let us not think that you are blameless in this regard when you consider that this is a person whom these things were said about in 1983 and when you consider the advice that was given by Senator Evans in 1983 and then you had the gall to appoint this person as Deputy President in 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. In commencing my remarks I congratulate you on your election. My point of order is that Senator Ferguson, when referring to former Senator Evans, should make it clear that he is referring to Mr Evans, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives, and not to my good self. I do not mind getting hanged for my own crimes but I do object to being hanged for other people's alleged crimes.
—I am sure that Senator Ferguson will make this clear.
—It is a very good point. Let me say that I did refer to Senator Gareth Evans earlier. As I kept saying `former Senator Evans', it can be assumed that I was still referring to Gareth Evans.
—He admits it is a crime.

—Senator Evans, certainly no reference was meant to you as I have worked quite closely with you on committees and I know that this sort of thing would not happen to you. What I do want to say is that you who claim purity in this whole incident of all of the things that you have done need to remember that back in 1990 you were prepared to nominate and elect a person to the Deputy President's position who you knew as far back as 1983 had been required to pay back travelling allowance discrepancies and that it had been recommended that the matter be referred to the Australian Federal Police on the pleading of then Senator Gareth Evans but this matter was dealt with internally and never made public. (Time expired)

—Madam Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. My point of order goes to a document standing apparently in the name of former Senator Gareth Evans quoted by Senator Ferguson. I ask that Senator Ferguson table the document from which he was reading or quoting.
—On the point of order, Madam Deputy President: as you well know because you understand the orders, and as Senator Faulkner should know, that is not a point of order and it was frivolously raised.
—What I have here is a series of notes with a series of quotes about a whole range of things. It is not a document that is purported to be from former Senator Gareth Evans.
—They are private notes.

—Madam Deputy President, let me respond to some things that Senator Ferguson said. The first offences committed by Senator Colston were under a Fraser government. The money was repaid under a Fraser government, under a Liberal minister Mr Newman. He claims that he wanted to refer it to the Federal Police, but none of those documents have been released to the opposition. We have no idea as to the veracity of his claims. Secondly, Senator Ferguson said that people on this side of the chamber knew of entitlement errors made by Senator Colston in 1983. I categorically deny it. I was never told. Mr Beazley or no‐one else passed that information to me.

BREAK.PARA: Let me also say that I held the portfolio of home affairs which covered ministerial and parliamentary services for about 15 months from July 1987 to October 1988. A whole range of information came across my desk about members of parliament—not involving criminality, I rush to add, but about breaches of entitlement and things that would embarrass them; things that affect Liberal ministers today. I have never once passed that information on to any of my party colleagues. It has remained confidential to me and will remain confidential to me for as long as I live. If a minister learns of things bordering on impropriety, it is not necessarily the process that they would in fact disclose them to their colleagues or anyone else if proper administrative solutions were available.

Let me also say this: the fact is that what we have sought is what arrangements were made when Senator Colston was elected as Deputy President. The government I think has said on occasions, through the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and Senator Hill, that there were no inducements; there was no deal. When they were asked on the lesser matters whether there was an understanding or there were arrangements, we got no response.

Senator Hill had the cheek here to say that he had answered those questions last year. But the fact is that they were non-answers. Given the high moral ground that this government wants to take, where is the transparency? They are not willing to say what arrangements there were—the dates, the times and the length of all those discussions. There are people here in this chamber who were there at the initial discussions, even here now, but they will not disclose it.

We have the Prime Minister proclaiming that he has adopted the high moral ground. Let us examine that claim right here. Why was Senator Colston dumped as Deputy President? Because the Liberal Party had to get out from under. Those opposite having defended in this chamber the statements put down in this chamber and then having had the rug pulled from under them, John Howard called a hasty press conference on 8 April and referred the matter to the Federal Police, even though we know he did not have the power to do that, even if it is on the record that he did not even consult with his Attorney-General—the panic was so strong. They just had to cut and run. So, after weeks and weeks of resisting calls from the opposition and editorials that these matters should go directly to the Federal Police, John Howard panics under public pressure.

But he did not say that night, `I find his vote tainted.' No, he waits until two opinion polls come out that decisively show that government support is eroding. So they had a cabinet meeting, had a discussion and think, `What can we do about this? We will come up with this new scam. We will say that his vote is tainted and we don't want it any more.' Having bought the vote themselves, it was no longer acceptable. Then we had the cheek of the Prime Minister this morning saying on AM, `Senator Colston is entitled to be regarded as innocent until proven guilty.' We agree with that. But then he said that Senator Colston is entitled to his day in court. For heaven's sake, the police investigation is not even over. The DPP has not even been consulted and the Prime Minister has Senator Colston in court.

If he is so innocent, why dump him as Deputy President? Why say his vote is tainted if he is innocent? It is that side that has absolutely convicted him in public in recent weeks, yet they are still professing the old chestnut of his innocence until proven guilty. The fact is that they bought Senator Colston's vote—by what means we do not know. But the truth comes out after a while. Senator Alston in his great defence of Senator Colston did not mention that he had met with Mrs Christine Smith; did not mention to us in the chamber that he had had discussions. He again was coy.

The last point is that Senator Hill refuses to say what conversations he had with Senator Colston other than implicitly acknowledging that he had them. So much for transparency! So much for the high moral ground! So much for the Liberal Party! Senator Ferguson said that we voted for Senator Colston in 1990. We always ran candidates then. It was the Democrats who put him up, not us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let this debate of righteous indignation go without some comment about the way in which people on the other side have absolutely forgotten history. I want to mention some of the people who have been in this parliament who knew of the circumstances in which they now say Senator Colston had to repay money back in 1983, and they said absolutely nothing. They did nothing; they did not institute any inquiry; they did not send it off to the police.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Foreman and Senator Childs came here in 1981—two years before that repayment. Senator Ray came here in 1981; he has been a cabinet minister. Senator Bolkus, a former cabinet minister, came here in 1981. Senator Reynolds, a former minister, came here in 1981. Senator Cook, a former cabinet minister, came here in 1982. Senator Crowley, a former minister, came here in 1982. Senator McKiernan, a former whip, came here in 1985. Senator Collins, a former minister, came here in 1987. Senator Schacht, a former minister, came here in 1987. Senator Faulkner, a former cabinet minister, came here in 1989. Senator Sherry, a former parliamentary secretary, came here in 1990.

All of those people have been office‐bearers; they have been members of the executive of a Labor government and saw fit to do nothing at all about a person who they now claim to be a crook. Did any of those people—or anyone else in the opposition, for that matter—tell Senator Hill or Senator Alston what they now claim had to be repaid in 1983? Not one person on the then opposition benches knew what they had covered up. They covered that up all the way through, so much so that they supported him. All of those people who I have talked about supported that same man for the position of Deputy President in 1990.

Is it therefore unreasonable to suspect that these people on the other side, who are now so righteous in everything they say, actually helped to camouflage what they now call a crime? They do not want to let Senator Colston have his judgment made outside; they want to convict him right here and now. Yet they did not see fit to do anything about it for seven years prior to supporting him for the deputy presidency and for a further 13 years prior to their leaving office.

Simply because they are in opposition, because they ceased being the focus of attention, and because the Democrats ceased to be the focus of attention, they are now crying foul. I think it is absolutely and utterly appalling that we can have a whole range of former ministers, cabinet ministers, whips and parliamentary secretaries who were all in the know and one would have to presume—

TALK.START.PARA: —No!

—If you weren't in the know, why weren't you in the know? If you weren't in the know, Senator Crowley, how would you expect us to be in the know? Therefore, that highlights the absolute lunacy of the attack on Senator Hill and Senator Alston.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Crowley, a former minister until the wretched Labor government was thrown out last year, claims that she did not know, how on earth do they claim that Senator Hill and Senator Alston knew of any possible indiscretion by any senator on any side? It is the Labor Party who were in charge of the books from 1983 until last year.

Therefore, the fact is they cannot sheet home any blame to Senator Hill or Senator Alston. They covered it up. They covered up heaven only knows what, because I know there are other people in this place who are wandering around Australia at the moment with various people with whom they probably should not be. Why are they covering that up? That will probably be exposed in time, too. Why don't they look at that? But no, they are just focusing on one man. Let the man have his investigation. Let the proper channels be gone through, step by step. They saw fit to do nothing about it for 13 years. Why do they see fit to do something now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, can I take this opportunity to congratulate you on your election to the office of Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to support Senator Faulkner's motion to take note of an answer. I draw the Senate's attention to the statement signed by Christine Smith which in fact repudiates the statement that she had made earlier. In her second statement, she says:
On 24th March 1997, on arrival at the office
that is, the office in Parliament House—

I received a telephone call from Senator Colston. He said in a particular drawer in his office were three letters which had been signed by him and a statement for me to sign. I understand these letters were typed by another staff member during the weekend. The statement for me to sign was based on the first draft which Senator Colston had drafted at my uncle's home on 2nd March 1997.

We have heard today from Senator Alston that he has discussed, at one level, matters of no substance with Mrs Christine Smith; and, at another level, within the office of Senator Colston, the defence that he put up on 25 March which we now know to be a total fabrication. We said at the time, on 25 March, that it was a total fabrication. It was quite clear from the statements made by Senator Colston prior to the release of that statement that there was going to be, as he put it, `a believable statement'. But to us, and to most people in this country, a totally unbelievable statement was put before this Senate.

The real issue here is: to what extent did the government get involved in the preparation of that statement? To what extent was there foreknowledge of the false nature of that statement? Quite clearly, Senator Alston is going around the coalition benches saying to all and sundry that he was instrumental in procuring Senator Colston's vote in the lead‐ up to the last federal budget and the Senate's vote on the Telstra sale bill. It is quite apparent that senior members of the government in this chamber took it upon themselves to secure Senator Colston's vote in the lead‐up to last year's budget and the Telstra bill.

That is what is really at the heart of this matter. It goes to the very issue of the integrity of the legislative process in this country: the manner in which arrangements were made to secure the defection of Senator Colston to ensure the government had a majority in this chamber to secure its budget processes and, of course, the sale of Telstra. There can be no more fundamental national issue when it goes to the integrity of the legislative process within this country. There can be no more basic question in terms of the integrity of the political system in this country than the whole issue of vote buying in this chamber. It raises very basic issues that can only ultimately be resolved when the whole privileges issue is taken through and when we get to the very bottom of the question of the way in which documents pertaining to make false statements to this chamber were presented to this chamber, alleging that certain arrangements had been made in Senator Colston's office which, in fact, had not been made.

The question really arises: to what extent is this government implicated in the fabrication of those lies? To what extent are senior members of this government implicated in the whole travesty of justice that led to the defection of Senator Colston from the Labor Party to effectively join the coalition in this chamber, to deprive the people of Queensland of their true vote and to undermine the democratic process in this country? To what extent has this government been involved in various meetings with Senator Colston and his staff to fabricate the documents that were placed before the Senate? These are matters that this government will not be able to run away from. Vote buying is a very serious business. It undermines the very basic premise of the democratic system in this country and you are guilty of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Campbell, on a point of order.

—Madam Deputy President, congratulations on your election to that post. I draw your attention to standing order 193(3). Senator Carr has quite clearly, on two or three occasions in this debate, contravened that standing order, creating an imputation of improper motives and making personal reflections. He has further made a reflection on votes of this chamber. He was reminded of that standing order two or three times in the last session, prior to Easter, and was required to withdraw. He shows contempt for the Senate and for previous rulings by continuing to do so today.
—Senator Carr, if you are reflecting in such a way, would you care to withdraw those reflections and tailor your remarks within the standing orders?
—I am not casting reflections upon the chamber itself. I am casting reflections upon the political system in which the buying of votes is allowed to proceed.

—Further to that point of order, he is now canvassing your ruling, Madam Deputy President. You did ask him to withdraw imputations of improper motives and reflections on votes of this chamber and he has refused to do so.
—Senator Carr, some have taken exception and feel that you are imputing motives.

—In deference to your ruling, Madam Deputy President, I of course withdraw any imputations of improper motive. But, as I continue my remarks in this matter, I draw to your attention that we do have a most basic question about the legislative integrity of a political system in this country which allows certain members of this government to engage in private meetings with senators. I put to this chamber the very real possibility that there have been inducements offered to ensure the passage of certain legislation. That really is at the heart of this question; that is, the nature of the vote buying exercise that has been undertaken in this place.

—Madam Deputy President, he is now wilfully ignoring your quite clear ruling on this matter and is showing total contempt for the Senate. If he has that contempt for the Senate he should perhaps resign from the Senate and find somewhere else to pour his verbal diarrhoea; this is not the place to do it.
—You might like to start by withdrawing `verbal diarrhoea'.
—I am happy to do so if that is unparliamentary, Madam Deputy President. I respect your ruling in that regard.
—How many times did you do that with the Democrats?

—Order! Senator Ferguson, this is not helping. Senator Carr, would you care to be careful how you raise these issues. It is a difficult technical point, I understand, for you to remain within the standing orders but I would ask you to remain conscious of the need to do that.

—I certainly will, at all times, seek to remain within the standing orders. The question that arises in this Senate is that Senator Alston has made the point today that he has engaged in discussions regarding the defence that Senator Colston put to this chamber, which we now know to be false. He has made that admission today. He has said, at one level—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I also join in offering you my good wishes on your election and I congratulate you on achieving this goal. I also note your selection of a Liberal blue jacket for the occasion and I trust that your rulings will be similarly inclined.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate seems to have been—if I heard the last speaker correctly—about the integrity of the system. It is pretty clear that, in 1990, the then Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, knew of the alleged `malfunctions' of a particular senator. I want to make it clear that I am one of those who believes in the rule of the law and I do not, in any way, presume that Senator Colston or any other senator is guilty of anything unless that is eventually proven—unlike the Labor Party, who seem to take it upon themselves to be judge and jury. I do not want to do that and I am sure no‐one in my party does.

If what the Labor Party is now saying about integrity is correct, how is it that Senator Gareth Evans, who was well aware of those suggested defaults—he was actually involved in them as the Attorney‐General at the time—together with his party, nominated Senator Colston for the position of Deputy President? I do not say that Senator Colston has done anything wrong but if, as the Labor Party say, he has done something wrong then why did they nominate him? Why did you, Madam Deputy President, and all of your colleagues support him when the Attorney‐General had full knowledge of what was alleged to have happened at those times? You talk about integrity here: I think the previous three speakers from the other side show an absolute lack of any credibility in this matter. Senator Carr seems to—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief personal explanation.
—Does the honourable senator claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.
—Madam Deputy President, let me, too, congratulate you for being elected to your office.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) said that I had misled the Senate in the form of the questions I asked him in question time. In fact, I did nothing of the sort. He failed to address in his accusations against me the fact that I had pointed out that a report upon which he based a decision had made it clear that pure rainforest would be logged, and he knew that it would be logged if he gave the go ahead for a licence—which he did—without seeking an environmental impact statement.
North Broken Hill applied for 6,800 hectares of pure rainforest to be logged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I take a point of order, Madam Deputy President? Senator Brown cannot claim to have been misrepresented. He is now starting to debate the issue and to present an argument. I think he should stick to where he claims he was misrepresented and not debate the issue.

—On the point of order, some brief response to what the minister said is vital here to get to the point. It will be very brief, I assure you. I am simply making clear the basis upon which my question was put to him.

—If you wish to make a very brief explanation outlining what the minister has said, then that is appropriate, but make sure that you are pointing out where you have been misrepresented. That is the role that is expected of you.

—I thank you. The application was for 6,800 hectares of pure rainforest to be destroyed. The go ahead was for 3,000 hectares, and the report to the minister said that two areas of 1,000 hectares were pure calindendrous cathedral‐like rainforest. I did not mislead the Senate. In fact, the report on which the minister based his claims does not mention in its conclusions that these forests are degraded. It uses other adjectives, but it does not use that term. He was quite remiss in saying to the Senate that these forests are degraded when, in fact, they are floristically intact. There has been some very dispersed removal of logs in the past, but in fact it is calindendrous, intact, wild rainforest which he has licensed for destruction.
—I raise a point of order on the curtailment of the motion to take note. There were only six speakers. I was the sixth of them, and I think I only had a couple of minutes.
—You took points of order on me.
—But they do not count.
—I think there has been some slippage in stopping the clock for points of order. There were only six speakers.
—Madam Deputy President, perhaps, to save embarrassment, could I seek leave to speak for no longer than three minutes on the topic that I was speaking on at the time the curtailment was—
—Is leave granted?
—If you want to speak, you can speak.
—Leave is granted, if there is no objection.
—No, I agree with the management of government business.
—You said leave was granted, Madam Deputy President. Do you take instructions from someone lounging in his chair telling you what to do?
—Senator Macdonald, let us be a little bit cautious here.
—Just keep yourself under control, pal.
—Order! Senator Cook. The question I asked was whether leave was granted. I heard nothing other than Senator Campbell saying, `No'.
—I did not say, `No'; I said, `If you want to speak, you can speak'.
—I will now put it again: is leave granted?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FAULKNER

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that case, Madam Deputy President—and I did not want to do this—I take a point of order in that there is obviously a malfunction in the timing of the Senate. Every senator here—or those who have sat through the debate—will know that there were six speakers. I was the sixth. There must have been some mistake in the timing and, in that event, I seek—
—So you think what you have to say is more important than legislation?
—No, I do not think it is more important. But we want to observe some procedural rules here which obviously your lot are not at all interested in.
—Order! Senator Macdonald, I assure you I will have the times the clock was stopped and was not stopped checked to ensure that there is no further malfunction, if that has occurred.

—That really is not the point. I was in the throes of a very important speech refuting some of the lies and rubbish that come from the Labor Party. It is quite clear that there were six speakers who had five minutes, but I was cut off at two minutes. I demand my right to complete my speech.
—Senator Macdonald, leave was not granted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: MACDONALD

TALK.START.PARA: —I did seek leave to try to avoid this embarrassing situation, but now I simply want to continue speaking in accordance with the time of this Senate and according to the standing orders of this Senate. With your concurrence, Madam Deputy President, I will continue my three minutes.

INTERJECT.PARA: As I was saying, it is pretty obvious that the Labor Party does not want the truth to be known and they will take any procedural step to gag the truth coming out in this particular debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald, I have put the motion that notice be taken of the answer, and that was carried.
—I beg your pardon. You have not, Madam President.
—I am sorry, but I have.
—Well, you should not have, Madam Deputy President.
—I am sorry, but I have done so. After you sat down, I put the motion that the answer be noted and it was carried.

—I cannot recall that—there are not too many on our side. Madam Deputy President, you are in charge of this chamber. How do you account for the fact that there are six speakers at five minutes each and one speaker, who happens to be on this side of the chamber, gets two minutes? How do you account for that?

—Senator Macdonald, would you resume your seat? As I pointed out earlier, there was some slippage of time in setting the clock when points of order were taken. It was rather difficult, on occasions, for people to understand that a point of order was actually being taken. So I am sorry, but I have given my ruling.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FERGUSON

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Deputy President: standing orders are quite clear that there is half an hour allocated for taking note of answers.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Margetts interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order, Senator Margetts.
—Senator Margetts, I am not talking about six people.
—Senator Ferguson, would you direct your comments to the chair.

—Madam Deputy President, standing orders allocate one half‐hour period for taking note of answers and points of order are not to be included in that time. If nobody speaks for more than five minutes, which they cannot—and each of the speakers, on this occasion spoke for five minutes—it stands to reason that, in order to comply with standing orders, the sixth person speaking should be allocated a full five minutes. If there is slippage on the clock, Madam Deputy President, because it was not stopped for taking note of answers, you do not have to be very brilliant at arithmetic to know, if points of order are not to be taken into account and you are only into your sixth speaker and no‐one has spoken for more than five minutes, that Senator Ian Macdonald is entitled to a further three minutes.

—On the point of order, Madam Deputy President: I think that the arithmetic of Senator Ferguson make sense, there is no doubt about that. Let me suggest to you, Madam Deputy President, that this is not an unusual circumstance. During question time today, for example, in answer to a supplementary question from a minister, the clock was set at four minutes. I dealt with that in a very different way from Senator Ian Macdonald.
—You sought leave, as I did.
—Order, Senator Macdonald!

—I dealt with this in a different way. I indicated, sotto voce, to those responsible that this was the situation. This is not uncommon in this place. It does happen from time to time. There are so many occasions when the clerks set the clock for time limits on contributions that are being made, but every now and again there is a foul up.
—Why did you refuse leave?

—I am just taking a point of order. I am happy to seek leave and make a statement, if you would prefer, on this matter. I actually do not want to see the time of the Senate wasted on this issue. I do not think that three minutes of nonsense from Senator Ian Macdonald is worth any of our time.
—We had five minutes' nonsense from you.
—I do not think this debate is going to be very edifying.
—I am sure that Senator Faulkner is getting close to the end of his—

—Exactly—very edifying to those who might be listening. I think, Madam Deputy President, as you have put the question that the Senate take note of answers to questions, that has been dealt with, the time limit has run out and it is competent for a senator to seek leave. It is then competent for leave to be agreed or denied by the Senate. In this circumstance, I do not think it is competent for a senator—Senator Ian Macdonald, in this case—just to stand and take the floor. It is a matter for the clerk to call the next business before the chamber. That is what I believe ought to happen. Equally, if the Manager of Government Business in the Senate can think of a way through this which ceases this extraordinary embarrassment that Senator Ian Macdonald is to his colleagues and to the Senate, I am sure that you will find that the opposition and other senators will try to assist you and the good standing of the chamber.

—Madam Deputy President, the way through this is for the chamber to allow Senator Ian Macdonald to speak for three minutes. The fact is that the motion had been put and had been passed, but there is no reason why the Senate could not show some flexibility in this to allow Senator Ian Macdonald to say what he needs to say. That should only take three minutes and not the 10 minutes we have just spent debating whether or not he can speak. Therefore, I seek leave for the time required for Senator Ian Macdonald to conclude his three‐minute speech on the matters raised during question time by various questions from the opposition.

—I am still speaking to the point of order, Madam Deputy President. In answering the point of order and some of the things that Senator Faulkner raised, the lack of edification in this debate—of course, it is the debate that he initiated and I agree with him on that—
—What is your point of order, Senator Macdonald?

—I am raising the same sort of point of order as Senator Faulkner, and you allowed him to do so. I simply want to say that, regrettably, Senator Faulkner was not in the chamber—as he rarely is. You might understand, Madam Deputy President, that I recognised there had been an embarrassment with the timing and I had sought an easy way through that which would not have wasted time and would have saved embarrassment to those concerned. I sought leave and that was quite unfairly, and contrary to the procedures and procedural fairness that the Labor Party is now recognised for, refused by your leader in this chamber. So, Madam Deputy President, I think you should uphold Senator Ferguson's point of order and allow the matter to proceed as Senator Ferguson has suggested.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald, my leader is not on either side when I am in this position as Deputy President. I am about to put the request by Senator Campbell, as Manager of Government Business in the Senate, that leave be granted to allow you to speak for three minutes. Is leave granted?

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply cannot understand Senator Faulkner. When that request was put previously, he simply refused it to waste the time of this chamber, as the opposition have done consistently since the last election. They do not understand the will of the people and they are determined to make sure that the will of the people is not heard.

SPEECH.PARA: I was just making the quite obvious point, I might say, that Senator Carr is suggesting that meeting with other senators is somehow a breach of procedures and fairness and that there is something terrible about it. You will recall that the Labor government did nothing but meet with the Democrats and the Greens in the previous parliament—little groups around the parliament talking about how they could ensure Democrat and Green support for various parts of their legislation. They had by far the smaller number of senators in the parliament but they used to do that all the time. Now they are suggesting that there is something wrong with Senator Alston or Senator Hill talking to other senators about matters before the chamber.

The other brief point I wanted to make in relation to this matter is that it seems that Senator Carr and others are taking the word of Ms Christine Smith as being absolute gospel. I do not know Christine Smith at all. I have never met her and I do not know who she is. But it seems that she has given two versions of an event. The Labor Party are choosing one version and not the other. It seems to me quite incredible that they should base their debate on this issue on the veracity of a statement made by Ms Smith—which statement, I am not quite sure. And one would have to question why one statement is preferred over the other.
I finish with Senator Chris Evans's words when he acknowledged—

TALK.START.PARA: —Careful you get this right.

—You acknowledged that Senator Gareth Evans had committed the crime and you did not want to be shown to have been the person who committed the crime. I think that really sums it up. The Labor Party knows, their Whip knows, that Senator Gareth Evans did `commit the crime' all of those years back, and yet the Labor Party have the hypocrisy to start this debate today.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate the devastation wrought on East Timorese society since the Indonesian Invasion of 1975.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all further United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. enter into dialogue with East Timorese political parties and groups dedicated to securing national independence;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. halt forthwith all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telstra: Privatisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes attempts by any Australian government to privatise Telstra as well as any other Australian public assets.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate opposes any intentions by an Australian government to sell off national assets through privatisation.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are opposed to any moves to cut funding to universities.
We believe that funding cuts to universities can only have a negative impact on society and will impede the development of our Nation.
Furthermore, we are opposed to any increases to the annual amount payable by students via the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS).
We believe that an increase to HECS will discourage individuals from enrolling in universities.
We believe that university entry should be based upon relative merit, not relative wealth.
We believe that education has a direct social and economic benefit and appropriate levels of funding should be made available from public revenue.
Your petitioners therefore humbly ask that you will not cut funding to universities or increase HECS.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Brown, Sen Bob; Brownhill, Sen David
PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

PETITION.PARA: Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production; irradiated foods (here and internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt‐reduced; free‐range; vitamin‐enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Brown(from 20 citizens)and Senator Brownhill(from 210 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

PETITION.TITLE: Port Hinchinbrook Development Project
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned humbly request that the Senate honours the obligations of the Commonwealth of Australia to protect its territory that has received World Heritage status according to the World Heritage Convention of which Australia is a signatory.

Significant areas of marine and mangrove ecosystems of Australia's World Heritage Great Barrier Reef Marine Park are directly threatened with destruction by the adjacent construction of Australia's largest tourist resort and marina complex at Oyster Point near Cardwell North Queensland (opposite Hinchinbrook Island).

We implore the Senate to use its powers immediately to permanently halt the construction of the marina and access channel in the World Heritage "Buffer Zone" as recommended by the Valentine Report made to his Department in October 1994.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Evans, Sen Chris; Faulkner, Sen John; Kemp, Sen Rod; MacGibbon, Sen David; O'Chee, Sen Bill
PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Chris Evans(from 49 citizens), Senator Faulkner(from 116 citizens), Senator Kemp(from six citizens), Senator MacGibbon(from five citizens)and Senator O'Chee(from 18 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that only one group have been excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) where such group has performed honourable overseas `active service'. That group being members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 which were excluded under `Operational Service' at Section 6. (1)(e)(ii) of the Act.

The various claims made in Statements to the House and the Senate and the contents of correspondence from various Ministers to maintain the exclusion are answered as follows, the answers are from documents obtained under FIO and from public record:

(i) `They were never allotted for operational service', (contained in a letter from the Hon. Con Sciacca Minister for Defence Science and Personnel 1995). A letter from the Secretary Department of the Navy to Treasury dated 11 November 1955 stated `the date that the Navy were allotted for operational service was 1 July 1955'.

(ii) `Members of the RAN were only doing the duty for which they had enlisted', (October 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). This applies to all Service personnel everywhere.

(iii) `They were in no danger', (November 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). They shared the same danger as all other Australian Service personnel serving in Malaya at the time.

(iv) `They were not on Special Overseas Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel to Mrs Williams of Adelaide dated October 1996). Requirement for Special Overseas Service was introduced in 1962 without retrospective conditions, therefore has no relevance to events of 1960.

(v) `They were not on Active Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel dated October 1996). It is now, as it was then, that Service Personnel had to comply with one of three requirements for Active Service, this group complied with two, or twice as many as is needed. The one that they did not comply with was, `is in military occupation of a foreign country'.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate should remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act, thereby giving the Australian sailors involved comparative recognition with the Army and RAAF personnel that served at the same time, and all other Australians who have served their Country on active service overseas.

PETITION.TITLE: Sexual Discrimination Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament, assembled.

The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows that the Sexual Discrimination Bill 1995 will promote homosexuals and attack the institution of marriage. Therefore your petitioners pray that the Senate disallow this Bill.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Euthanasia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that euthanasia is the actual intervention by another to end a human life. It is neither curing nor a therapy. It destroys a human life.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to:
(a) recognise that euthanasia is not an issue which can be dealt with adequately by the States or Territories;
(b) listen to the public, doctors, health carers and religious organisations who are against euthanasia;
(c) legislate to prevent euthanasia being carried out in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
To uphold, defend and protect Australia's historic Australian National Flag:‐

We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia, hereby attest and assert that Australia must preserve, protect and uphold our Australian National Flag, symbolic of our Australian Nation since Federation in 1901. We take this patriotic stand because:—
(1) This glorious Flag recognises our Australian history, culture, and rich heritage.

(2) This beautiful Flag entails all that is good in our rights and freedoms, recalling Magna Carta, Habeas Corpus, Common Law and the great Bill of Rights as fundamental to our growth and success, and together they gave rise to the Australian belief of a fair go for all.
(3) This distinctive Flag reflects our inherited Christian ethic and values.

(4) This remarkable Flag enshrines the ultimate sacrifices endured by our Glorious War Dead who honoured God, Queen and Country and upheld our belief in freedom, democracy, limited government and the Australian Way.
(5) This brave Flag is our proud signature to achievement in national and sporting events worldwide regardless of ethnic or cultural background.
(6) This historic Flag marks our welcome of migrating peoples who came to Australia to shelter under our inherited freedoms and share and enjoy our liberal democratic values.

(7) This ubiquitous flag, Australia's own, has represented Australia at the four corners of the world, and now symbolises the achievements of past generations, while inspiring younger Australians to future and loyal achievement.
(8) This Australian National Flag is beyond politics and integral to Australia's national being, and therefore must continue to be the soul of Australia regardless of factions and politics.

Because our National Australian Flag marches in tandem with the proud heart beat of the Australian Nation, was selected for Australians by Australians at our nation's very founding, and since then has displayed the primary thrust of our national spirit, and our Australian Flag at all times commands and is deserving of all due honour and respect, we loyal Australians, therefore, petition that our Australian National Flag be always upheld, respected, saluted and honoured, and never denigrated, dishonoured or replaced, and that due process be strengthened immediately to protect our Australian National Flag from dishonour or public offence.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray, God Save the Queen:

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
To uphold, defend, protect and retain forever Australia's historic Constitutional Monarchy:‐

We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia strongly support Australia's Constitutional Monarchy as successful, positive historic and enduring and reject totally any thought of a republic and its insidious companion, creeping republicanism, as divisive, devious, extremist, and without merit.

The Constitutional Monarchy has served Australia well, overviewed our impressive growth and undoubted prosperity, reigned continuously with pomp and circumstance from our first settlement and national foundation, guided our national development in both war and peace, ensured and protected our liberties while delivering peace, order and good government, and rightly denies to evil men those powers which could be used to enslave us.

The Constitutional Monarch is Australia's head of state by tradition, law and right, and, sitting as the Monarch does, at the apex of our Constitution, presides over a Constitution designed for Australians by Australians by some of the wisest constitutional designers to grace our national stage.

We therefore look with trepidation at the antics of a few unwise individuals who would replace proven substance with unproven rhetoric and in doing so threaten the freedoms of all Australians and as loyal Australians hereby petition that the Senate, swearing allegiance to our Queen do live up to that oath by upholding, defending, protecting and retaining forever Australia's historic Constitutional Monarchy.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray: God Save the Queen!

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned expresses concern at the Government's decision to cut funding to the ABC and as a consequence your Petitioners request that the Senate calls on the Government to:
(1) Restore the ABC's funding base to its pre 1996/97 budget level and index future funding to inflation
(2) Retain the current role of the ABC as a comprehensive Public Broadcaster
(3) Retain the current prohibition of sponsorship and advertising on domestic ABC television and radio services; and
(4) Reinstate the expansion of ABC radio services into Regional Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of Senate assembled:

That we are opposed to the unfair and inequitable assessment of AUSTUDY eligibility through the implementation of the new (and recently revised) regulations pertaining to the Actual Means Test and the raising of the age of independence for student income support to 25. We believe that AUSTUDY/ ABSTUDY benefits play a vital role in ensuring a broadly accessible higher education system, which is in turn fundamental to efforts in creating a more just and equitable society.
In particular, the Actual Means Test and raised age of independence have the effect of:

PARA.TAB: forcing students to become reliant on their parents and families for support during their studies despite their family's capacity or willingness to perform this role;
reducing access to higher education for people from disadvantaged backgrounds;
further shifting the cost of higher education from the public realm into the private domain;
further complicating the AUSTUDY application process thereby deterring students from applying and
forcing some students out of study or into dire poverty in order to continue their studies.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate lower the age of independence for AUSTUDY to 18, to entirely revoke the ill‐considered and inequitable Actual Means Test and raise AUSTUDY benefits to a level above the Henderson poverty line.
