DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak to the Beyond Cinderella: Towards a learning society report, which was tabled out of session, as has just been stated. Reports come and go in this place, but some, it seems to me, deserve our particular consideration.

This report is a seven‐year review of the adult and community education document Come in Cinderella, tabled in this place in 1991. That report put adult and community education on the political agenda. Indeed, I do not believe it will ever be removed from the political agenda, so I will not hold my breath on the capacities of this current government. We do not want it removed, and that is the unanimous report of people reviewing adult and community education six years after the first report.

We do note that the benefits of adult and community education continue and are now much better documented. The number of people using adult and community education is better counted. Although we really had no base data before 1991 that was very reliable, we can now say that, compared to 1991 when about 800,000 people used adult and community education, over a million people use it per annum. That is a remarkable marching with the feet, if you like, by the people in this country about what they think of ACE.

The most important thing our report found was that, while ACE is a very good thing and people seriously want it, in the five or seven years that it has been in existence on the political agenda—it has been in existence much longer than that—there has been a skewing of adult and community education towards the vocational education and training end. The report documents that very nicely.

What with the previous government's efforts to deal with unemployment and with the expansion of labour market programs, there was available Commonwealth funding for vocational training and labour market programs. A lot of the adult and community education efforts were then directed towards that end, particularly as they could apply for, and very often were successful in gaining, Commonwealth funding to assist them in the delivery of those programs.

The trouble with that was that it seemed like adult and community education was becoming dominated by, even subsumed a little by, the vocational education and training end, and that the broader, more general education and more community delivered neighbourhood houses program of adult community education was being overlooked. This report says that that balance between adult and community education and the vocational end of adult education has to be put back into proportion. We ask the government to commit to the community or the ACE end and make it be able to stand alongside vocational education and training—not one subsuming the other, not one more important than the other, but both acknowledged as having a critical role to play and a critical appreciation by people in the community.

The other thing that we make a very strong case for is that if government—any government—is taking up the adult and community education cudgel, it appreciates the importance of a commitment to lifelong learning. Our recommendations ask that the Commonwealth government, firstly, makes an unequivocal commitment to the concept of lifelong learning and to the promotion of a learning society; and, secondly, imbues its educational policies and associated funding mechanisms with the values and principles of lifelong learning for all Australians.

There is a sense in which adult and community education is seen as a bit of a mickey, as a bit of a soft cop at the top end of people's lives as they get older. That view completely misses the important contribution of the ACE sector in vocational education and training and the critical contribution it makes to any post‐school education. Adults who undertake this form of education do not have to be 55, 65 and 75 years of age. Adults are often people who, as 15‐year‐olds, dropped out of school and later come back into the schooling system under the adult education umbrella because there they find that somehow it matches their needs better, they are treated as persons, they participate differently and now, suddenly, they are learning. It is about the whole teaching methodology and the teaching approach that, in some ways, I believe is a critical part of education. Indeed, we judge that it will be of great value to all education in this country, not just to what is called adult and community education.

We suggest ways in which the adult and community education and the vocational education and training areas can be put together. We decided in the end that we would recommend that happen rather than try to come up with the perfect acronym. But it certainly seems a most important part of our recommendations and of our report that ACE and VET should stand side by side, not have one dominating or subsuming the other. We also suggest the restructuring of ANTA, the Australian National Training Authority, to include the ACE sector. This report recommends that, without terribly much expenditure or significant increase in outlays, that could be very effectively achieved.

We have also argued the importance of some government funding for infrastructure for the community deliverers of adult education. It is not possible for people in neighbourhood houses or in community colleges to try to participate adequately if they do not have access to some infrastructure assistance, if they do not have a computer on which they may be able to take the data to report on how many people are using their service, to be able to make sure that, with any funding that they are successful with—sometimes they have been able to contribute to the vocational end and have achieved funding for that—they are able to properly document and account for that. They need infrastructure assistance at that level, and we make a recommendation about that.

We also appreciate that the data that we have been able to get shows that in some sectors very large numbers of people participating in adult education are women. They are much more likely to be women who have already had access to education and are adding to that; whereas it is clearly documented now that there are sectors of the community—particularly people from the lower socioeconomic end of town—who do not go to or do not participate in or are not involved in adult and community education. We recommend that that be looked at very seriously and that an equity fund be established to assist some of those people who are grossly under represented to have access to that kind of assistance, particularly in any post school training or in bridging courses before they even get to vocational education and training. Along with this, of course, is needed continuing and adequate research, and we also make recommendations about that.

I will leave it to my colleagues to make more remarks about this report. I strongly recommend that if people want to get the sense of it and do not want to read the full report, they can read this overview or summary of the recommendations and the general outline of what our report found.

One of the things that I think is particularly interesting is the evidence that is emerging that if people have the opportunity to use their minds, to do the intellectual push‐ups each day, to participate in any kind of education—whatever they prefer—this contributes to them staying mentally alert and active. There are some measured suggestions that it may indeed prevent the onset of Alzheimer's or early senility.

Given that so many Australians will be becoming older—by the year 2010 we expect a very significant increase in the aged population in Australia—anything that might assist with the community having people live out their lives participating and contributing and managing for themselves in their own homes is going to be not only something we would like for those people but also something of great economic benefit. This is highlighted in the report and I believe it deserves very serious examination by governments, particularly if you are looking at the long-term costs of people going into nursing homes and aged care.

As I have said, adult and community education should not be seen as being only for people over 75 or over 50. It is about an attitude or an approach to education that I believe should infuse all education. That is what this report recommends.

In conclusion, I particularly thank the staff who have been involved with this report—the Secretary, Brenton Holmes; Mr Alistair Sands; Jan Connaughton; Pam Corrigan; Jan Willis; and, Diane Leak—for their splendid assistance in writing the report, in dealing with the submissions and in organising our public hearings in every capital city and some beyond capital cities. It has been a most fruitful report and I look forward to the government's response to our recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this report of the Employment, Education and Training References Committee, I support the remarks that Senator Crowley has made. I draw to the Senate's attention that on this committee there are substantial political differences and, of course, substantial issues of debate. However, this is one area on which I think all senators who have a genuine interest in education and a commitment to the important role that it plays in the development of our nation are able to agree. This is essentially what this report puts before the Senate—the broad agreement of a range of senators who would normally disagree substantially on very significant matters of public policy.

SPEECH.PARA: It is in that context that I put to this government that there is a basis on which senators are recommending to this government that they take this report seriously and that they do more than just issue pious platitudes—that they actually put some serious money behind this initiative, which is long overdue in terms of real commitment from education authorities around Australia. In saying that, I would like to join with Senator Crowley in thanking the secretariat for the outstanding job that they have done in organising the report and organising the inquiry. The Senate has working for it a very good group of people in this committee.

The Senate committee which reported in 1991 on the adult and community education sector produced the report Come in Cinder ella, which has received critical acclaim throughout the education community. I think that internationally it has been recognised as a significant document about policy in what is often referred to as the fourth sector of the education and training industry. While the report highlighted the connections between the various sectors of this industry, I think in many respects it has not been fully understood within the realm of government. Therefore, our second report draws to the attention of the government practical ways in which it can undertake measures to improve the development of a total learning society in this country.

Next month, Commonwealth and state ministers are coming together in their regular forum. I understand that a paper will be presented to that conference by the Victorian employment and education minister, Dr Honeywood. This will provide an opportunity, a vehicle, for this government to take up these issues. I trust that the ministerial council will be able to look at this report and use it as the basis for its discussions, in addition to those matters that Dr Honeywood is going to put before the ministerial council.

I trust that Dr Honeywood will have studied this report. I am sure that the officers in Victoria will be able to draw upon the advice and evidence put before the Senate committee to bring forward constructive contribution in this area.

In regard to Victoria and Victorian education, it is very rare for me to be able to say very much that is in fact positive. But in regard to adult and community education in Victoria, I think there is substantial work going on, which is very much a continuation of the programs that were initiated under the previous government in that state. It is one area which has managed to avoid the decimation faced by education in that state.

The adult and community education sector in Victoria, while lacking serious funding—essentially because it is not able to effectively tap into ANTA funding—has maintained nonetheless a philosophy and a program which I believe makes it a leader within this country in the provision of adult and community education.

BREAK.PARA: There is, of course, still very much work to be done in that area. In particular, I think adequate recognition has to be secured for the full range of education and training services provided through the adult and community education sector. There are many policies and structural changes which have made a big impact on the provision of those education services to the people of this country. In particular, the establishment of the national vocational education and training system, which has been funded through ANTA, has provided a vehicle for additional funding to the various providers of adult and community education.

The real issue here is that there has been an extension of adult and community education as a result of additional moneys that have been made available by the Commonwealth. The real problem is that, while a more diverse group of people has been able to be introduced to education after they have left school—often they are persons who have missed out on really rewarding experiences through the education system—the provision of adult and community education, as if it was a labour market program alone, is not sufficient to meet the full educational needs of the adult and community education sector.

It is really very unfortunate that the description and definition of VET funding is such that it actually excludes general educational provision, which is of great detriment to the adult and community education sector. Despite the commitments that have been made by the national VET strategy—the so-called commitment to lifelong learning and the acknowledgments that governments have made of the contribution of general adult education to adult and community education—there remains this major deficiency in that there has not been provided to ANTA funding for general educational purposes to adults outside the formal education system as we know it.

What we clearly see on the evidence that has been made available to us is that there are now nearly one million persons who are involved in adult and community education. There is a much broader array of people involved in that sector than there has been at any time in the history of this country. Yet they are not all able to secure access to reasonable sources of funding. Particularly, there is a bias towards particular groups of people in this country. In fact, a great disadvantage is being experienced, particularly by working class men, as a result of the failure of governments to meet the needs of all Australians in this sector.

So, as I see it, there are two real difficulties here. I draw your attention to the difficulties that are faced by the non‐participation of so many people, particularly those most disadvantaged in our society and who have been so disenfranchised in terms of their access to real power, real authority and real wealth in this country. Not only working men but also persons with disabilities and people who are from Aboriginal and Torres Strait backgrounds are particularly disadvantaged in this sector, as they are in every other sector of the education industry.

What we as a parliament need to do, therefore, is to keep pressure on this government to ensure that ACE providers are provided with additional resources and that the ministers and government officials in the education departments across this country are made aware of and recognise the contribution of adult and community education to lifelong learning in our society. At a time when there is growing evidence of people being disorientated and alienated from the social structures of our community, this area of education provides a real opportunity for ordinary people to participate as community members and to improve their skills in a real and effective way, so that they can join in their society in a more effective manner and contribute fully to it. In this way, it is serving not just a narrow vocational purpose but a genuine social purpose as well.

In that regard, the government has an obligation to broaden its descriptions of adult and community education programs and to see that genuine community activists in the education field are able to attract people—particularly those who have had a bad experience in the formal institutional settings of education in this country—to ensure that there is lifelong learning and that it is possible for people to maximise their full potential by being able to enjoy the benefits of learning, mixing with other people and seeking out new information and knowledge about the way in which our society works. This parliament has a responsibility to ensure that ministers from all governments around this country—and all officials in all departments throughout this country—understand that adult and community education is an important part of the education environment. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The report of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee, presented to the President yesterday, deals with the role and future of Radio Australia and Australia Television. I stand here today able to say that, as a result of tremendous public response to the committee's inquiry, together with the public outcry that has taken place right across this nation and in countries around the region, we still have Radio Australia. However, the Radio Australia we are going to have in the future is going to be a far cry from the one we had until the recent decisions of this government.

The majority report, representing the opposition senators and the Democrats, of the Senate committee strongly supports a continuing role for the ABC in international broadcasting and, in particular, strongly supports the retention of Radio Australia and Australia Television. It calls upon the government to rethink its position and its attitude, to drop its ideological obsession with slashing the budget of the ABC and to commit appropriate funds, in accordance with their pre‐election commitments to maintain Radio Australia and Australia Television.

This coalition—and in particular this Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston)—has made an art form out of breaking promises. There are many areas where we see that occurring daily. Amongst the clearest examples are its breaches of promises with respect to the ABC. This is a government that made statements prior to the last election—and, indeed, the minister made a statement on the night of the election—saying that ABC funding would not be cut. Yet what happened after the election? Fifty‐five million dollars was slashed out of the ABC's funding. This is a government that promised it would maintain Radio Australia: it recognised its great importance to the nation's interest.

This is a government that said it would continue the commitment of the previous government to the funding package for Australia Television over the course of the next three years; yet we now have a situation where ATV is to be sold off or, if it is not sold off, it could well be closed down next month, if Mr Mansfield's recommendations were to be adopted. We have a position where Radio Australia has had approximately two‐thirds of its funding removed. The fact that it will still receive funding in the order of $8 million—as compared with the $23‐odd million it relied upon previously—is not due in any part to some recognition by the government that it got it wrong; it is due to the public pressure that has been applied to this government to get it to rethink at least part of its position.

This government and this minister set up the Mansfield review with the clear intention of stripping back and nobbling the ABC. In the words of the minister's own options paper, presented to the budget last year, they foresaw the future of the ABC as a very narrow, domestic broadcasting only operation.

They have this ideological obsession to kill off the ABC. They have not got the courage to bring legislation into this chamber or into the other House which seeks to change the charter of the ABC, which is really what they would like to do. What they have set out on is a course to strangle them of funds. They would then say to the ABC, `You have to decide whether you will put the scarce resources that you will have in the future into domestic broadcasting or into international broadcasting.' It is a classic Pontius Pilate approach—slash the funding and then leave it to someone else to have to make the hard decision.

This government has absolutely no understanding, it would appear, of the importance of international broadcasting. Throughout the entire period that the inquiry has been under way and since the Mansfield review report came down in January this year, which led to the establishment of this Senate inquiry, the minister has made misleading statement after misleading statement. First of all, he said in an interview on 28 February, after this committee of inquiry had been established:

. . . I think Mansfield's made a pretty powerful case. There's been a lot of emotive reaction to it but I haven't seen any sort of in‐depth analysis that demonstrates either the effectiveness of the service or a significant demand for it—
he is talking here about Radio Australia—
There may well be that evidence, but you would have expected it to have been put before Mansfield, and it wasn't, and Radio Australia has obviously had every opportunity to mount their case.

He said that Mr Mansfield had actually looked at this and that Radio Australia had an opportunity to put their views to the Mansfield review. That is completely untrue. Mr Mansfield in his own report said that his terms of reference did not include consideration of the foreign affairs implications of closing down Radio Australia or ATV. In his own report he said that the government needed more information on these issues and that he did not have the terms of reference or indeed the time to consider it.

The minister said that he had not seen any sort of in‐depth analysis. That is true because Mr Mansfield had not done it. The minister claims that Radio Australia had an opportunity to put its case. They did not. Two days prior to the interview with the minister—you wonder what the minister was actually doing and why he had not brought himself up to date—Mr Mansfield said:
If you look at my terms of reference, I only had to look at the ABC. I didn't have the task and wasn't asked to look at Australia's foreign policy.
He went on to say:
I just didn't have the instruction to take into account the foreign affairs implications.
Having put that misleading comment to bed, the minister then changed tack. He claimed that short‐wave radio is really a declining technology and Radio Australia really should be done away with.

As the committee inquiry shows—and my colleague Senator Hogg will come more specifically to much of the evidence and detail put before the committee overwhelmingly in favour of the retention of RA and ATV; only one of over 2,200 submissions really was opposed to RA—major broadcasters like the BBC, Voice of America, Deutsche Welle, Radio France, China Radio, Radio Japan and Voice of Vietnam are increasing their investment in short‐wave technology. What does this minister say? He says, `It's dead. Forget it, it's history.'

The minister has also tried to put the view, as other members of the government have, that Radio Australia and ATV do not serve any purpose. Fortunately, it appears that there are some people on the government side who take a different view. One of those is the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer. We know that Mr Downer wrote a letter to Senator Alston in February pointing out the positive advantages of Radio Australia to our foreign policy interests and the fact that it should continue and that funding should not be cut. It is a pity, however, that Minister Downer did not ensure that his own department made submissions to that effect when they came before the inquiry.

It is a thorough, most extensive report. I urge all members of parliament to read it because it lays out fully the history and the role of Radio Australia and ATV and all of the foreign policy, trade and other reasons as to why it should continue. In conclusion, I especially thank Mr Paul Barsdell, the secretary of the committee, and Ms Loes Baker, who worked extremely hard up to last Friday even though she is expecting a baby next week. She worked right up until last week to finish the report. I also thank the other members of the secretariat for their hard work and long hours on this most valuable report. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —I was the Democrat's representa tive on the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee which prepared this report. I learnt a great deal, which I did not already know, about Radio Australia and ATV while we were taking evidence and looking at all the submissions. I did not look at all of the 2,200 submissions, but I did look at quite a few of them. As Senator Forshaw has said, all but three of those submissions said that Radio Australia and Australia Television should be at least maintained. There was really only one submission out of the more than 2,200 that was against Radio Australia being maintained in its present form.

SPEECH.PARA: What were the arguments given against Radio Australia and ATV? There were really only two. The first argument is that it is too expensive to maintain these two services. That seems to be the general throwaway line that is used. Is it too expensive? When you look at the net cost to the country of ATV you find that it is about $2.34 million a year. That is when you take out the advertising. I wish there was not advertising on it. I voted against there being advertising on it and still wish there was not.

When you look at the situation as it is now, we do have advertising and that advertising pays for a lot of what is on ATV. The net cost to the country of ATV is about $2 million. When you look at that in the context of the entire budget it is absolutely so minuscule as to be absolutely ridiculous when you consider the good that this television service does us, especially in Asia, the Pacific and including North America.

I was in North America recently and the point was made to me that Australia had gained a great deal of credibility in business in North America because ATV showed that we can do business in South‐East Asia. People were coming to the ABC in North America asking how we went about it. We had gained an immense amount of credibility in North America with ATV. We gained an immense amount of credibility in South‐East Asia and the Pacific particularly in what are called the A and B demographics—that is, the people who are the real decision makers in South‐East Asia and in the Pacific. They do look at ATV and they do take notice because they realise that it is unbiased news and fair and reasonable news. Obviously the cost is nowhere near too expensive. It is a ridiculous argument.

The government has now decided to privatise ATV. I cannot understand this. The good that it does us is so immense. It is the most ridiculous decision. It is just unbelievable. Equally, is Radio Australia too expensive? It costs about $20 million when you include the transmission costs. For the good that that does and the influence that that gives us in South‐East Asia and in the Pacific region in particular, but also in Europe and North America it is not too expensive.

When I was in North America two weeks ago people from the United Nations, from human rights organisations based in the Hague, from the United States Congress, from their international relations committee were asking me—I did not raise the question myself—why on earth Australia was deciding to close down or cut back Radio Australia. They could not believe it. It would be so silly. Nobody can believe it. I cannot believe it. The Minister for Foreign Affairs cannot believe it. Why on earth would we, for the cost of $20 million, which is really very small in relation to the rest of the budget, give up the influence that that gives us? It is unbiased news, it is fair and reasonable and it is in other people's languages, not just our own.

The fact that we have the foreign language services, the non-English services, demonstrates that we have a commitment to this region, that we have a commitment to South‐East Asia and to the Pacific. If we get rid of any of those foreign language services then that demonstrates the very clear message that we are cutting back on our commitment to this region, that we are cutting back on our commitment to anything other than English. That is not a clear message we want to be giving at the moment. It is just ridiculous.

The second argument against Radio Australia and ATV, particularly Radio Australia—and I think one person out of those 2,200 submissions gave this argument—was that the Australian national broadcaster does not have the right to broadcast a point of view which is not that of the government of the country to which that broadcast reaches. I think that is an absolutely and totally outrageous thing to say.

How can anybody who has read the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, who has read the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights, who has read the International Convention on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights say that people in a country other than our own do not have the right to hear what somebody other than their own government has to say? Does that mean that he believes that to Burma we should only be broadcasting what the SLORC says or we should only be broadcasting what Aung San Suu Kyi says? She is the elected leader but she is not the actual leader; the actual leaders are the SLORC.

It follows of course that the ABC, being the Australian national broadcaster should not broadcast anything but what the government says. It follows that anything that the Labor Party, the Democrats or the Greens or anybody else says should be anathema to be broadcast by the ABC. We would not agree to that. Nobody would agree to that. It is the most outrageous statement. How on earth anybody can make that statement in relation to overseas broadcasting I cannot understand. Obviously that is not an argument either.

Therefore, there are no arguments that can be put that would get rid of Radio Australia and ATV, for the influence that it gives us, for the good that it gives us. It is in the national interest that we not only maintain Radio Australia and ATV at the level at which they now are but that we increase them, that we increase the foreign language capacity of both of these organisations and that we make sure that they grow, not that they shrink. It is an absolutely ridiculous argument.

The overseas reaction to this has just been incredible and absolutely massive. There has been reaction from Asia. We have all seen the reactions from Malaysia, Indonesia and from places we would not have expected. People have said in newspapers mostly that Radio Australia in particular and ATV have to be kept on. It is just silly and ridiculous for the government to cut back on them.

BREAK.PARA: Look at the Pacific. Sir Julius Chan while he was still Prime Minister of PNG said that he would give us back $1 million of our aid to Papua New Guinea in order to keep it going because it was such an important service to Papua New Guinea. I am very pleased to see that the government has decided that the Tok Pisin service is to remain. That is good but what about the other services? What about the Cantonese service? That is going to go. Do we have no interest in people from south-east China? Is that why the Cantonese service is going or do we think they should all just learn English and then they will understand what Radio Australia has to say?

The reaction from the USA has been large. One of the rumours going around Washington at the moment, that I was told about when I was there, is that the reason we are cutting back on it is that the government has been pressured by the Chinese government into getting rid of or cutting down on Radio Australia in particular. I hope that is not true. It is certainly a rumour that is going around Washington DC. If it is not true it ought to be scotched by our government immediately. The easy way to scotch it, of course, is to fund Radio Australia and ATV to the current levels. Increasing that funding would be even better.
Let me give you one quote that was in the Herald‐Sun on 3 May. It is from Mr Bruce Gale of the Hong Kong organisation, Political and Economic Risk Consultancy. He is quoted as saying:
Whatever the Australian government does now, it is too late. (Pauline Hanson) and the closing of Radio Australia seem to show Australia turning in on itself.

It is not too late. I do not believe it is too late. We had heard, as Senator Forshaw told us, that Radio Australia would be cut down to a service of $2 million to $3 million in English only and via satellite. The human rights implications of that are so gross and horrendous it is just not worth thinking about.

All these people who live in the backblocks of Indonesia, who live in Burma, who live in places that do not get reasonable, unbiased news from their own news services—and they know that—listen to Radio Australia to find out what is actually going on in their own country and in the region. This is an absolutely basic service. Radio Australia and ATV—particularly Radio Australia over short wave—are the only services that will give these people news about what is going on in their own region. But it is not too late. The position has been expanded from where it was. We have gone up from that $2 million figure and we can keep going up.

The whole basis, however, of this downgrading, this destruction, this abandonment of RA and ATV, is the vicious cuts to the funding of the ABC. That is something that we all have to look at. We all have to make sure that there are no more vicious cuts; in fact, that those vicious cuts are reversed, that the ABC is funded properly and that the ABC is given a reasonable amount of money to do its job both domestically, within Australia, and internationally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, I presented the President with the minority report of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee which made several recommendations about the future of Radio Australia and ATV. But it is important to realise that the groundwork for the cuts that have been made to Radio Australia, and, indeed, to the funding of the ABC, started with the financial situation that the present government inherited when it gained government in March last year and we faced an $8 billion financial black hole. The ABC, in common with many other government departments and government authorities, simply had to take its share of the cuts.

SPEECH.PARA: If the ABC has to look at an overall cut in its funding and it has to choose between international broadcasting and cuts to domestic services, I know what I would be choosing. It is very important to remember that it is the ABC itself which decides where its priorities lie. If I were in charge of the ABC and looking at making cuts to rural and regional broadcasting to people in Australia or international broadcasting, I know what I would choose.

Nevertheless, it is very important to realise that it is the management of the ABC which chooses to make those cuts and the management of the ABC which sets down where the funding lies. I clarified that in my exchange with Mr Johns during the committee hearings, when I said to him that any decision to close Radio Australia would be made by the board. Mr Johns's response was, `Yes, absolutely.'

It is important to realise also that, of the many letters that were written to Radio Australia about the reasons why people listened to it, everyone believed in principle—that is, those who wrote from overseas as to why Radio Australia should not be cut—that it should not be cut. But among the percentage of answers which gave specific reasons as to the value of Radio Australia were the following responses: from the China section, 18 per cent stated that Radio Australia promoted trade, tourism and study connections and 13 per cent of those Chinese letters said that Radio Australia was a valuable ambassador.

Eleven per cent of the letters received from the Indonesian section said that Radio Australia promoted trade, tourism and study connections, and nine per cent mentioned the ambassadorial role. Only 15 per cent of the total responses which have been processed and categorised by Radio Australia said that Radio Australia is an ambassador for Australia; 13 per cent said that Radio Australia promoted trade, tourism and study involvements.

If the ABC board has to prioritise its funding levels, I would expect that it would target the international broadcasting market in those areas which are going to promote trade, tourism and an increase in the way in which we engage with Asia. Certainly that is something which they will have to consider. We should target our market a lot better, and we should make sure that we reach the decision makers in Asia who are going to influence our trade, tourism and educational roles. The way to target the decision makers is to engage them in a variety of mediums—not just Radio Australia, but also ATV, which has been set, I presume, on a successful sale path. There have been many expressions of interest in ATV, and I would expect that, after the end of June, ATV will go on to pursue the very active entrepreneurial role for Australia which it has assumed so far during its very short existence.

We need to target Asia at a variety of levels, and it is not just Radio Australia which is going to provide that in the future. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade provides a valuable service by the dissemination of information through its posts. The private sector plays an increasingly valuable role in sending out our trade, ambassadorial and educational messages, and all the other messages which we need to send out through Asia. As I said, the use of ATV is something which could be expanded almost to an unlimited point in the future.

This inquiry was basically set up as a political stunt. It was given a time frame of three months—between February and the start of May—and there is no way that a reporting date one week before the budget could possibly hope to influence the budget process. I was rather disappointed that in spite of much of the valuable work done by the Mansfield report, the opposition chose to denigrate that report as something that had made no contribution whatever to this debate. I would prefer to believe the opposite.

Certainly, in the decisions that have been made both by the government, in keeping some of the language services, and by the ABC board to keep the Indonesian service, I believe that we have recognised the essential components of Radio Australia and the areas of Radio Australia where we should be putting our efforts in the future. Therefore, I commend the minority report to the Senate and I look forward to further actions by the government to consolidate our efforts in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I would like to say in speaking to this report is that it is not a political stunt by the opposition. It was brought about by the fact that the government, for their own perverse reasons, were going to axe Radio Australia and sell off ATV. That was purely an economic rationalist decision. There is no doubt, as Senator Bourne said here earlier, that the money was there to keep both ATV and Radio Australia alive, because they both serve a valuable purpose for our neighbours in Asia and the Pacific region.

SPEECH.PARA: If one thinks we are alone in servicing those areas, one only needs to look at chapter 8 of the report where well-known broadcasters in that region are listed, and it is interesting to look at a few of them. The BBC World Service broadcasts in 12 regional languages; Voice of America, 12 regional languages; Deutsche Welle, six regional languages; Voice of Russia, nine regional languages; Radio France International, five regional languages; and Voice of the Islamic Republic of Iran, seven regional languages—and so the list goes on and on.

So what we are doing in the Asian region and the South Pacific is nothing unusual. There are many both independent and national broadcasters beaming into that part of the world to put their point of view or at least to have their point of view heard by the people with whom they are going to deal. That is the burgeoning market for the Australian nation—that South-East Asian region—and we cannot ignore it.

Yet what this government is attempting to do by reducing the service of Radio Australia and by selling ATV is to reduce our direct influence in that part of the world. I think that is a completely reprehensible move on the part of this government.

I will turn in particular to some of the remarks made by my colleague Senator Forshaw. Senator Forshaw made it quite clear that the Mansfield report did not in any way address the issue of foreign broadcasting—in particular, with Radio Australia and Australia Television. So that completely dispels what the government have said in their minority report and what has been put to this chamber today by Senator Troeth.

There is no doubt that there is a real role and a real part to be played by both Radio Australia and Australia Television as independent broadcasters—and this is the important thing. They are independent broadcasters, as opposed to some of the other broadcasters who broadcast into the Asian and South-East Asian region.

BREAK.PARA: Radio Australia and ATV—even though Australia Television has only been going for a short time—have gained a lot of respect and have gained a lot of loyal listeners or viewers, whichever the case may be. They are quite essential to many people throughout this area.

The figures that Senator Troeth was quoting before may serve her purpose well, but they do not represent the overwhelming evidence that was given to the committee when it was taking evidence in the various states of Australia. So there is no doubt that what we are seeing is the axing or the diminution in the role of a vital—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for debate on this matter has expired.
—I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT —I present a response from the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the resolution of the Senate on 10 December 1996 concerning Burma.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

What an extraordinary cop-out by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) and the Howard government this letter back to the Senate is. On 10 December last, the Senate adopted my motion which called on the Howard government to follow suit with the Clinton Administration and the Congress of the United States in legislating to ensure that trade contacts with Burma were terminated. The terms of the American resolution stated:

. . . the Government of Burma has physically harmed, rearrested for political acts, or exiled Daw Aung San Suu Kyi or has committed large‐scale repression of or violence against the Democratic opposition.

Since that time—in fact, just two weeks ago—reacting to continuing repression of democracy and the people in general by the SLORC military government in Burma, President Clinton decreed and brought into law that there shall be no further investment by United States entities, persons or corporations in this military dictatorial country.

The government and the minister here are well aware of what the SLORC government in Burma has done. Firstly, it has totally corrupted democracy by refusing to accept that Suu Kyi is the properly elected head of state. She was elected in proper democratic elections by the people of Burma, but instead of being the elected head in Burma, she is under house arrest and her life is increasingly in danger. Beyond that, many people who support her or who have otherwise given expression to their feelings in Burma are in gaol and are being or have been tortured or killed—that is thousands of people.

Reports coming back from all over that country are that this is one of the most abominable repressions by a government of its own people anywhere in the world today. We read about villagers who are being shot and people who are being raped. Adults and children are indiscriminately being grabbed from their villages. They are being abducted on walks between villages and taken off to slave camps where they are working for nothing under deplorable conditions which no self‐respecting government in the world would allow—degrading conditions which are not dissimilar to those which we have seen under military occupation of foreign countries by reprehensible dictatorships in the past. This is a country enslaved. This is a country where the abrogation of democracy and rights is standard. But this is a country which this Australian government is giving succour to by its failure to take stronger measures.

The Senate was quite right in passing the motion; the government is terribly wrong in essentially thumbing its nose at that motion. It is noticeable in this letter from Alexander Downer—which, by the way, has taken some five months to come back to us—that he does not even recognise Suu Kyi as a democratically elected head of state. He tries to get out of Australia doing anything about the SLORC regime in Burma by saying that Australia accounts for less than one per cent of total foreign investment in Burma and that our trade in or out of that country accounts for less than one per cent of international trade, and therefore sanctions on Burma are going to have very little real effect. That is an inverse argument if ever I heard one. The argument is usually the pain that will be brought on the country levying the sanctions. What Alexander Downer is saying in this letter is that there will be very little pain indeed to the Australian business community, and to this country as a whole, if we follow suit with the United States. He may have a stronger argument—in fact governments traditionally do have a stronger argument—if there is more at stake.

This is the same Howard government, let us remember, that refuses to bring Tibet into mainstream debate when there are meetings between heads of government in China and Australia, because of the increasing trade connections and advantages that the government sees for Australian businesses investing in China. Without expostulating on this, the real reason is that it is dollars before people, and it is mounting billions of dollars that are involved in that trade. And this is the strongest argument this government has for turning a blind eye to what is happening in Tibet.

But they turn that argument right around. The minister turns that argument completely on its head when it comes to Burma. He is saying that, because less than one per cent of Burmese trade and investment comes from Australia, we are not going to levy the same sort of embargo that the United States has just levied. It is cowardly, it is thoughtless, it is irresponsible, and it is an embarrassment to have this country, which holds democratic principles and liberty and life at such high levels, represented by a government that cannot even rise to the occasion in following suit with the United States in a very limited action to try and bring some pressure to bear on the SLORC military government in Burma. The minister, Alexander Downer, and the Prime Minister, who no doubt is in full consultation on this, stand condemned.

BREAK.PARA: Most Australians will abhor this attitude from this government which puts a few dollars and a few sectional interests ahead of the wider principles which Australians hold clear and dear. If the average Australian knew a little bit more about arrant cruelty and destruction of life and liberty that is going on in Burma, they would be all the more appalled by the weak‐kneed, wimpish attitude of this minister and this government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to order of the Senate and on behalf of the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), I table documents relating to the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement, which was the subject of a return to order moved successfully by Senator Lees on 26 March. I also seek leave to incorporate a tabling statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
In considering which of the documents sought by Senator Lees should be tabled I have been guided by the exemption provisions of the Freedom of Information Act.

I have decided not to table any material setting out the Commonwealth's confidential negotiating position in discussions with Victoria on the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement. I believe that disclosure of this material could reasonably be expected to cause damage between the Commonwealth and that state and jeopardise further Regional Forest Agreements in Victoria.

While there is a general public interest in the availability of information on dealings between the Commonwealth and states, against that I have considered the wider public interest in the Commonwealth being able to freely conduct its Regional Forest Agreement negotiations. Although the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement has been concluded, there remain to be finalised other agreements with Victoria and other states and it is essential that the Commonwealth's negotiating positions maintain currency for these negotiations.
I have also decided not to table:
‐ documents which would be privileged from production in legal proceedings on the grounds of legal professional privilege;
‐ documents affecting the personal privacy of individuals; and
‐ a small number of internal working documents whose release I do not consider to be in the public interest

In tabling the remaining documents relating to Senator Lees' motion, I confirm that both the Commonwealth Government and the Victorian Government remain committed to actively investigate and participate in World Heritage assessment of the Australia‐wide Eucalypt theme, including any potential contribution from East Gippsland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the adjournment of this debate, I was raising with Senator Kemp the importance of having all of the information available prior to our deciding on this particular issue, or even prior to expressing a concluded view on this particular issue. Here, of course, we are talking about the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge (Assessment and Collection) Bill 1997 and, as we all know, the Treasurer had the Commonwealth Actuary head a committee to report on the implementation of the scheme that the government has. I had asked Senator Kemp to table that document because I think it will be an extremely revealing document if it is tabled. I see that Senator Kemp is not, as yet, in the chamber. We have the Manager of Government Business in the Senate in the chamber and I am wondering whether he could let the Senate know whether that document, namely the report of the Actuary, is available to be tabled in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: From what I can gather, there are a number of matters in the Actuary's report which would be of great interest to the chamber, not only to members of the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens, but also to government members. All I can do is to hope that the government would accede to the request to have the Actuary's report tabled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the issue that Senator Harradine has raised, this actuarial report, I agree with Senator Harradine that it is important and I hope, when Senator Kemp is able to respond on the matter, we are able to see the contents of the report. I notice that in dealing with these first amendments we are moving to some other issues. I do not see anything wrong with that, Senator Harradine, because there are some issues that our amendments do not go to where there is still a big question mark. I will be asking what the states are doing and I will be taking that issue up when Senator Kemp is here.

SPEECH.PARA: The process of the actuarial report is that the government announces a new tax in the budget and then says that they will seek actuarial advice from an actuarial committee. I do not see Senator Kemp with any documents in his hands, so I am not hopeful that we are going to get this actuarial report. It might have to be a request of the Senate.

It is important because it goes to the advice the government has received about defined benefits funds in particular and we will get to that issue a little later. There are some other issues that I do want to take up with Senator Kemp in the context of this debate and, as I said, Senator Kemp, yes, the opposition would certainly like to see a copy of the actuarial report. Perhaps if I stop at this stage, you can respond and then we will continue on with some other matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a couple of preliminary comments which go to the comments I made earlier about the lack of consultation in relation to these amendments. In the last three hours I have had the tax office and the Treasury—some of our finest minds in those two institutions—looking over—
—You need them.

—We always need good advice but, even more than our needing good advice, you need good advice. The reality is that in the totality it is our conclusion that the range of amendments which you have moved and which you landed on this chamber at 12.30—
—Does this include Senator Harradine's amendment?

—We will come to Senator Harradine's amendment. After we have discussed some of those issues, I suspect that you will not be voting for Senator Harradine's amendment—but I do not wish to prejudge the way you will vote, Senator.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments, by and large, would make the bill unworkable. In a number of areas they are very poorly drafted, and they would not achieve the goals that they seek to achieve—unless the goal were to sink the superannuation surcharge on high income earners and politicians.

As we go through each of these amendments, we shall address concerns constructively, but some of these amendments would simply make the bill as it stands quite unworkable. If that is the Labor Party's intention, that is fine and the Labor Party will bear the cost. I hope that, if Senator Sherry is recalcitrant, other non‐government members will not be.

On the issue of the actuarial advisory committee report, we of course issued a press statement—I think it was 15 February—which outlined the action we were taking based on and taking note of the advice in the actuarial advisory committee report. That was a report to government, but our response to the report has been in the public domain for a long period of time and has been the substance of considerable debate. As was the practice of previous governments, it is not our intention to table the report, which was providing direct advice to the government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On this actuarial report, with respect to the specific actuarial advice as to how the surcharge—so‐called—will be applied to defined benefit funds, perhaps Senator Kemp could give us an update on when the Government Actuary will be producing the guidelines that affect defined benefit funds.
—It is the Institute of Actuaries which is developing them, and my understanding is that they have already issued a draft.
—Is that draft publicly available?

—The practising actuaries of actuarial firms would have a copy of it. It is not publicly available, to my understanding. Senator, it is at an advanced stage, so it will depend when that is finalised. The stage is well advanced.
—That is not telling me the date. Is it a month or a week or two months?

—Senator, it is the institute which does the guidance note, and it is up to them. But they are, as I understand, at an advanced stage, as one would expect and hope because I think it is important to finalise these matters.

—Did the report deal with the question of the surcharge applying to pensions or annuities? Is it a fact that the report actually raised serious questions about the applicability of the surcharge to pensions and annuities?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, the terms of reference of the Actuarial Advisory Committee report are attached to the press release which was made on 15 February. That press release outlined, among other things, the approach to superannuation pensions and annuities, golden handshakes and unfunded defined benefit schemes. What we have done there, as indicated by the Treasurer, is that the government established the actuarial advisory committee, chaired by the Government Actuary, to provide advice on the implementation of superannuation contributions for higher income earners.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee was requested to advise the government on the application of the surcharge to defined benefit schemes and unfunded and constitutionally protected schemes. That is what the committee was established for and the detailed response by the government on these issues—taking account of the views that were put by the actuarial advisory committee—were released on 15 February.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that but it is difficult to read the response to a document that we have not read because it is not available to us. All I ask is for you to take it on notice, if you like, and at some particular stage, preferably before we finish this debate, to table the report. I suppose the document is not able to be obtained through freedom of information but it could be obtained by the Senate accepting a motion for return to order. That may be an interesting way of going about it.

—I think I have stated my views on that matter and I do not think I can add anything further to it. The key thing is that the government's approach to these issues has been out for a considerable period of time now. Some of those issues were being debated as recently as last night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the key aspects of this is the continual change that has been occurring in respect of the legislation and the amendment on amendment. But there was another issue that was touched on earlier and that goes to what is happening with state protective schemes. Senator Kemp would certainly be aware that I have asked for a progress report on a number of occasions on the state of negotiations with all of the state governments about applying the superannuation tax to the state constitutionally protected funds.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for our concern is that—let us assume this legislation goes through in whatever the final form is—the federal government wants revenue as a result of this new tax from 20 August last year. When are we going to see the legislation? When is it going to be passed in each state in order that the government is collecting the revenue from the state constitutionally protected funds via the state governments?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are keen to finalise these things as soon as possible. I cannot give you a ball‐by‐ball description of where these matters are at but there is no lack of interest on our part in having these matters finally resolved. It is—just to underline the fact—the government's policy intention for the surcharge to apply to superannuation contributions of all high income earners. There are some restrictions imposed on the government by the constitution, including section 114, which effectively protects some state government schemes from a surcharge. But it should be noted—again, this is quite contrary to some reports that have been issued—that such constitutionally protected state schemes represent a minority of state superannuation schemes. There are some complexities but the government is anxious they be resolved.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an important issue because we would be in a ludicrous position if private sector employees were affected by this legislation and federal government employees were affected by this legislation, with the exception of currently serving judges, but those same classes of employees were not taxed in the same way by the respective state funds. I am sure that is a position you do not want to develop, Senator Kemp.

—Without going into the detail of every word you said, I would have thought you probably got it in one. We want it to apply to all schemes and we have to deal with the constitutionally protected schemes, as we have discussed before. As I said, it is the government's hope that this can be resolved as rapidly as possible. But they are a minority of schemes. I think we should not overemphasise the problem, as some commentators appear to have done. They are a minority of schemes but, nonetheless, I think the government's intention is clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept that they are a minority of schemes: we are not arguing that point. What we are concerned about is the absurd position we would be in in this country. We did pose this question to the tax office at one of our estimates—it may have been at the hearings before the Senate committee—of whether they could think of any federal government tax that will potentially not apply to the same class of employees by virtue of their being employed by the state government. They could not come up with an answer. We certainly believe that if this measure is going to go through then it should be applied to the states as well.

SPEECH.PARA: This new superannuation tax was announced on 20 August last year and here we are in the Senate on 6 May debating the legislation. Is there any state that has agreed to pass the necessary complementary legislation at this point in time in respect of the surcharge?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just had further discussions with my officers and the advice—in general; I do not say this applies to all states—is that the states are waiting until this legislation is through. The sooner we can get this legislation through the sooner we can get these matters, hopefully, resolved.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us assume this legislation goes through in whatever final form. Do you want that legislation in its final form to be reflected by each and every state and territory in the Commonwealth?

—Senator, we want these so-called state constitutionally protected schemes to ensure that the surcharge is appropriately applied to high income earners. That is what we are all seeking. I do not think I can add any more to that. I am glad you feel it should be applied. We feel it should be applied. In general, the view is—and I do not say this applies to every state—that the states are waiting for this bill to go through. You suggested that the Commonwealth would be in an awkward position; I think the states would be in an awkward position if the surcharge was somehow not applied in particular schemes. As I said, it is our intention that it will be.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp, you say it is your hope and intention. Putting aside the issue of the states waiting to see this legislation pass, have any of the states agreed in principle to legislate to reflect the federal surcharge legislation in their respective states?

—Senator, as I said, we have stated our position. We understand that, in general, the states are waiting to see that the bill goes through. We are very keen that this should be applied to ensure that the surcharge is applied equitably across the system. There is no lack of intention on our part, Senator Sherry. But one could, from the states' perspective, say, `Well, let's wait to see that the surcharge goes through.' I cannot add any more to it. The sooner we get this bill through the sooner we can get this thing settled down.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CAMPBELL

TALK.START.PARA: —We could have done it before Easter, if it wasn't for you!

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator SHERRY (Tasmania—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (5.47 p.m.)‐ If Senator Campbell wants to be a little provocative, yes, we could have done it before Easter if you had brought it on a little before 10 o'clock at night and did not leave us with two hours to deal with the matter. Senator Campbell obviously does not want it to be completed over the next two days at his current rate of interjection. I will ignore the provocation out of respect for the government's timetable.

Senator Kemp, as I understand it, the Commonwealth had hoped to obtain agreement at the aborted Premiers Conference. Isn't that correct? It sought agreement at the Premiers Conference from the government on these issues in principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I do not think I can say anything more than I have. TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

—You are probably going to give me a by‐line now, aren't you? I am going to walk right into this. There are others who I have found at times to be unreliable.

—Is that okay to do that, Mr Temporary Chairman? I could table a list. —I might get a story on the inside cover tomorrow. Senator Sherry, I think the point Senator Kemp was getting to was that the states quite clearly do not always go along with Commonwealth schemes voluntarily. TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have discussed a range of issues, and I suspect this particular provision has become a sort of catch‐all discussion for other areas that our amendments do not deal with. It does not seem to me that you have justified that basic principle, other than that the government wants half its revenue earlier than it would otherwise receive it.

This will presumably enable most funds to pay any moneys owing without having to borrow. The government has set out what it is seeking. It has set out its budget. It has indicated that this is a major measure; there is no question of that. That is recognised not by all senators but I hope by a majority of senators.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no disagreement that it is a major measure. But why should any fund at all have to borrow money to meet tax liabilities when there was a commitment given by the government that there would not be a tax of any sort? Why should they have to borrow?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —But does it cost the budget over three years any loss of revenue if the advance instalment is not collected—other than the interest that the government obviously earns on the money?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —You have given us the year 1 effect, but I asked what was the effect over three years, on the bottom line collection, if there is not an advance instalment. What are those figures, please?

—I would like to add another question to that. There does not seem to be any logic to it. If it is in fact only 15 days in advance, as the minister suggests, then what is the rationale? What are the benefits to be gained from creating a rather complex situation in order to get 15 days in advance?

—Senator, it is not complex. It is a revenue measure. I have indicated that the contributions are in. There is a desire to seek complexity when complexity does not exist. A great deal of work was done in the consultative process to sort out potential problems and difficulties. This is a major revenue measure. It was announced in the budget last year.
