It is a measure which was announced in the budget, and the government is seeking to give effect to its budget. As I said, this measure is well known—it was announced. I do not know whether Senator Sherry wants to take $160 million out of the budget, and we hope that that is not his intention. No matter how one may attempt to portray it, it is not an onerous measure.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp, you still have not answered my question. What is the bottom line loss to government revenue over the three years by there not being an advance instalment? Could you please ask your advisers what that cost is?
—My advisers tell me that it is at least $160 million over the three years.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly cannot see why it costs $160 million by eliminating the advance instalment over the three‐year period.

—Senator, you asked me to ask my advisers. I asked my advisers and they provided me with a figure. As I have said, it is not unduly onerous. Most of the contributions are in. It is an important budget measure and we ask the Senate to pass it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, this is the first opportunity I have had to congratulate you on your election to Deputy President of the Senate.
—Thank you.

—I want to use this time in the committee stage of the superannuation bills to ask the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) whether he could listen to these particular matters that have been raised and give a response on them, particularly in respect of defined benefit schemes. Whilst I acknowledge that these particular matters that I am about to raise are not specifically related to the amendment that is before us, this amendment and the fact that we are in the committee stage anyhow have enabled a number of questions to be asked of the government.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise a number of matters now. I ask the minister for his response, particularly relating to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. We have had a number of representations about it. Of course, it is a defined benefit scheme. The employer does not make contributions during the life of the scheme but pays a defined benefit. In the case of public servants, it is usually a pension on the retirement of the employee.

The proposed 15 per cent surcharge contained in this legislation requires that a notional employer contribution is actuarially assessed each year in order to calculate the amount of the surcharge owing for that year. The surcharge amounts assessed each year accumulate until the member retires or leaves the fund. Interest is charged on the accumulating amount each year at the 10‐year Treasury bond rate, which is currently almost eight per cent. The final amount owing is paid by commuting the pension otherwise payable, deducting the amount owing and then recommuting the remainder into a reduced pension.

The net result of this approach is that after the first year the effective surcharge rate will be more than 15 per cent because of the effect of interest charged on the amount. The total owing will increase rapidly because of the compounding effect of the interest charges. In one scenario, a public servant with 15 years service would pay half as much again in interest charges than he or she would if he or she were able to arrange for the surcharge amount to be paid annually as it fell due.

Is it not a fact that the legislation discriminates against members of defined benefit funds in at least three areas? It will not permit defined benefit funds to pay the surcharge amount owing annually as it falls due. The surcharge is to be based on a notional employer contribution to be actuarially calculated each year. The eventual loss to a member of a defined benefit fund when that member retires or leaves the fund, in respect of the extent of the reduction in the member's final benefit, usually a pension, will again depend on an actuarially calculated variable—namely, the commutation rate to be applied.

These three factors result in discrimination between members of defined benefit schemes, such as the Commonwealth's superannuation scheme, and members of accumulation schemes, which is of interest to all of us, such as the PSS. Because the actuarial products will presumably be averaged to apply to a particular scheme, the last two factors that I mentioned will also result in discrimination between members within a defined benefit scheme in that they are notional calculations which do not take into account individual members' circumstances.

In respect of the first factor that I mentioned, members of accumulation schemes will be able to pay their surcharge amount annually thus avoiding interest. In accumulation schemes such as the PSS, members will also be able to increase their contributions within defined limits and in defined circumstances and in so doing will be able to increase the amount of their employer's contributions thus offsetting to an extent the reduction in final benefits which would otherwise apply. I believe this is important for us because we have some responsibility in that particular matter.

Members of accumulation schemes also have the benefit of receiving interest on their employer's contribution each year. As there are no regular employer contributions in defined benefits schemes, these options are not open to members of such schemes—and here I particularly refer to the Commonwealth Public Service scheme—who will suffer the additional inequality of being forced to pay compound interest on the accumulating notional amount of surcharge plus interest. Members of defined benefit schemes will usually have planned their retirement on the basis of expected final salary level and a percentage of that salary will be paid as a pension. The surcharge which is contained in this legislation will effectively reduce the final pension payable.

I ask honourable senators whether that is fair and just and whether it amounts to the Commonwealth taking a decision which in effect repudiates the employment contract into which these public servants entered many years ago. I ask the minister if he would like to comment on the matters that I have raised because I think as the employer of public servants the government does have a responsibility to those public servants who are members of defined benefit schemes and who will be discriminated against by this legislation as I have just indicated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I too acknowledge your recent elevation and again offer my congratulations and as always my cooperation, as you have noted over the years.
—Thank you, Minister. I look forward to that.

—There are, of course, a wide range of funds which the government has to deal with and the idea is to treat all funds in an equitable fashion. What we are seeking is to ensure that people are treated in an equitable fashion. Some would argue that people in defined benefit funds are advantaged by the payment deferral. I think economists would say that, depending on the rate of interest, if there is no interest it often is an advantage to defer a payment.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a spate of articles initially when this scheme was announced. My memory, and I think it serves me correctly, is that there was a feeling that people in defined benefit schemes such as the ones you are referring to would be advantaged. The idea is to prevent unfunded defined benefit schemes being advantaged by payment deferral. The notion is, if you have to pay the same amount now or you have to pay it later, it may well be an advantage to pay it later. Scheme administrators will be required to maintain accumulation accounts of relevant members linked to a prescribed interest rate to maintain its value.

What we are seeking is not to advantage one particular fund compared with another type of fund. What we are seeking to do is treat all arrangements in an equitable fashion. That is why there is a prescribed rate of interest. That is why there is the development of a notional surcharge contribution. As I said, we believe that what we are doing is treating funds in an equitable fashion.

BREAK.PARA: There was a feeling initially in some of the debate that the ability to defer payment, as in the defined benefit schemes, would be seen to be an advantage. You are now seeing it as a problem, but I think the attempt to ensure equality of treatment between the two different types of funds requires the payment of a rate of interest which I think most economists would agree is required to achieve equality between payments which are paid in different periods of time.

Senator, let me assure you the government does not seek to advantage one particular group over another. It does not seek to advantage one particular scheme compared with other schemes. The arrangements I think are best summarised in the press release of 15 February, which looks in some detail at the contribution rates for defined benefit funds and unfunded defined benefit schemes. I hear what you say. My advice is that we are seeking to treat all schemes in an equitable fashion. We are not seeking to advantage one particular type of scheme compared with another type.

TALK.START.PARA: —The interest is charged at the 10-year Treasury bond rate, but in defined benefit schemes because it cannot be paid by the funds in that particular year that interest rate is not only applied but the interest compounds annually. How can you say that the beneficiaries of those funds are treated equitably with those funds that can pay out on an annual basis? I cannot follow that. The interest compounds annually.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not a statistician. I do not know whether you are, but I certainly am not.
—He is very good at numbers—Senator Harradine. I never underestimate him on that angle.

—That is right. That is an interjection which I think has some merit for a change, Senator Sherry. He is good at numbers but he is not good on this number, let me tell you. The statistical experts who sit beside me have pointed out that in order to achieve equality you have to apply an interest rate which applies each year. If you borrow $100 this year you have to pay interest on that. If that interest is not paid then you have to pay another 10 per cent or whatever.

SPEECH.PARA: The very strong advice that we get is that this has been done to ensure equity. People may have a particular preference, not economic reasons, for money today rather than money tomorrow or indeed vice versa, but I think in the economic sense we are seeking to achieve equality of treatment between two very different types of schemes—between accumulation schemes and unfunded defined benefit schemes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to finalise this matter, I propose to seek leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard a table of numbers which I am sure the Senate will find of interest. I am sorry that I have not shown it to the minister and to other honourable senators. Perhaps if Senator Margetts is given the call I will then seek leave shortly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister might assist us by telling us who is actually going to benefit from the difference between bond rates and normal bank rates, whose hand will be in whose pocket and what will happen with that. Also, the minister indicated that there has been a great deal of consultation. I wonder how much notice the government has actually taken of the consultation. I have just seen a press release from the Institute of Actuaries of Australia in which they have indicated:

SPEECH.PARA: We remain of the view that the government's preferred course of action is not a good one. The institute has drawn the government's attention to a number of problems with the current superannuation surcharge, including the complicated and expensive method of collection, the likely inequities for individuals because of averaging, the difficulty of calculating the surcharge for defined benefit funds and different treatments for defined contribution and defined benefit funds and possible tax avoidance.
That probably supports what has been said by Senator Sherry and me in relation to the complexities. Are you suggesting the actuaries are all wrong here and it is not complex at all?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not suggest that there are not issues here which are issues which have a degree of complexity but I think there is a tendency in this whole debate to overstate in a number of areas the complexity which is involved. The complexity for the collection has been raised as being somehow incredibly complex although much of it involves exactly what funds do in the normal course of business. What funds have to do is supply the tax office with a person's name, contributions and tax file number. There is nothing hugely complex about that. The tax office has then got to match it up with income and, where required, send back a debit to the fund. That is not hugely complex.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there have been a lot of attempts to try to prevent the introduction of a measure which, after all, is about equity. I think the Greens support the 15 per cent. The Labor Party supports the 15 per cent—or do they? Time will tell. But they did support it. I do not think the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, has indicated he has done a complete backflip. They indicated they would support it.

There are issues which involve a degree of complexity but I think there has been a bit of a tendency amongst some groups to overstate the complexity involved. I have given a summary regarding the collection. The Institute of Actuaries gave some emphasis to this issue in the statement which Senator Margetts read. Frankly, it is not as complex as other schemes which were put forward including, we think, the scheme which was put forward by ASFA. I do not want to diminish the fact that this involves some challenges, but to suggest that the collection device is hugely complex as far as the funds are concerned overstates the case.

The issue of the choice of the bond rate was raised. Senator Margetts, we should not always assume people do things out of mala fides or ill faith. The 10‐year Treasury bond rate was used as this rate reflects the interest on long‐term Commonwealth debt. It is seen as appropriate that long‐term debts due to the Commonwealth are subject to the same rate of interest as applies to long‐term debts owed by the Commonwealth. That is the rationale for the particular interest rate which was chosen.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot find any mention in the budget statements of August last year of the advance instalment.
—Which year are you looking at?

—I am looking at 1997‐98, 1998‐99 and 1999‐2000—4.5 in the budget statements. Could you or your advisers draw to our attention the reference to the advance instalment in these budget statements from last year?
—We will provide you with some advice on that. Without having the budget papers here, it is difficult, but I think we can provide you with some advice after the dinner break.

—You are arguing with us that this amendment will allegedly cost $160 million. Where is the reference to this $160 million advance instalment? —My advisers tell me it is in the revenue estimates. We are happy to see whether we can give you any further information on that after dinner. I think we would need to get the documents and provide you with some references, if we can.

—This casts doubt on the information we get from your department. We asked this question during the estimates hearings and we could not be provided with an answer. But if it is included in these three figures, why is there no reference to actually saying there is an advance instal ment in these figures, in these papers and in the other papers which the Treasurer (Mr Costello) released on budget night? The first we became aware of an advance instalment was some months later.
—You have raised a number of issues. We will assist and, as I said, perhaps we could come back to that and provide you with that information after dinner—or before if we can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that you might need a bit of time, but we have got to come to a vote on this issue, and it is a pretty important question. You are saying to us that, if we remove the advance instalment, it is going to cost the government the bottom line revenue—$160 million. We want to know where it is identified in these documents and why, on the previous occasions when questions have been asked about this, we have not been able to get this figure? Where has the $160 million appeared from since budget night? I understand the difficulty and I am sure you can provide us with an answer after the dinner adjournment, but we certainly want that information prior to moving to a vote on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 1 on page 504 is being circulated. I understand that amendment No. 1 corrects any potential problem that may emerge from our amendment No. 6 as to a possible loss of government revenue. I seek leave to move amendment No. 1 on page 504 and amendment No. 8 on page 466 together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 7, page 5 (after line 14), after subclause (2), insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: No surcharge payable unless contributions exceed the surchargeable contribution threshold

SPEECH.PARA: (2A) Surcharge is not payable for a financial year unless the member's superannuation contributions for that year exceed the surchargeable contribution.
Note: For surchargeable contribution threshold see section 9A.
(8) Page 9 (after line 24), after clause 9, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Surchargeable contribution threshold for 1996-97 financial year

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The surchargeable contribution threshold for the 1996-97 financial year is $2,000.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Surchargeable contribution threshold for later financial year

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The surchargeable contribution threshold for a later financial year is worked out in accordance with section 9 as if the term surchargeable contribution threshold were substituted for the term surcharge threshold in that section.

These two amendments deal with a very important issue for the Labor Party, namely, the issue of the non‐collection of surcharge tax revenue from low and middle income earners. This is one of the two sets of amendments that are critical to our support of the third reading of this legislation. It has been claimed, time and again, that the government wants to collect this revenue from high income earners—those people earning more than $70,000. The income level is actually somewhat less than that, but we will not argue about that detail—it is an important side issue, but it is a side issue.

BREAK.PARA: We know, despite the assurances Senator Kemp can give about the intensive campaign that will be waged by the tax office, that there will certainly be some people who will have to pay the surcharge who earn less than $70,000. The advice we receive from those we refer to as expert advisers and Senator Kemp refers to as vested interests is that there will be a very significant number of people earning less than $70,000 who will be required to pay the surcharge because of the non‐provision of tax file numbers—and we cannot find anyone who contradicts this. We have been given figures showing that enormous numbers of people will be hit by this collection of tax revenue from low and middle income earners. This is one of our fundamental concerns.

The numbers we are given vary considerably. We have had figures ranging from a million to two million to 2½ million. No one can give us an accurate figure but we are told constantly that it will be very substantial. We are told by all the experts that the number of low and middle income earners who will be hit by the surcharge and who should not be hit by it will exceed the number of people who should be taxed—those earning more than $70,000. That is what we are told by all the experts, and we cannot find anyone to contradict that.

We can argue or disagree about the number of low and middle income earners who will be hurt, but the government's continual assertion is that it is only after revenue from those people earning more than $70,000. Labor's fundamental principle on these two amendments is that, if there is tax assessable on low and middle income earners—as there will be—it should not be collected. That is the fundamental principle underlying the two amendments we are considering.

Because of the drafting of the collection mechanism, the superannuation surcharge bills—as they are currently drafted—do not fulfil the commitment that this legislation is aimed at taxing high income earners and not low and middle income earners. Labor will not accept a piece of legislation—or vote for it at the end of the day—if low and middle income earners are hit by this tax, albeit as a by‐consequence of the collection mechanism.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't have to be hit.

—The interjection was, `They don't have to be hit.' But the reality, Senator Ferguson, as you know—and you have sat on the superannuation committee and are experienced in the industry—is that we are dealing here with an enormous number of people. We are dealing with close to eight million people and, I think, 16 million superannuation accounts. You should know the practical problem of collecting tax file numbers in the next few months in order that the assessment can be made. It is an enormous problem.

BREAK.PARA: We fail to see why those people who are assessed as being low or middle income earners should have to pay one single dollar of tax that they should not have to pay. Why should the tax office go through the enormous cost of collecting tax that apparently at some later date is going to be refunded? The government said, `This money is refundable,' but why collect tax from 100,000 people, half a million people, one million people or two million people—from anyone, for that matter—who should not be paying a tax in the first place? As I said, it is the most significant shamble that we have seen in a long, long time.

We have suggested that tax should not be collected from those persons whose superannuation contribution in a year is $2,000 or less. The current superannuation guarantee charge is six per cent—it does increase to nine per cent over time—and we came to the figure of $2,000 by calculating six per cent of a person's average weekly earnings. It is an approximation but—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a guess.
—It is not a guess. This amendment is deliberately—

BREAK.PARA: Senator Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you suggest, Senator Ferguson? Nothing?
—Put in their tax file number.
—Your suggestion is to put in their tax file number. But we know that there are going to be hundreds of thousands of people, if not a million people, who will not put in their tax file number.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Ferguson, I have regard for your intelligence and knowledge of the superannuation industry. You must know, I put it to you, through the committee hearings, through your contact with industry and, in fact, through people who have complained to you about this particular provision that there will be many people who will not put in their tax file number—many people will not realise the consequences of not putting in their tax file number. Why collect the money from them? It is a very fundamental and simple principle.

The government has told us time and time again that there is no money in the budget forward estimates from anyone earning less than $70,000. This is a revenue neutral amendment because the consequence of this is that it refuses to collect money from people who have less than $2,000 put into their superannuation accounts each year. It is revenue neutral—unless of course the government wants this money from low and middle income earners.

It will be a lot of money. We concede that. If these bills are not amended, there will be a lot of individuals affected and there will be a lot of money collected that should not be collected. It might be $50 million, it might be $100 million, it might be $200 million, it might be another $500 million. But if your intention is that it will only affect higher income earners, why should the money be collected from low and middle income earners because the funds do not have their tax file number? Exempt them, Senator Kemp.

I have to say that it was not easy to design these amendments. It was not easy to design these amendments because of the way you have gone about collecting this money through the funds. You have called it a surcharge—you have not called a tax a tax. We have debated that issue often enough, and I think we have scored a fair few points.

TALK.START.PARA: —You still haven't won.

—The chair of the Western Australian Liberal Party superannuation policy, Mr Steve Blizard, seems to think there is at least some credibility to our arguments, judging from his public quotes. So does Mr Eoin Cameron. Mr Eoin Cameron seems to think there is some credibility to our arguments, and he is a colleague of yours.

BREAK.PARA: We have continually asked the government, in estimates committees and on the floor of this chamber, to provide us with estimates on the amount of revenue that will be collected from people earning under $70,000. They will not give it. I know why they will not give any estimates. The figure would be a guesstimate, but it is certainly going to be a very, very sizeable sum.

Senator Kemp, you have continually told us that not one single dollar gained from low to middle income earners is calculated in that $1.5 billion that we talked about earlier and that all the money in the forward estimates will be raised from the high income earners—those earning more than $70,000 a year. If that is true, we would love to see you accept this revenue neutral amendment not to collect the money from those persons whose superannuation contributions are less than $2,000 a year.

If these amendments are carried as well as the Labor amendment in respect of what occurs to workers when they are made redundant, Labor is willing to support the third reading of this legislation. That is our commitment. But what has become obvious to us in this debate on the surcharge legislation during the seven months since the budget has been the continual problems with the legislation. I am not going to go into the details about the legal problems and the re‐writing—and we have dealt with the problem with the states—but there has been a series of continual problems in respect of this package of legislation.

I do not think even you, Senator Kemp, truly understood—and I have to say that I do not think some of my colleagues understood either—the magnitude of the tax that would have been collected from low and middle income earners because of this tax file problem. It has certainly become much more apparent in recent months as a result of the debate and the very important evidence we received before the Senate committee on this very, very critical issue.

Labor's position is very clear. If you want to tax people earning more than $70,000 a year, that is your budget measure, that gives you the revenue and that is what is in the forward estimates. Labor's position is clear. We are disappointed that the government has chosen to break its promise at the election about no increase in taxes or no new taxes, but this is an increase and a new tax. You want the revenue for your budget bottom line. We accept that, so long as it is coming from those earning more than $70,000 a year. But not one dollar should be collected from low and middle income earners—not one cent.

Why should the tax office go through this inordinately expensive process of collecting the money, holding it and having to refund it? I do not think a lot of people would seek a refund, regrettably, and why should you get more than the stated revenue that you put in your forward estimates when you claim this is a fair measure aimed at higher income earners and when lower and middle income earners are caught up in the tax net? It is grossly unfair that any lower and middle income earners should be caught up in the revenue net. Within the technical bounds of designing the amendments to this extraordinarily complex package of legislation that even the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has conceded had some drafting problems, we do not want that money collected from lower and middle income earners. That is one of our two principled positions on this legislation.

There are other amendments, Senator Kemp, which may not be passed. We are not going to be happy with that because we think they will improve the legislation. They are major amendments in their own way because they deal with somewhat smaller issues in the sense of the effect they have, but they are still important and I do not want to downgrade their importance. This to Labor is fundamental: no taxing of lower and middle income earners, no collection of the tax. I note—and we will deal with an amendment later on—that where the tax is collected and it is refunded there will be no interest paid. That seems to us to be fundamentally unfair. We are talking here about a massive number of people who may be hit with a new tax. The critical thing is, this money is taken out of their fund by the fund trustees, passed on to the government, and these taxpayers, through no fault of their own, are losing interest on money that has been taken out. Why should they lose the accrued interest over that period? But we will get to that amendment later.

We would certainly like to see the government accept this amendment. It is intended to be revenue neutral and our drafting will reflect that. We would certainly appreciate any advice the government is willing to give us on that drafting. Goodness knows, we have been giving them enough advice in the last few months on the continual amendments that have had to be made to the government's legislation. It is our intention, based on the budget estimates, only including revenue from people earning more than $70,000 and not including one cent, Senator Kemp, from people who earn less than $70,000, that this will be a revenue neutral set of amendments. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I flagged in my first contribution to the committee stage of this bill that I would be seeking to move an amendment to Senator Sherry's amendment No. 8. That is one of the amendments he has just moved. The idea is to replace his section 9A(2) with a definition which, we believe, will be clearer and is less likely to suffer from the changes that will occur, especially when the employer contribution increases. I would like to commend this amendment to the committee. This should, more clearly, allow people to know where they stand in relation to the surchargeable contribution threshold. I would definitely go along with the whole prospect—as I have mentioned in my speech—of making sure that those who should not have to pay the threshold are not going to be subject to unnecessary complications and have to pay money that they should not have to pay and then get it back through sometimes difficult processes.

SPEECH.PARA: There is at least one superannuation fund that I have not yet got around to advising what I am going to be doing in respect of my tax file number. I am sure there must be lots of other people in the same situation. People will have difficulty in knowing what they have to do to get their tax back. They will not know whether they have to go to a tax agent to work out what they have to do and so on. We all know the difficulties. There are a lot of people who cannot afford a tax agent who might be in a worse position.

What we are trying to do is go along with what the opposition are saying, but simplify or clarify their section 9A(2) in relation to working out what the surchargeable contribution threshold is, based on the formula of an annual average weekly ordinary time earnings, times 52, times the percentage of compulsory superannuation contributions from employers. We think that would be fairer and we think it means that people will know where they stand now and in the next couple of years when things change.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 8, page 6 (line 23), at the end of subclause (2), add:

PARA.TAB: , but excluding any amount paid to the member as a result of an insurance payment.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 43, page 44 (lines 6 to 13), omit the definition of adjusted taxable income , substitute:

PARA.TAB: adjusted taxable income of a member for a financial year means the amount worked out as follows:
(a) the member's taxable income for the year of income, not including any amount paid to the member as a result of an insurance payment;

(b) the amount of any eligible termination payment (apart from an eligible termination payment within the meaning of paragraph (d)) paid in respect of the member in respect of that year of income; and
(c) any amount in payment of unused leave;
(d) any net capital gains included in assessable income under section 160ZO(I) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936;

TAB.TAB: plus

PARA.TAB: (e) the retained amount of an eligible termination payment (because of paragraph (a) of the definition of eligible termination payment subsection 27A(I) of Subdivision AA of Division 2 of Part III of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936) paid by an employer.

SPEECH.PARA: These two amendments deal with adjustable taxable income. Our reasons for moving these amendments are that, under this definition, the commissioner calculates the members' adjustable taxable income to determine whether the surcharge is payable and the rate of the surcharge. The adjusted taxable income for a member is the sum of taxable income and surcharge on the contributions.

The purpose of these amendments is to exclude from adjusted taxable income all eligible termination payments other than payments under paragraph (a) of subsection 27A(1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, golden handshakes. Paragraph (d) of the opposition's amendment seeks to ensure that employee share schemes are also excluded from the definition of annual taxable income.

The opposition is very concerned that currently the definition of adjustable taxable income includes things such as ETPs, unpaid leave and like benefits that may be received by an individual when retrenched or made redundant. The opposition does not believe that these payments should be caught within the definition for the following reasons. Firstly, they are one-off payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of clarification: the amendment that we have under your name does not in fact do what you are saying it does.
—This might be the opportunity to clarify it. I do not know whether Senator Sherry said he was moving amendments Nos 7 and 47. I am not quite clear about amendments Nos 9 and 10, Senator Sherry.
—I am going off a running sheet. Amendments Nos 9 and 10 deal with partial rollovers. I understood that was to be dealt with after amendments Nos 7 and 47.
—Has that clarified the inquiry that Senator Kemp had?
—It is the new informal running sheet, is it not?
—Yes.
—The amendment that we have has nothing about employee share schemes.
—I am coming to that. Amendment No. 47 subclause (e) is the amendment that deals with employee share schemes.
—We are still having trouble. We do not have the same sheet of paper that you are working from. Would you have another copy of what you are working from so we can follow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am assured that the comments I am making will be dealing with amendments Nos 7 and 47. Our amendment No. 47 is the definition of `adjustable taxable income'. Looking through our amendment, Senator, I have referred to ETPs, unpaid leave and like benefits that may be received, and that is clearly what our amendment No. 47 deals with in respect of adjustable taxable income. Employee share benefits are covered by subclause (e).

SPEECH.PARA: We do not believe these payments should be caught within the definition for the following reasons. Firstly, they are once-off payments that are in keeping with industrial practices. They are not payments of a Bartels nature. These are payments that many of the 13,000 Telstra workers, for example, who will be made redundant will receive upon the cessation of their employment. Many of these people will not have any other form of income. Their superannuation is in fact their only security. We cannot accept that a government that is committed to a comfortable and relaxed Australia would seek to destabilise so many Australians.

The definition as currently drafted actually substantiates a leak that my office had in May 1996—that is, the government was seeking to impose a redundancy tax. That is our opinion of at least some of the effects of the government's current provisions. Interestingly, in our view, the bills as currently drafted attempt to achieve this end, at least in substantial part.

We are also appalled by statements of government officials in the budget estimates. When asked if the surcharge tax would apply to ETPs, the officials answered that it would not and that the surcharge tax would only apply to those payments received on cessation of employment that were in excess of $70,000. I would note that we are not seeking to move an averaging definition. This should be seen as a sign of the opposition being reasonable in its approach on this matter.

Those small business people who sell their business, farmers who sell their farms or receive payments for crops, artists who sell a piece of work or sports people who receive a contractual payment will all have to include these once‐off or irregular payments in their taxable income for that year. This may mean that these people will have to pay the surcharge or tax and, of course, the advance instalment that we talked about earlier. The opposition is taking the reasonable position of only requiring that eligible termination payments and receipt of unpaid leave are exclud ed from the definition of `adjustable taxable income'.

In relation to paragraph (d), we believe we are keeping the government honest. It seems that the government is going to have to rely on us to do so. The current definition of `adjustable taxable income', as defined by section 43, would catch all employee share schemes. We do not believe this should be the case—and that is certainly the advice we have had from a number of companies who are concerned about their employee share schemes being caught.

The eligible termination payments surcharge bills impose a surcharge on eligible termination payments paid from employee share schemes. On budget night, the government announced that the superannuation surcharge would apply to golden handshake payments. There was no suggestion the surcharge would apply to ETPs paid from employee share schemes. It is considered that the application of a surcharge regime with effect from 20 August last year to such payments would be both offensive and harshly retrospective. It is the equivalent of imposing a surcharge on existing superannuation benefits.

In 1995, we introduced new legislation dealing with employee share schemes. That legislation ensured that, in effect, shares allocated up to 30 June 1996 could continue to be paid as ETPs and would not be subject to the new taxation regime. In 1995, amendments were made to the reasonable benefits limit legislation ensuring that ETPs paid from employee share schemes were not subject to such benefit limits. It is interesting to note, Senator Kemp, that when you were in opposition you did support employee share schemes and, I understand, the legislation that we put before the Senate at that time.

The termination payments surcharge bills represent an enormous blow to the efforts made by the employer to give employees a direct ownership stake in the enterprises in which they work, providing incentives—that is something you purport to do—to achieve high levels of productivity and excellence in the workplace. That last statement, the last couple of lines, was made by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) himself in a news release dated 6 February 1996. We do find it strange that the government changes its position on this particular issue when it suits it.

The other point the opposition would like to make regarding eligible termination payments is that they are already taxed. This would in fact be doubly taxing these benefits. In the case of those shares and employee share plans, they would be taxed three times if our amendment were not passed. Of course, this is a new tax measure, when the government promised there would be no increase in taxes or introduction of new taxes under the coalition government. We believe that you are blatantly breaking that commitment to the Australian electorate by the imposition of a surcharge tax, and now you plan to impose another tax on the new tax. This is completely in contradiction to your election statement.

I would like to remind you again, Senator Kemp, that on 17 August your leader, the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, said that no worker would be worse off superannuation wise under a coalition government. Mind you, he also applied that promise in respect of some other matters, including the government co‐contribution. Because I am cognisant of the time, I will just refer to one specific question that we had raised with us late today; you might seek some advice from your advisers on this matter.

We have been contacted by members of the military—I did allude to this matter earlier—who receive retention bonuses in order to encourage them to stay in the armed services. They are claiming to us that, on their advice in reading the definition of taxable income, retention bonuses would be included within that definition. Consequently, when the retention bonus is collected by members of the military, many of them would pass over the $70,000 threshold. You may be able to confirm whether retention bonuses are included for military within the taxable income. We would be adding a further subclause (f) that retention bonuses paid to members of the armed services would also be omitted from the definition of adjustable income.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me deal with a number of the issues which have been raised by Senator Sherry. In relation to opposition amendment No. 7, insurance payments are not included in surchargeable contributions. The current provisions achieve this. We are not sure at all what the amendment is trying to achieve. The amendment is simply not necessary. I repeat: insurance payments are not included in surchargeable contributions. The current provisions, I am advised, achieve this. We are not sure—Senator Sherry may wish to advise us—what the amendment is trying to achieve. I repeat that amendment No. 7 that we are now debating is not necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry then discussed the issue of adjustable taxable income. This is dealt with in opposition amendment No. 47. I wish to make a number of remarks on that. Many senators, and those interested in this debate, would be aware that in the press release issued by the government in February, we made it absolutely clear that the definition of a golden handshake did not include bona fide redundancy and approved early retirement payments to the extent they are within the income tax exemption levels. In the number of debates I have had in the last 24 hours it became apparent that people did not appreciate that fact. I felt that some rather extreme and, to be quite frank, extravagant statements were made, which completely ignored that fundamental issue.

These are, of course, within the income tax exemption limits. They were developed by the Labor government. They were what the Labor government—I think in July 1994—regarded as being fair and reasonable. Bona fide redundancy and approved early retirement payments have been exempt from income tax up to a limit which is indexed annually to average weekly ordinary time earnings. For the 1996‐97 year the income tax exemption limits are $4,348 plus $2,174 per year of completed service with the employee. These are generous and, as I said, they were developed by the Labor government. As I have said in this debate, I regret that a number of people had completely forgotten that bona fide redundancy payments within the income tax exemption limits were excluded from the surcharge.

Senator Sherry's amendment does a number of things which I think are unintended from his point of view, but we do not support them. We believe that the way he seeks to define adjusted taxable income leaves open avoidance using salary sacrifice packaging. It excludes capital gains and, of course, capital gains are often held by high income earners. We do not believe that is an equitable way to go. We believe that it would increase complexity.

Senator Sherry raised the issue of employee share plans. This, I understand, is actually a matter of dispute. I am advised that payments from employee share schemes are not ETPs, following amendments concerning the tax treatment of employee share schemes in 1995.

I think there has been some misunderstanding among some companies in respect of this particular issue. My advisers indicate that employee share plan benefits that arose after 1 July 1996 are included in assessable income under separate provisions in the income tax law. The amendment would exclude only a small number of employee share plan benefits from adjusted taxable income. Therefore, there is different treatment depending on when the benefits in the employee share plan arose. Senator, we heard your words on employee share schemes. As I have said, the issue seems to be more complex than has been indicated to you, certainly by some of the companies. We will not be supporting that amendment.

I understand that the Democrats, after discussions with them, are going to be moving amendments. I understand that we could accept in those amendments super fund ETPs and unused leave on redundancy. So we are prepared to look at this issue once again. I do not think that that amendment is available yet. But, if my information and assumption are correct, and if your amendment when it appears is along the lines I have indicated, the government would support that. But we will not be supporting opposition amendments Nos 7 and 47 moved by Senator Sherry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding, from what we have heard tonight, is that the ALP wants to ensure that certain areas are clearly excluded from the definition of `adjustable taxable income'. We think some exclusions are quite reasonable, but the new amendments seem to include some additional areas which I understand will have significance for some of the unfunded defined benefit schemes and for those receiving Commonwealth disability allowances. These areas are capital increases and insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: We are sympathetic with the intent. I wonder whether, if we exclude insurance from assessable income in order to help some legitimate Commonwealth employees who are not rorting the system and are not getting big salary substitutes, we will not just open up a new method for private industry to do salary sacrifice for executives. I think there might be such options in excluding insurance. I can imagine businesses offering to pay life, health, housing and car insurances for executives as part of a salary package. I would not like to see that untaxed or used as a tax minimisation mechanism.

I have to oppose amendment 7 as it stands, although we would be happy to look at alternative words to allow some of the Commonwealth invalid, disability or sickness items to be included as insurance to be excluded. We have a little concern with the net capital gains situation in subparagraph (d) of Senator Sherry's amendment 47 along the same lines. We have heard some elements of why it has been proposed. We would like to hear what potential there may be for the private sector to abuse the proposed amendment, to create minimisation schemes for high income earners. The indication that I have is that it would apply only to those people who are already on the higher level of income. So you are not looking at Mr and Mrs Joe Average who are part of a small business or a larger business and are engaged in employee share ownership. I think you are looking at people on executive salary packages.

Whilst that is not necessarily a bad thing, in my opinion there is no necessity to shield people on such high incomes from paying a fair amount of tax. If we were to support Senator Sherry's amendment 47, it would be on the basis of putting an amendment which would remove part (d) of that amendment.

I know this makes things almost hopelessly complicated. We are not able to support amendment 7 but we could support amendment 47 if (d) were removed. But, from where I am standing, it does not look like there are the numbers in the Senate to support it even if section (d) was removed. Perhaps Senator Sherry would like to respond.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It will assist us when the Australian Democrats rise to indicate what they are doing. Senator Kemp, do you have a response in respect of retention bonuses in the armed services?

—The advice that I have received is that, to the best of the knowledge of the advisers I have here, retention payments made to members of the military would form part of the recipient's assessable income. Therefore, these amounts would be included in adjusted taxable income for surcharge purposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We would seek to move an additional subclause that would read `(f) retention bonuses in respect of members of the armed services'.
—Are you seeking leave to amend your amendments?
—Yes, to add the words `(f) retention bonuses for members of the armed services'.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: KEMP

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that we will be supporting it, but we grant leave.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After paragraph 43(e), add "; and (f) retention bonus for members of the armed services".

I sense that Senator Margetts has concerns with (d). I flagged in my opening comments the particular problems that some people would have with their net capital gains being included. I would have to accept that there would be some concern with the nature of some capital gains being included in (d). The great difficulty with this process is trying to define what are reasonable capital gains that should not be included in taxable income and what are unreasonable capital gains. So, in the spirit of compromise, we are willing to withdraw from our amendment 47 subclause (d) in respect of net capital gains. I seek leave to withdraw subclause (d) of amendment No. 47.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw subclause (d) in respect of net capital gains. The issues we have before us are as follows. With regard to insurance payments, we do not see this as a significant area of avoidance at all. There are many legitimate situations where a person receives an insurance payment in the event of invalidity and disability; we do not believe that should be included in the adjustable taxable income. We do not believe, on the advice we have received, that there would be any significant tax avoidance remodelling to pay people insurance payments in order to minimise tax.

SPEECH.PARA: By its definition, if there is a payment based on insurance it is subject to a whole range of tests about the validity of the insurance payment, depending on what the type of insurance is. We would hate to see people who receive an insurance payment, in the case of invalidity and disability, have that payment then included within adjustable taxable income. We would argue that the consequences of that are much worse than any possible tax avoidance, which we think, if it did occur, would be minimal. The difficulty it would cause for a number of people if insurance payments were not deleted from taxable income would be considerable.

Senator Kemp said—I think, when I was listening to him—that insurance payments are not included. That is not our advice, Senator Kemp. We have had a number of people raise this issue with us. If it is not included there is no problem in you accepting (a).

TALK.START.PARA: —I just did, Senator. But it adds further complexities to it.

—Certainly the representations that we have had would want to ensure that insurance payments are not included. I will make some further comments on (b) in response to Senator Kemp. With regard to (c), the amount in payment of unused leave: that can be very substantial on redundancy.
—We're prepared to accept that.

—I know you are accepting that. With regard to unused leave, let us take the example of BHP workers who have long service leave. Many of them would have unpaid long service leave and unpaid annual leave and those could be substantial amounts of money. It could be many thousands of dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, we withdraw (d), net capital gains. Amendment No. 47, part (e)—and I apologise if I misled on a couple of points on (e)—goes to the employee share plans. Senator Kemp, you are advised that employee share plans are not included; that is not the advice that we have had. We have had one very major company contact us. They have been to their lawyers and they have carried out an exhaustive examination of the legislation. They still believe they are covered by the legislation. You accept they should not be but their advice to us is that they want assurance that employee share plans are not included.

Finally, with regard to (f)—I am not sure whether Senator Allison was listening when I was asking Senator Kemp about this—we had members of the military contact us about their retention bonuses, which are paid in order to keep members of the military in the armed services. Apparently, on Senator Kemp's advice, retention bonuses for members of the armed services are included in the definition of taxable income. I do not know whether Senator Kemp can make a quick decision on the run but I would have thought you would not want that sort of payment included in taxable income. I could not give you an estimate of the amount involved but it would be a relatively small number of people who would receive retention bonuses who would cross the threshold as a consequence of it being included. We think it is unjust for members of the armed forces to have to pay—or perhaps have to pay, depending on the level of income—if their income is less than $70,000 but they trip over the $70,000 barrier because of their retention bonus in the armed services.

With regard to eligible termination payments, you are right, Senator Kemp, when you talk about bona fide redundancy payments being exempt. There is a definition of that; you have given it to us and we are aware of that. But there are a range of other payments that are made that may not be bona fide redundancy payments on termination.

We do not believe that, on redundancy, an employer is going to devise eligible termination payments outside the bona fide redundancy payments in order to boost the payments to employees to avoid the additional 15—or whatever the level of tax would be over $70,000. We think that there are many instances where there are quite reasonable eligible termination payments that are made. Why should they be caught in the superannuation surcharge tax net? So we will stick with (a), (b), (c), (e) and our new (f), which is the retention bonuses for members of the military.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we were probably a little misled by the terminology of Senator Sherry's amendments Nos 7 and 47(a) because we saw `insurance payment' as something you pay to an insurance company. An insurance payout, however, is something an insurance company pays to you. If it is clear that what you are talking about is an insurance payout as a result of a legitimate claim for all sorts of reasons—theft or injury or illness or whatever—that does clarify things for us. We would be happy to support it on the basis that what you are talking about is an insurance payout. Is that the word you intended?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. I seek leave to change the words `insurance payment' to `insurance payout'.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 7 will now read in part:

BREAK.PARA: . . . but excluding any amount paid to the member as a result of an insurance payout.
And part (a) of opposition amendment No. 47 will read:
(a) the member's taxable income for the year of income, not including any amount paid to the member as a result of an insurance payout . . .
I would just reassure the Senate we are dealing with (a), (b) and (c), we withdraw (d) and (e), and there is a new (f) in respect of retention bonuses for the military.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate that the Democrats in principle support the amendments, but I foreshadow that we have an amendment which we think better covers our concerns. These concerns are around the issue of who is forced to pay the tax surcharge. These amendments seek to ensure that the liability for surcharge is not skewed by the inclusion of retention benefits and unused leave. This is important because, like the previous amendments, unless these provisions are changed then a very large group of ordinary Australians will be dragged into that surcharge tax net.

SPEECH.PARA: Only last week 3,000 Newcastle steel workers were told, `You'll be retrenched within two years.' Some 22,000 Telstra workers are in the process of being retrenched along with 20,000 public servants and several thousand bank employees. Many thousands of these workers would be forced to pay the surcharge under the current bill. Of course, we think that is outrageous.

We are not talking here about high‐flying corporate managers. These are battlers who have been the victims of the economic rationalist policies of both this government and the previous governments. We do not see why the government should put in place the policies that cost these people their jobs and then turn around and collect an extra 15 per cent of their retrenchment benefits on the way out.

I acknowledge that some retrenchment benefits are excluded from the surcharge under the bill as it stands, but this is still quite narrow and not likely to protect many workers facing retrenchment. I also acknow ledge the consent of the government that golden handshakes by employers should be included in the surcharge and we agree with that. As I indicated earlier, however, we will not be supporting the amendments. I trust that this debate will be deferred for a period in order for us to finalise our amendments and to understand just where we are in the debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We were looking for copies of these amendments, but we could not find them.
—Go back a step.
—Do you need a resolution for us to go back to our previous amendments?
—It is proposed that opposition amendments No. 7 and 47 be postponed. There being no objection, it is so ordered. We will now return to amendments Nos 6 and 8.
—I do not believe that amendments Nos 6 and 8 are ready.
—To make sure we are talking about the same thing, as I understand, this concerns, in shorthand, the $2,000 threshold.
—Yes.

—I think Senator Margetts is going to move an amendment to your amendment. I understand that Senator Allison has her own amendment in relation to this matter. I think if we all understand where the debate is going we can now proceed.
—Senator Allison, are you saying that you are not in a position to go ahead with your amendment?
—I foreshadow a further amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that, but we have not got a copy of it so it is a bit impractical for us to proceed until we do get a copy of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not yet moved my amendment. I was waiting until I received it. I understand the Democrats had a problem with our amendment to the opposition's amendment. There was a concern about average weekly ordinary time earnings. They wanted it clarified that that was full time. I understand that the average weekly ordinary time earnings is actually the terminology which is used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and which generally would assume full‐time work. If that were to be clarified by the Democrats, I have no problem with that. I am not sure how to be helpful to the committee at this stage. The committee was helpful to me by waiting until my amendment was available, which it now is. I am not sure where we go from here. I do not know whether it is useful for me to move my amendment at this stage and what the committee would like to do.
—I think you should move your amendment, Senator Margetts, but whether we get much further ahead, I am not sure.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Omit subsection 9A(2), substitute:
(2) The surchargeable contribution t/lresllold for a later financial year is the amount calculated by the formula:

TAB.TAB: (AWOTE x 52) x CSP

PARA.TAB: where:
AWOTE is the annual average Weekly Ordinary Time Earnings for the year, as given in Australian Bureau of Statistics publications 6301.0 and 6302.0; and

CSP is the percentage of compulsory superannuation contributions from employers under section 20 or 21 of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 , plus the percentage of any employee contributions which are compulsory under any Commonwealth, State or Territory law.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an amendment to opposition amendment No. 8 on their revised sheet 466. As I explained before, the idea is to try to make it as clear as possible and to make sure that when there are changes to the employer share ownership rules in relation to compulsory contributions they do not change in front of people's eyes—they know what is involved. It will change with weekly ordinary time earnings as published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in publication 6301.0 and 6302.0. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are so many bits of paper floating around here. We have a copy here, which I think has been distributed, of the Democrat amendment.
—I do not believe the Democrat amendment is available to the chamber at this stage.
—I am just trying to work out which is Senator Margetts's amendment.
—What we are dealing with is sheet 505, which is Senator Margetts's amendment. We have no Democrat amendment at this moment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the amendment as moved by Senator Margetts to our amendment is a more precise formula than a fixed money amount that we have indicated of $2,000. Should I withdraw our amendment in its totality?
—Senator Margetts's amendment will be put and passed.

—We will be supporting it. We think it is a more precise formula, and I have to say thank you and congratulations because this was an extraordinarily difficult cut-off point to try to find some words to exempt lower and middle income earners.

—I would like to indicate that we have taken up this amendment in our foreshadowed amendment, which is not yet circulated. But I just indicate to those in the chamber that we have also picked that up and we support it.

—I, too, indicate that I will support the amendment. The arguments that have been put by Senator Sherry and Senator Margetts have been quite powerful. I believe that the government should consider now whether or not it ought to agree to the amendment itself. After all, it has said that this measure is one that is designed to affect only well-off persons, who are people who are receiving a very high income. This measure is designed to protect the low and middle income earners. I would suggest that the government might now perhaps read the writing on the wall and agree to this measure unanimously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We understand that Senator Allison will move an amendment which we are more comfortable with and which we think addresses the issue in a more effective manner than the manner which is before us. We certainly do not support Senator Sherry's amendment which I now understand has been withdrawn. Is that right?
—No.

—Senator Sherry's amendment has serious administrative problems, it has serious equity problems and it is one which we certainly would not be able to support. On the administrative complexity side, funds will still need to report all contributions. The ATO will still need to accumulate all amounts that are determined if the $2,000 level is reached. There are no savings. The indexation of the $2,000 limit does not work.

SPEECH.PARA: It actually results, according to my advisers, in the threshold becoming $70,000 in year 2. The reason for this is because subsection (2) refers to the surcharge threshold which is stated to be $70,000 in subclause 9(1) of the bill. The amendment would require redrafting to correct this. So we certainly do not accept Senator Sherry's amendment. It is, by the advice I have, poorly drafted and leads to, as I said, some absurdities. The amendment will cost revenue because high income earners will not be charged on the first $2,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp, we are actually debating my amendment.
—Senator Sherry, you have withdrawn your amendment, have you?
—We are supporting her amendment.

—You are going to vote for hers to replace yours. We will not be supporting the amendment of Senator Margetts because we believe that we will be somewhat closer to where we wish to be with the amendment that will be moved by Senator Allison. We have one slight drafting difficulty with that amendment but hopefully in the debate we can resolve that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Just one small point from what the minister was saying. He seemed to be a bit confused about what we are debating. Whilst it is true the opposition have not withdrawn their part of the amendment, ours if it is successful will replace it. So there is no necessity for the opposition to withdraw 9A(2). However, the issues he mentioned about the $2,000 therefore would become redundant if this amendment is supported.

SPEECH.PARA: The one thing that the minister has forgotten—and it is one of the most important principles in what we have been trying to debate here—is that the costs are not just corporate costs. I would like to ask you, if there are indeed hundreds of thousands of people around Australia who end up with the aggravating problem of having to work out if or how they can retrieve money that has been taken from them which they did not have to pay because they were not on the right income or having all the problems of dealing with the annoyance of giving up tax file numbers and so on, what is the real financial and personal cost of hundreds of thousands of people—I do not think we are exaggerating—around Australia having to go through this enormous bureaucratic hoop?

What will the cost of that be in terms of the staffing of various bodies, including the ATO, to try to fix the muck‐up in this instance? If you can conveniently forget the duplicated cost—I think you always talk about unnecessary duplications—right around the country of people trying to deal with this if they do not have an income level at which they should be paying it, the real cost would probably be a saving to you. We would have a much happier population because they would not have to go through all of this unnecessarily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I think you missed the thrust of what I was saying. There is an amendment which we find more practical which will be moved after we have debat ed your amendment, and that is the amendment which we understand Senator Allison will move. So we will be opposing your amendment. We have a slight problem with Senator Allison's amendment; nonetheless, it is a better amendment than the one which you have moved.

SPEECH.PARA: It is our belief that we have made it very clear that the superannuation surcharge applies to high income earners. I have outlined in detail the steps which we have proposed to take in relation to the information campaign of the tax office. As I have indicated, there is no allowance in the figures produced in the budget for moneys collected from low and middle income people.

I have stated on more than one occasion that not one low or middle income person need pay the surcharge. Of course, all that they have to do is supply their tax file number. Senator Sherry has raised some issues as to whether all will do so. Of course, there will be considerable efforts at collection to make sure that they do. The government is at one with all members of this chamber that we wish to ensure that low and middle income earners do not pay the surcharge. But it has to be done in a way which is administratively sensible, which does not provide perverse incentives, for example, for high income earners, by their own packaging arrangements, to avoid the surcharge.

As I pointed out, there are some serious technical problems with the amendment moved by Senator Sherry. Senator, we will not be supporting your amendment. We will be looking more closely at the amendment that Senator Allison intends to move which we think comes closer to what we are seeking to achieve, provided we can sort out one small problem associated with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will look forward to that amendment. If the government is now accepting the principle that there will be an as yet undefined number of low and middle income earners who are going to be paying the surcharge because of non‐provision of tax file numbers, why on earth wasn't the legislation drafted in the first place to exclude those people? Senator Kemp, what you have been saying month after month is, `It'll be all right. We're only going to tax the higher income earners—those earning more than $70,000.' Now you are admitting that that undefined number—and it will be very significant, in our view—would have had to have paid the surcharge, or the tax, if we had not acted in this chamber to force these amendments on you. That is what you are now admitting, Senator Kemp. It is a pity that the government did not listen to some commonsense about this problem when it started the process.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to remind the committee that the great problem with all of this is that we have to go through what are extremely complex and convoluted amendments because the government would not call this a tax in the first place. It insisted on calling it a surcharge to avoid the accusation that it broke its election promise. So the government calls it a surcharge and gets the superannuation funds to collect it rather than collect it directly as a tax, as should have occurred in the first place. That is the fundamental reason why the government has had enormous problems with this over the last seven months since budget night.

What is incredible is that millions of people will have to be alerted to the tax file number problem. This will be at enormous cost to the tax office and to the funds. It is going to cost millions of dollars to collect tax file numbers and information that we do not want from 90 per cent of people—we do not want the information but we are going to collect it just the same. And now the government is finally conceding that, having collected this information as best we can, because you will not get it from everyone, we are not going to bother to collect the tax that we were going to hit them with in the first place. I have never seen such a shambles of a tax collection method in my six years in the Senate.

Senator Kemp, all these problems could have been averted if you had been honest and up‐front. If the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) had said, `This is a tax,' and taxed people directly rather than indirectly through the funds and not tried to hide it, it would have saved a lot of difficulty and angst on this particular measure seven months ago.

I will have to look at the wording of the Democrat amendment, because I want to make sure, on behalf of the Labor Party, that it is effectively going to exempt from this tax everyone in receipt of below or around about average weekly earnings. We want to make damned sure that that is the case. As I said, we do not want one cent collected from low and middle income earners, because all the evidence on the government's current construction of these bills to date has been that there would have been at least a million subject to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, rubbish!

—You can say `rubbish', Senator Kemp, but tell the committee of any person outside the government who can refute the evidence that came before the Senate committee, and our claim is based on that evidence. Tell me one superannuation fund, Senator Kemp, that has come to you and said that there will not be hundreds of thousands of low and middle income earners caught by the process that you are imposing on the funds. Tell me one fund that says it will not happen, Senator Kemp. You cannot. All you can say is, `Rubbish; we don't want to collect the money and we hope that everyone provides their tax file numbers.' That is all you can say. But the evidence is overwhelmingly against what you say.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased at this very late hour that you are finally conceding there is a problem of a yet undefined size—but there is a problem—and you are accepting this principle, which I hope is included in the amendment, that you are not going to collect 1c from people who earn less than average weekly earnings. That is the sort of provision which should have been in the bills in the first place.

If only the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, knew a little more about superannuation and the Treasurer, Mr Costello, had not been so damn arrogant about this issue from budget night. He has been so arrogant. His approach to this package of bills has been, `We will accept no change. We will consult in name. We will pretend to consult, but we will ignore the fundamental problems of this legislation.' He has ignored all the criticism, ignored all the positive suggestions and just barged on regardless. His attitude has been, `If hundreds of thousands of lower and middle income earners in this country have got to pay tax who should not pay tax, let's just proceed. Let's just push these bills through the Senate.'

Here we have it at 9 o'clock and the government is finally accepting that there is a problem. It is finally accepting the principal argument of not just Labor but the Greens, Senator Harradine and the Democrats that this issue has got to be solved so we can give some assurance to the lower and middle income earners, many of whom would have been slugged by this new surcharge.

I will just conclude my comments by saying that, despite this acceptance in principle by the government of this inevitable amendment that has been forced on it tonight to exclude lower and middle income earners, there is still enormous complexity. The irony is that we have to add complexity to complexity in order to delete lower and middle income earners and ensure they are not taxed by this new surcharge. That is the irony. The convoluted way the government is attempting to collect this revenue—by denying it is a tax and by getting the funds to do it—has led us to this enormously complex and difficult situation tonight, with an enormously complex, unwieldy and extraordinarily costly administration mechanism. Again, all the evidence is there.

Senator Kemp, you cannot tell the Senate of one fund that believes the extra administrative cost to all the superannuation funds in the country to collect information—whether the cost is $10 million, $20 million or $100 million; there are a variety of claims, but I will accept the average of $40 million to $50 million—will not be borne by the eight million members when, in many of those funds, a very small proportion of the members earn more than $70,000. Unfortunately, this enormous administrative cost is still going to be passed on to all the members in the fund. It may be only 20c or 30c a week, but it is still a cost that erodes their long-term retirement benefit. It is an extraordinarily high cost of collection for half a billion dollars in revenue if we take those factors into account.

I hope I have spoken long enough and, in the interim, the Democrat amendment has been circulated. I am just trying to assist the government by making sure we can get the amendment around. Is it ready to go?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I make some comments. Senator Sherry, you did not need to labour the point for 10 minutes and go over a speech which I have heard 100 times from you. We have indicated on innumerable occasions that the superannuation surcharge applies to high income earners, not to low and middle income earners.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a suggestion—and I feel there was a hint of this earlier in the night from you, Senator Sherry—that people who really want to sink the superannuation surcharge decided they would hide behind the argument, which is not well‐based, that this was going to impact on some low and middle income earners. Many groups in the community have a vested interest in seeing this superannuation surcharge on high income earners defeated and tossed aside. Senator Sherry has indicated that somehow it is a costly and expensive way to collect it. Let me tell you that it is a damn sight cheaper than the option you were proposing.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it's not; give us your costings.

—Yes, it was. Your option, Senator Sherry, as far as I am aware—and you did fluctuate a little on this—was going to involve not only up to one million employers and probably 10 million taxpayers but also the superannuation funds. So for you to get up and attempt to lecture people on this, I have to say, is a complete nonsense and we simply do not accept it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry, you have been a focal point. You have been prepared to retail every unsubstantiated argument which has been put to you and then throw your hands in the air and say, `What confusion entails.'

TALK.START.PARA: —It's all my fault, is it?
—No. You have acted in an irresponsible fashion because you have been prepared to pick up every extravagant figure and every wild claim—
—No I haven't, actually.
