—and retail them. We know you are under great pressure to toss this superannuation surcharge bill aside. We may yet save you from the flak the Labor Party will have to wear if this important bill is defeated.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have been doing in the chamber tonight is looking at where we can get common ground and looking at which issues that have been raised senators may need some assurance on. It is our intention, and it has been from day one, that low and middle income earners will not be hit by the surcharge. That is why we have put all these procedures in place which I have detailed to you.

We had discussions earlier in the evening with Senator Allison. It appeared as though there was an option coming forward which we felt we could accept and which would provide a degree of comfort to those who did not accept that all the procedures we had put in place were going to be effective in achieving their goal.

But there is still work being done on this amendment I understand. So it would be my view, with the concurrence of the chamber, that until we can get an agreed amendment before the chair it probably makes sense for us to move on. But we are always happy to cooperate. What we want to do is get an amendment which addresses the real concerns of people—an amendment that does not involve administrative complexity, does not open up new loopholes for people, but does provide a degree of assurance that some senators wish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a quick question of the minister. I wonder how many people around Australia are actually in a situation where they may not have consolidated their superannuation. They may actually still belong to several schemes to which they have paid in the past. Some of those schemes might not have their current address. The schemes might be sending to an address which they think will enable them to contact the person who is or was contributing to a superannuation scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: Can the minister advise me what will happen in those instances where there are no means of communication. One would have to assume there are people who have forgotten about the superannuation schemes to which they have contributed. This would apply to people who have been involved in short‐term work—to people who have worked on a temporary basis for government or for a university. You can name any number of combinations which apply to people who may have had small or medium accounts which they have not amalgamated. What will happen to people with a range of superannuation accounts who only advise in respect of one group and do not advise in respect of their smaller accounts?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The ATO will take every reasonable step it possibly can to contact people. As I have mentioned, a range of procedures are in place. There are accounts which are untraceable. They are probably unused accounts. They may not have been used for a number of years and moneys are not being paid into them. There are some 16 million accounts in total and about nine million people are paying into accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, one of the reasons why the superannuation funds are collecting tax file numbers right at this very moment is to assist in the amalgamation of accounts. You would have perhaps missed from Senator Sherry's rather histrionic performance that in fact superannuation funds right now are collecting tax file numbers. Superannuation funds have wanted tax file numbers for a considerable period of time for administrative reasons and, of course, to assist in the accumulation of accounts. In listening to Senator Sherry's comments, most listeners might have actually missed that rather important fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a quick question which I hope will have a quick response. Could the minister advise the chamber how much money would have been saved had the surcharge been imposed as a tax and collected in that particu lar manner? Has consideration been given to that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, there are many varieties of tax and the option that seemed to receive some support was the one that would involve group certificates, would involve some one million employers, would involve some 10 million taxpayers with their group certificates, and would actually still involve the funds, who would have to also provide details to the tax office for compliance reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: It is our conclusion that we chose the best option. It was not one that was favoured by the superannuation funds, that is true, but we were not prepared to impose additional red tape on small business in particular. The superannuation funds that administer superannuation have the systems largely in place and they are collecting tax file numbers. We believe that the system we put in place was the most efficient of the options which were available to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, you, Senator Kemp, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) continue to assert what I consider to be totally untrue. Every expert—I am talking about the society of accountants, the institute of actuaries, lawyers and every superannuation fund that I have spoken to, or has spoken to me—says that what you say, Senator Kemp, is untrue; that what the Prime Minister says is untrue; that what Mr Costello says is untrue; and what a lot of members of your own party know is untrue. We know from the public statements members of your own party have been making that it is untrue.

SPEECH.PARA: You set out to avoid calling a tax a tax. You set out to try to hide it as much as possible through the superannuation industry and get them to become effectively de facto tax officers for you. That is the reason why you did it—to hide it and to avoid calling a tax a tax. No‐one believes you, Senator Kemp. A poll taken today of the attitude of businessmen to this superannuation surcharge resulted in 83 per cent of them saying that it is a tax—your own people; your own constituency.

Still you persist in the misleading nonsense—you, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer—on this position about the collection mechanism and that it is a surcharge and not a tax. No‐one believes you and you look sillier every day by continuing to assert that, Senator Kemp. Not one single industry person believes you. Not one single industry person on the record accepts your miserable excuse for imposing this new tax on higher income earners and a lot of other lower and middle income earners who would have been caught but for the actions of the opposition senators, the Greens, the Democrats and Senator Harradine.

You can continue to go on with your misleading assertions, Senator Kemp. We are confident that what we say is correct. I challenge Senator Kemp to give me the name of one superannuation fund that believes this is not going to impose very costly administration. Senator Kemp, give the Senate the name of one person out there in the commercial world who has an understanding of superannuation—and there are many thousands of them—who believes that what you are doing is right. Give us the name, Senator Kemp. You know you cannot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can. Kim Beazley supports the 15 per cent surcharge—yes, he does. The Labor Party, before the histrionics today, strongly supported the surcharge on high income earners. I could produce some quotes which would show that your leader supported that. You asked for a name and I gave you a name. It is not surprising that high income earners do not support with any enthusiasm the superannuation surcharge. I mean, gee whiz! That is hardly surprising. What is important for public policy reasons is whether the surcharge is an initiative which, at least up until today, Senator Sherry, when you started to backslide, was designed to ensure greater equity in the tax concessions which are available to high income earners and those available to low income earners. So raising your voice, indulging in histrionics and making wild claims, frankly, is absurd when you think that the Labor Party, at least up to this point of time, supported the superannuation surcharge on high income earners.

SPEECH.PARA: I know a lot of your colleagues do not like it and I know a lot of the interest groups around you do not like it, Senator. I know that there is an idea: how can we slide away from this policy? And, of course, what we pretend is to raise fear that low and middle income earners will be hit. That is the strategy, Senator Sherry. We can see through it.
You asked for a name of who supported it. I gave you a name—Kim Beazley. I wonder whether he still supports it today or whether you are just running loose. It would be interesting to find out.
I seek advice from the Democrats about their amendments. Senator Allison, in order to move this debate forward, we have a couple of amendments from you. Is one of those ready to go?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have one here which is hand amended. I am not sure whether that is an appropriate form in which to be put at this stage.
—Why don't we get that typed out and we will move on to the next item.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record and putting aside the ongoing shambles of the surcharge bills, the legal problems, the problems you have still got today, Senator Kemp, with the states—you still cannot tell us of any state that is going to enact this surcharge—we were faced with the problem that, up until tonight, the government has steadfastly refused to have a provision in this legislation to exempt low and middle income earners from the collection of this new tax. We believe it would have been many thousands, if not a million.

SPEECH.PARA: We had until tonight a government saying that they would not accept the removal of a number of payments where redundancy occurs and I am pleased to see, Senator Kemp, that you are accepting those two fundamental principles tonight with the amendments that are being drafted. Subject to us looking at the exact wording of those particular amendments, we will be pleased to support the third reading of this legislation, Senator Kemp. It has taken the Labor Party to force you to that position tonight on those two fundamental principles. I will be pleased if the two amendments that are being prepared at the moment do effectively what the Labor Party has been demanding for some seven months and that you have steadfastly refused to accept any amendment up until tonight.

That is the reason why we have had to threaten you that we will not support this legislation on the third reading until you back down on taxing low and middle income earners and a large part of what would have been payments on their redundancy. That is the fact of the matter, Senator Kemp. You are accepting amendments in principle on those two critical issues to Labor. As I said earlier today, we deal with those two matters and we will be pleased to support a tax on higher income earners, which is what you stated you were doing in the budget.

There are a range of other amendments that we have concerns about that we would like to have seen passed. I hope some of them still will be. It is those two fundamental principles that we have had to fight you on right up until tonight to get any satisfactory, any acknowledgment from the Treasurer, Mr Costello, who arrogantly has continued to assert, and you on his behalf, that there are no problems with this legislation. `There's no problems. We won't tax lower and middle income earners. We don't want to tax redundancy pay. We won't catch them.' Why accept these amendments tonight, Senator Kemp, which you are going to do. The reality is, you know you have to because you have not dealt with those issues to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not accepting your amendments—let's get that absolutely clear—your hopelessly and carelessly drafted amendments which you deliberately refused to show us until the last moment. So get this absolutely clear: we are not accepting your amendments, Senator Sherry. I have pointed out to you some of the absurdities in the amendments that you have put forward.

BREAK.PARA: The Democrats have been prepared to talk in a constructive manner and look at some of the issues which they have had some concerns about. We have to see the final amendments, I have to say, but, assuming that the amendments are ones which we think reflect our earlier discussions, we will be happy to accede to them. As I said, we wait anxiously for the final wording.

Senator Sherry, we as always are being constructive; you, I might say, in this whole debate have been destructive. We do not give any credit to your work. I think your general performance has been pretty ordinary throughout this debate. The fact is that after five weeks you dumped the amendments on us some minutes before the debate. Talk about a shambles.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have had the bulk of them for five weeks.

—Yes, we got the other ones at half past eight with the debate starting at a quarter to nine? Boy! We got your first lot with a couple of minutes to go before the debate started and we got your second lot in a similar manner. Talk about shambles; talk about poor planning. I would have to say, Senator Sherry, that you must take the cake. For you to stand up and attempt to lecture others really is a little bit rich. Your intention all along, of course, was to try to get the Labor Party off the hook so this bill would be defeated. That was your intention. All the pressure groups around you were determined to try to prevent the superannuation surcharge coming in.
—But we've saved him.

—I think we have saved you from yourself, Senator Sherry. I do not expect any thanks from you, but you were engaged in as transparent a political exercise as I have seen for some time. The Democrats have been prepared to discuss some of these issues in a constructive manner and, as these amendments come through, we will have a look at them to see how we are proceeding.
—May I first of all say that it would be very helpful if honourable senators directed their comments though the chair rather than to each other across the chamber in a personal manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of points. It is interesting that every time we enter into a new debate about a new amendment the same outrageous accusations come forth from Senator Kemp that in some way the Labor Party have drafted poor amendments, when what we have seen from the government in this legislation is a case of not just policy on the hop but basically drafting of this legislation in the chamber and amendment by media. The whole passage and process of the development of this piece of flawed legislation have been fraught with mistake after mistake, and Senator Kemp must carry the responsibility of that, being the minister who has carriage of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it quite offensive that he continually stands up and just denies fact. And he used Mr Beazley, after a direct challenge from Senator Sherry to name somebody in the industry that has any support for this piece of legislation. It just shows the absolute lack of depth and support that Senator Kemp has when he has to rely on flippant comments with respect to the Leader of the Opposition to prove his point.

I think it is a reflection of the depth of the contribution of the minister to the debate on the amendments to this legislation that he continually relies on flippant and sarcastic comments about the issues at hand rather than on substance and on responding to specific questions asked by members of the opposition.

Minister, perhaps I can just conclude by asking another question in relation to the high income earners that you claim are primarily going to be the ones paying this surcharge. What sorts of studies or surveys, canvassing or data collection has the government done to ascertain the retention rate of high income earners in superannuation schemes after the implementation of this legislation in its current form? And what sort of results have you got from any such study?

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask you to direct your questions through the chair, Senator Lundy.
—Through the chair, I put the question to the minister: could he provide details to the Senate with respect to those matters I have just raised?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lundy, I do not know why you always feel when you have to speak—
—Senator, I ask you to direct your comments through the chair as well.

—Thank you, Madam Chair. I certainly will direct them through you. I am always at a loss when Senator Lundy stands up—and I have noticed it in relation to virtually every other minister who stands up here and makes a comment—and relentlessly responds by saying questions have not been answered. It is as though that is a stock phrase which is rolled out, which I think, Senator Lundy, sometimes means that you have not listened to the answer or you are not prepared to acknowledge that an answer has been given to you.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me see the position you are at now. It looks as though, from Senator Sherry's comments, the Labor Party is supporting this. Provided we can sort out this couple of amendments, it looks as though the Labor Party will be supporting the superannuation surcharge on high income earners. We finally got Senator Sherry from half past eleven this morning, when he was not going to do it, to this evening when he was. You adopt a totally negative—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp, I ask you to please make your comments through the chair. This is becoming a bit like a football match with people just screaming across the chamber.

—I apologise, Madam Chair. You get no hint at all from Senator Lundy's comments that the Labor Party, as of this time of night, has apparently come around to supporting it. Senator, the reason why I think in the end this will go through this Senate—I hope it will go through—is that it is a fair and equitable scheme. You have not grasped that issue. You have not grasped what the basic debate has been about. That has been the problem. You stand up and ask what studies have been done in relation to, I think you said, drop‐outs from superannuation. About three hours ago I said that all the indications were that money was flowing strongly into superannuation.
—Oh, you're not going to mislead us with that rubbish again, are you?
—Only statistically speaking, money is flowing strongly into superannuation.
—That's not the question.

—I quoted the article in the BRW for you on 28 April which shows that superannuation, even for high income earners, is still a very advantageous and attractive option. All the scare tactics which people have attempted to drum up clearly have not had, at this stage, any significant effect, if you can judge from those two sets of statistics I have quoted. There is also the fact that accountants and others are working out that superannuation is still a very attractive option. That is why, Senator, the superannuation industry will continue to grow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to foreshadow the amendments the Australian Democrats will put—soon to be circulated, I understand—and to indicate that we will not be voting with the ALP's amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, in the current act, we have excluded from the definition of income the first $4,300 of any relevant benefit plus $2,200 for each year of service. I will be seeking assurance from the minister that insurance pay-outs are excluded. We will now seek to exclude ETPs paid by superannuation funds. We will exclude unused leave in situations of bona fide redundancy or invalidity. We believe that that will provide a fair level of protection for retrenched and invalided workers. It excludes the potential for golden handshakes, which we think do exist in the ALP amendments. This is why we have taken the trouble to draft these amendments at this very late stage. I foreshadow what we intend to do after this vote.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I ask where unused leave, long service leave and annual leave are included in the document circulated? It is handwritten, but could you tell us which section it is included in?
—I may be able to assist you, Senator, although it is not my amendment. One of my advisers was kind enough to point out to me that it is included under 26AC and 26AD.
—Could I also ask where the retention bonuses to the military are included in this particular amendment?
—No, Senator, I think I pointed out to you that we are not supporting that.
—Why do you want to include retention bonuses paid to military personnel as part of the taxable income for surcharge purposes? Why?
—Perhaps I could answer that question. We believe such payments to be part of taxable income and therefore should qualify for this superannuation tax.
—It is part of assessable income. I think that is the reason why we do not believe it should be excluded.
—I seek clarification with respect to a disability benefit payable. Would that be liable under this amendment?
—My understanding is that invalidity is covered by the amendment that has been put. Perhaps the minister could add to that with reference to his adviser.
—Yes, I am looking at my adviser too. Your adviser and my adviser seem to agree again on this one. I notice the nodding all around. The invalidity is included in the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to leave, it is my understanding that it is long service leave and annual leave with respect to a bona fide redundancy. What about a person who retires and has a long service leave and annual leave pay-out? Is that still included in taxable income in the year they retire?
—As I understand it, yes, that is the case.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like an explanation. Is that reasonable from both the Australian Democrats and the government? Long service leave and annual leave are statutory payments. They are clearly defined. You cannot rort it. You cannot make up annual leave and long service leave. There are specific long service leave acts; there are specific annual leave agreements in industrial awards and industrial agreements. Why should people who have those sums of money when they retire have them included in taxable income? It seems to me to be fundamentally inequitable that it should be included as part of taxable income on retirement.
—The previous government included them in taxable income in 1993.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad you reminded us that they are included in taxable income. What you are now doing is putting a tax on a tax. They are included in taxable income, okay. You tax them. We accept as fact that that is what happens. For surcharge purposes, that amount of money is then included as part of taxable income on retirement. So, in effect, the money paid for long service leave and annual leave, which they have been taxed on already on retirement, will boost their income in that year. For some people, it will lift their taxable income and they will be surcharged on it. Why should that happen?

—Senator, they are included in the threshold just in order to work out the assessable income. That is why they are included: to see whether they go over the limit. We are following a precedent that the Labor Party established. The Labor Party said they were part of assessable income in 1993, and we are saying they are part of assessable income now. There is no change. We are following a precedent which was established by your own party.

—My understanding is that—and I think this is what Senator Sherry is indicating—it will be a problem not just for that immediate amount of money; it will end up being a surcharge on all their superannuation rather than on just a particular payment. So you end up having a particular payment which means that a person is lumped with a surcharge on a superannuation fund which fairly well exceeds the reality of what their income was.

—No, Senator. It works out the assessable income to see whether they cross the threshold or not. That is what it does. The surcharge is not applied on that. It is applied on the contributions. As the previous government said it was part of assessable income, so we are saying it is part of assessable income. Senator Sherry said it was a tax on a tax; he has probably reversed that position. It is complex. We understand. But I hope that gives you the assurance you were seeking, Senator.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, if you have $5,000 worth of leave—whether it is long service leave or annual leave—there is a tax paid on that. Whatever that figure is, it is taken out. That component of income—that $5,000—then lifts your income for taxable purposes. If it lifts your income to $75,000, your superannuation for that year is taxed at five per cent of $75,000. So the inclusion of long service leave and annual leave, having been taxed—no complaint about that—can also boost your assessable income for the purposes of surcharge on superannuation payments made in that year. We claim it is a double tax, and we do not support it. It is two taxes.

—I have a specific question to ask about the way in which funds are supposed to distinguish between the contributions paid out in ETPs, any liability for the tax and confusion that may come about if they are determined, firstly, as super contributions and, secondly, as taxable income. How does the government believe this should be managed with respect to the funds being able to make those distinctions? It is a question of process, about how you, as government, perceive the funds managing this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I am not trying to be obtuse, but would you mind repeating that. I know the hour is late. I did not quite understand it and then I looked over at my advisers, and they did not appear to understand it either. It is no reflection on you, but it may assist us if you could repeat the question. Were you wondering about the difference between assessable income for the purposes of gathering the threshold and the contributions on which the surcharge is paid?

SPEECH.PARA: The funds know the individual, his contributions and his tax file number and they send that to the tax office. The tax office then knows the assessable income. The tax office then does the work to assess whether a surcharge is payable. If the surcharge is payable, the debit is sent back to the fund. That is the process. It is not a complicated process, although you would not believe it if you read all the press and listened to Senator Sherry. I can understand why people would be worried. But they should not be, to correct the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the question was directed towards that distinction in relation to the assessable tax income and the part over the threshold that needs to be assessed. So, yes, in describing how that is actually managed, you have gone some way to responding to the question. You say it is a simple process, but the point has been made that it does require several communications between the fund and the tax office to progress it, adding multiple layers of administration that would have been avoided if you had called this tax a tax in the first place.

—I would like to make some comments about the remarks Senator Sherry made and to explain that what we have sought to do is protect workers who have been retrenched or invalided. Other employees have more choice in determining the timing of their retirement and are, therefore, able to manage their retirement packages and their exit accordingly. I do not think it is reasonable to argue that we are talking here about a double tax. It is not that. It is a tax on a superannuation contribution. It is important to make that distinction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just indicate that we do not accept the logic of the Democrats on this issue in respect of long service leave and annual leave on retirement. We think it is unreasonable. We believe that there are far too many circumstances where ETPs in respect of redundancy will be included in taxable income, and we do not believe that is satisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: Some people might consider it a pretty esoteric issue. We certainly do not regard the concerns of military personnel as esoteric, particularly given the widespread redundancies that they face—and there is a whole range of other superannuation problems they face that is not the subject of debate tonight. We do not believe that retention bonuses in the military should be included.

For those reasons, even though there is some shift—it is a major shift; it is a quantum leap shift compared to where the government was eight or nine months ago—it does not satisfy all of our concerns so we will still be supporting our amendment and the suggested Green change. We will not be supporting this Democrat‐government compromise.
Amendment (Senator Margetts's) negatived.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.
Noes 38

TAB.TAB: Majority 14

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: (Senator Conroy did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 43, page 44 (lines 6 to 13), omit the definition of adjusted taxable income , substitute:
adjusted taxable income of a member for a financial year means the sum of:
(a) the member's taxable income of the year of income comprising the financial year less any amounts included in the member's assessable income of that year of income:

PARA.TAB: (i) that were eligible termination payments for the purposes of Subdivision AA of Division 2 of Part III of the Income Tax Assessment Act (other than amounts that were such payments because of paragraph (a) of the definition of eligible termination payment in subsection 27A(1) of that Act);

(ii) that were so included under section 26AC or under subsection 26AD(2),(3) or (4), in respect of a bona fide redundancy amount, an early retirement scheme amount or an invalidity amount as defined in section 1595 of the Income Tax Assessment Act; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) the member's surchargeable contributions for the financial year.
I have already foreshadowed this amendment and indicated the reasons why we are supporting it, so I will not repeat those arguments here. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the written amendment that I have at the moment. Do we know how far away it is from being typed?
—The suggestion is that it will not be typed at this moment.

—We insisted on our amendments being put. We do not believe that the Democrats have covered enough of the concerns that the Labor Party sought to address. I note that is also the case with the Green senators and Senator Harradine. We are disappointed in the Democrats continued watering‐down of our particular approach, but we will not be calling a division on the matter in view of the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to make a fuss about this, but I do think it is helpful if people in the chamber know what they are voting on. I know that we are members of a party—and we are good, loyal members—but if we look at the chamber as a parliamentary institution, it would be helpful if we all knew what was going on. I know that Senator Harradine often talks about this, and it is right.

SPEECH.PARA: We have got an amendment which is handwritten. I am not sure what the arrow in the amendment refers to. A (ii) appears; I cannot see a (i) which should precede it. The words `that were so included' have a circle around them, and I am not sure what that attaches to. The amendment says:
under section 26AC or under subsection 26AD(2), (3) or (4), in respect of a bona fide redundancy amount,—
A bona fide redundancy amount is not, as I see it, defined. It may be. What a court would make of the expression `bona fide redundancy amount' seems to me not to be clear. It goes on:
an early retirement scheme amount or an invalidity amount—
No doubt there may be in the bill itself a definition section which talks about that. It goes on:
as defined in section 1595 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.
I do not know whether we have the ability to get to section 1595 of the income tax act or whether that has been referred to before.

Senator Allison has worked hard on this bill and has made a great contribution to it, but she has written it out and has put it before the Senate in a way that I do not think is comprehensible, and it is in a drafting form which does not seem to be the sort of thing that Hilary Penfold would present. It seems to me that we are rushing this amendment through which involves a very important matter. It is quite clear from the debate that has gone on today that it is important and is central to the issue. I have to go out and face my constituency, particularly those in the trade union movement. I see Senator Carr here—he will have to do the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Senator Murphy.
—That is right. It is not only those but anybody.
—The armed forces.

—In all seriousness, we could start expanding on those. They will ask, `What was your understanding of this when it was put before you, and what questions did you ask? What did you, Senator Harradine or Senator Evans, take "bona fide redundancy amount" to mean? When you voted on this, had you looked at section 1595 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and did you think that that was an appropriate definition to adopt in this amendment?' It seems to me that we all would have to answer, `No, we do not know any of those things, but we relied upon the minister.' He is no doubt a man of outstanding integrity, but is he a good reader of the law? That is the big issue.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a very erudite and learned group of advisers over there. When we go to court, are they going to come along and give evidence? If they do, the judge will say that it is irrelevant because it is not what they think that is the point; how the legislation reads is what really counts for this.

I feel that if we were making a will or making a contract using these terms, and if it did not turn out how it ought to, we would all be sued for negligence and that action would be successful. We as legislators ought to show as much responsibility to the people out there who we are supposed to represent as a solicitor would show in drawing up a contract. That is not being done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Allison, you might just make clear the proposal that you have before the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Anything to assist Senator Cooney in his pursuit of the truth. I will explain how the handwritten element of this amendment works. Take subclause (a), the third line and the first word of the third line—`income'. What is intended is that the words after the word `income' will form (i), that is, subclause A(i), which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that were eligible termination payments for the purposes of Subdivision AA of Division 2 . . .

Then, after the last line of A(i), which finishes with `in subsection 27(A)(1) of that act; and', the arrow indicates where (ii) is to be inserted. It begins with the words `that were so included under section 26AC or under subsection 26AD(2), (3) or (4)' et cetera. That forms subclause (ii) of A. Then the amendment goes on to (b), which says `the member's surchargable contributions for the financial year'. I apologise for the fact that this is not typed up. I am sure that if I had my laptop here, I would have been able to do it. Senator Cooney, I am sure that once Hansard comes out you will be able to read it and distribute it to those people you need to make the explanations to.

If it is of use, 26AC is unused annual leave and 26AD is unused long service leave. Bona fide redundancy amount is early retirement scheme amount and invalidity amount, et cetera, and it is all defined in section 1595 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. As I indicated earlier when I foreshadowed these amendments, what they do is pick up two of the three important safeguards that we think need to be within this act. One is to ensure that redundancy payments are excluded from the assessment income for the purposes of—

TALK.START.PARA: —My advisers have drawn a matter to my attention. For the sake of the record, it is 159S, not 1595 which I think is what was said. I have very sharp advisers here who picked that up.

—The second aspect of the amendment is to see that unused leave for those who have been declared redundant or are out due to invalidity is also exempt from the purposes of surcharge application. That is the basis of these two amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to be pedantic, but could Senator Allison acknowledge for the record that it is 159S? It is her amendment. I do not take exception to Senator Kemp pointing out the particular problem. It is obvious that the government has been in full retreat with drafting this. I think that if ever there was any test in the court, the person who is moving it should acknowledge that it is 159S.
—I am happy to acknowledge that it is 159S. That is a difficulty that arises when working from handwritten amendments rather than typed ones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Allison, I have been listening to this debate and have been looking at what you have proposed in your amendment with regard to bona fide redundancy amount or early retirement scheme. I thought I heard you say earlier that this amendment was not only designed to avoid the golden handshake deals but more designed to accommodate retrenchment arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: When redundancies are offered within a business and some people nearing retirement age choose, for a number of reasons, to take those redundancies by way of early retirement, are you saying that they are picked up under this amendment? Is that covered by a bona fide redundancy amount or is it covered by the early retirement scheme, even if it is not specifically called that? There are some instances where people may choose—and quite often it is because they are of an age where it is suitable for them to do so—to take a redundancy package offered by a company when it is not making particular jobs redundant. That is an important point of clarification because that is not what I understood you to say earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my understanding that it is the case that this would be picked up and that that was defined in a Labor Party act. The minister may be able to shed further light on that, but that is my understanding of these amendments.
—I would like to hear the minister's view with regard to people taking voluntary redundancies.

—You will be pleased to know that I anticipated that you would do that, Senator. I will check with my advisers to see whether I can add anything. We do not give quick legal opinions in the chamber. This is not a legal opinion, but is designed to give you a bit of the flavour. It depends on the circumstances of the case. Clearly, the circumstances of the case are very important. The situation outlined could be a bona fide redundancy case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I find that somewhat unacceptable, because you say that you are not in the practice of giving legal opinions in the chamber. I am sure a lot of people who work for companies that are offering redundancy programs which are voluntary in nature in the first instance and who are between 45 and 55 or 60 may well choose, whether for financial benefit or another reason, to take a redundancy when in fact the job that they are currently doing is not actually going to become redundant.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this is a very important clarification that needs to be made. Either all redundancies are covered or `bona fide' has to be clarified. If a person who works for an employer who offers a redundancy program, whether voluntary or otherwise—that is, where a group of people across a section of a work force may take it, or in the case where a specific job is being made redundant for whatever reason—takes a redundancy then we need to clarify this situation for them. It has sometimes been in the past a bone of contention. This matter does need clarification. I think you ought to be able to commit one way or another whether people choosing to take a voluntary redundancy offer from a company or an employer are covered by this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —This does not alter the issue in relation to redundancy and voluntary redundancy. That is defined under the Income Tax Assessment Act. This bill does not alter those issues, which are interesting and important, which you are raising. Those issues are defined through the Income Tax Assessment Act. What we have done here tonight does not alter the assessments which would be given as a result of that act. Whether it is a voluntary redundancy or a voluntary retirement or bona fide redundancy does not matter because these matters are in a different act. This bill just shows how they would be applied in particular circumstances. We are not in this bill altering the definitions which I understand apply in those areas.

—This amendment states that the adjustable taxable income of a member for a financial year means the sum of what is outlined in (a). How does (i) flow on to (ii)? Should there be an `and' or an `or' in there? What does the expression `so included' mean? Where is it included? It is included under section 26AC, but what do you mean by `so included'? What does the word `so' refer to? Should you not have some sort of conjunction between (i) and (ii)? How do you make sense of it?

—As I understand it, `so included' means included in the assessable income. I am sorry you were not here earlier, Senator, because there was a great deal of drafting going on in the chamber and we could have used your skills. Senator Murphy was looking at the issue of whether it is a voluntary retirement or bona fide redundancy. I have a bit of information on that.

—Do not confuse the two things—that is, voluntary early retirement and bona fide redundancy. In the case of redundancy per se it is a clarification of what is bona fide. I understood Senator Allison to say earlier—I may have misunderstood her—that if a person was in a position where a company offered a redundancy program across its entire work force and certain people took it on the basis of their age—if they were, say, 55 or 60—and the financial benefit, but yet their job, the specific task they performed, was not being made redundant, it could be argued that that is not a bona fide redundancy. All I am asking you to say is, `No, bona fide redundancy would cover those circumstances.' That is the point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —These issues are not issues for this bill. These issues are defined, as I understand it, in the Income Tax Assessment Act. So this bill is just looking at, for example, bona fide redundancy payments. Those issues and the way they are defined are determined in another bill which is not really the substance of debate here this evening and they are not issues which are altered by this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are saying is that there are certain payments which may be affected as a result of a redundancy. But, as I understand it, we are not seeking to change the definitions which currently exist. Bona fide redundancy is a concept that has been in the law since 1983. It was introduced by the then Labor government. Perhaps a number of other examples may assist.

BREAK.PARA: If a job is not made redundant and a member voluntarily leaves, that will not be a bona fide redundancy I am advised. It may be an early retirement amount if conditions of an approved early retirement scheme were satisfied. If the employer needs to have a reorganisation of some sort it must identify a class of employees who qualify for the scheme. The class could be all employees.

What we are doing here is tackling some issues which were raised in relation to eligible termination payments. We did not accept the approach the Labor Party had on this. We listened carefully to the arguments but did not accept their approach. The Democrats had some different priorities. We were prepared to give some support to those priorities. Senator, we are not changing those issues which I think are worrying you—the nature of a bona fide redundancy payment. That is not what we are seeking to define in this act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —It is our intention that voluntary redundancies would be covered by this amendment. I think if there is some doubt about that perhaps there needs to be some time, given the haste with which this was dealt with, for us to look at that. I certainly would be comfortable with being more certain. It has been drawn to my attention that the wording of section 2 under A needs to be adjusted slightly. It should now read:

SPEECH.PARA: (ii) under section 26AC or under subsection 26AD(2), (3) or (4) of the Income Tax Assessment Act in respect of a bona fide redundancy amount, an early retirement scheme amount or an invalidity amount as defined in section 159S of that act;
As I understand it, this amendment is being typed for circulation. I seek leave to amend my amendment.
Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just two points while I think of it on this particular issue, could Senator Kemp outline to us how will employees who have lost their employment since August 20 last year be treated within the terms of this particular provision? I can envisage a number of employees who have been retrenched unfortu nately over the last eight months who may have either spent the money that they have received or entered into a long-term commitment in respect of the money they have received. How is the tax office going to treat these individuals? Are they going to chase them up and obtain the revenue or will the tax office deal sympathetically with those individuals who may have a problem in paying the money once this legislation is passed?

—The tax office always seeks to apply sensible collection approaches. Without having particular examples on hand it is a bit hard to discuss. I do not know whether there is anything more I can add. I think the point is that the tax office deals in a sympathetic manner with these cases.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us assume a worker has lost their job in the last seven or eight months. I have to say that I have not had too many people coming to me saying, `The tax office treated me sympathetically.'
—They can be given extensions of time.

—We have had many thousands of workers made redundant in the last seven or eight months since the budget announcement on 20 August. Those people may have locked in or spent, a combination of both, their superannuation moneys and they may not have the resources to pay the assessment.
—Would not even be aware of it.

—Or they would not be aware of it at the moment because we are dealing with the new tax announced on election night almost eight months after the event. How would you treat them sympathetically, Senator Kemp? What is the tax office definition of treating them sympathetically?

—One way of course is extensions of time. That always assists people. The ATO will use sensible collection methods. It deals with this sort of issue almost on a daily basis. If it is bona fide redundancy it is not included anyway. In a sense, to the extent that you perceived a problem I suspect these amendments assist. On advice the answer is: that is the case.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —They assist—not enough, in our view, but they do assist somewhat. Has the tax office had many inquiries about the effect of the surcharge over the past eight months from budget night until the passage of the legislation? Does it have any estimate of the number of people who will have to be treated sympathetically?

—Despite all your scare tactics and the shock, horrors which regularly form the substance of your press releases, the advice I have from the tax office is that they have had very few inquiries, actually. This probably demonstrates people's commonsense in ignoring what you are saying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will see, Senator Kemp. We are just starting to get inquiries about the deeming of superannuation at 55. We are certainly getting some inquiries about it, I can assure you. The legislation was passed last December, but that is another issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise one other point: you have rebutted our assertion that there has been a lessening of confidence in the superannuation system. You draw our attention to the increased superannuation moneys going into funds. On the face of it, what you say in respect of increased funds going into superannuation is correct. There has been a significant increase in moneys flowing into superannuation. But if you look at the increase in the total amount of money going into superannuation over the last year, it almost exactly correlates with the increase in the superannuation guarantee from five to six per cent. It almost exactly correlates to the nearest percentage—and that is compulsory, of course.

I do not believe you can claim that, because money flowing into superannuation has increased, confidence has not declined. We would submit all the anecdotal evidence we are receiving—including from my hairdresser, who said to me the other day that he does not earn $70,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's her name?

—He; he has been cutting my hair for 18 years. He does not earn $70,000. He said to me that his confidence in the superannuation system was seriously undermined. He was not going to continue to make contributions; he was going to pay off his mortgage instead. We have had plenty of anecdotal evidence that this is occurring, and we think it is very unfortunate. We take issue with you, Senator Kemp. We would argue that the increase in superannuation over the last year almost exactly relates to the increase in the superannuation guarantee contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the bona fide redundancy amount. The term `bona fide redundancy' has often been used in the Industrial Relations Commission where a person may well have claimed to have been unfairly dismissed. The arguments will have been put as to whether they were unfairly dismissed or whether they were made redundant. The term `bona fide' really relates to whether or not the position in which the person worked has been made redundant—that is, it no longer exists in that business or factory.

SPEECH.PARA: I urge the Democrats to consider this matter. I do not want to suggest any amendments to this stupid legislation, but with regard to redundancy, if you are going to look at any assessment of redundancy payments, it ought to be across the board. If a company has offered its employees redundancy, whether or not it is bona fide, they are offered. I do not think you should raise any question about whether a specific position is redundant and whether a person working in a specific position has actually taken a redundancy. If I understand what Senator Kemp has said, I do not think that would affect this legislation. I hold the view that it would be far better if the word `bona fide' were removed and it just stated `where redundancies are offered'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear your view. The contrary view is that `bona fide redundancy' is a defined term in the income tax law and has been there since 1983.
—It's also a defined term in bloody industrial relations law.

—It was put in by your government. You feel it should come out. I understand that; we note your views. This legislation is not seeking to change the income tax law in that sense. What we are seeking to do is look at ETPs and what is included in an ETP. You have raised an interesting debate, but I have to say it is not directly relevant to the debate that is before the chamber. Senator Sherry took me to task about whether confidence remained in superannuation.
—Gently.

—Gently took me to task to see whether confidence remained in superannuation. I am not the only person who has made this comment. I think some very extravagant comments have been made, to be quite frank. I think some people have not served their industry well by those comments.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not naming names. If the cap fits, wear it. But I will name your name. I do not think you have been much help. I do not mind naming Senator Sherry who, for what he perceived as short‐term political gain—I think he was wrong—was prepared to say almost anything.

SPEECH.PARA: But, Senator, I noted that there had been continued growth. I also note your comments that a lot would have come from SG—I understand that. I think the other thing which is interesting is the number of small funds which are being established.

TALK.START.PARA: —For other reasons.

—Well, for other reasons. But, as I said, there was a recent analysis which showed that superannuation is still a very attractive product. I noticed that a number of people who manage funds have been advertising very extensively in the press in the last week or so.
—That's because they are trying to hold the funds.

—Senator Sherry adopts a more negative approach but I think that a degree of analysis which has occurred really has shown that there is substantial appeal in superannuation. I hope, when this bill gets through, that there will be less extravagant comments and a greater willingness to recognise that superannuation is an important industry and that it is still a very attractive product—even to high income earners.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to make a phone call but my colleague Senator Campbell, who is totally across these issues, will take over for a brief moment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that is particularly satisfactory given the importance of this legislation. I want to go to the toilet and make a phone call and have a cigarette. Could I just check on the progress of the amendment that the Democrats were having drafted? Senator Campbell may not be aware that we are in the middle of drafting a very critical amendment in respect of exempting the collection from lower and middle income earners, which was being prepared by the Democrats.
—We will have to ask that question of Senator Allison. You might repeat the question, Senator Sherry.

—I am referring to the amendment on not collecting the tax in respect of the defined lower and middle income earners, which is a really critical amendment. It is becoming somewhat difficult to progress this legislation given that we do not have that amendment. We would like to see the detail.
—This is the third amendment of ours which is to be brought forward during the surcharge imposition bill. We have just received note that it is on disk and it is about to be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a pedantic point but why do you change your prepositions? You say:

SPEECH.PARA: adjusted taxable income of a member for a financial year means the sum of:
(a) the member's taxable income of the year of income—

Shouldn't it be `taxable income for the year of income' rather than `of the year of income'? I do not think that is a big point but, in any event, are those two separate concepts in (i) and (ii) or do they run together? Are they two different amounts in (a)(i) and (a)(ii)? Has there been any decision as to the expressions `bona fide redundancy amount, an early retirement scheme amount or an invalidity amount'? If so, what was the decision?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, as usual they are very precise questions deserving precise answers. In your questions you said you were raising a pedantic point about whether it was `of the year of income' or `for the year of income'. I think we would agree with you: it was a pedantic point. As to the question of different amounts, that is right: they are, I am informed, different amounts. When I have not been in the chamber—and I haven't not been here for very long—I have been listening very carefully in my office to this absolutely compelling debate, and I think I heard Senator Kemp answer your last question a number of times today. I am further informed by the officers that it is the same definition as in the Income Tax Assessment Act.
—Have there been any decisions made as to the meanings of those? Has the court made any decisions about those expressions? That is what I am asking.

—I am further informed that, since the Labor Party introduced those provisions into the act in 1983, there has been some consideration of them but there has been no difficulty with them. There is very little case law. I am informed that if you were trying to build a practice around that area of the law you would be very poor.
—Do the advisers know of any decisions and, if so, could they tell us where they are reported?

—We cannot give you anything that would really add much to this debate. I am informed—and I do not want to read this down too much—that there is not a lot of case law. The cases that exist are reported in Australian tax cases and Australian tax reports. There is not a lot but if you would like us to find those reports for you we are happy to do so.
—If you would. I take it from that that the sorts of comments that Senator Sherry was making and others have been making—that those expressions are still uncertain—are correct.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the government have any estimated cost to revenue of the Australian Democrats' amendment that we are currently considering? I am not going to hold you to the nearest dollar or even million dollars, but I would like to have some assessment of that, please.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, to Senator Cooney—those definitions are the subject of tax ruling No. 94-12, and it is not fair to say that those matters are things that are unclear. They are clearly things that are as clear as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the costings on the Democrats' amendment, I remind the committee that it is a Democrats' amendment. It was only proposed this evening and we do not have any accurate assessments on the costing of it, but we are advised that it is not of a great magnitude—it depends on what you call big and small.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will raise this issue in estimates committees this week, so I give you advance notice of that. Also, you might provide us at estimates with costings on the exclusion of military retention bonuses and long service and annual leave on retirement as well as a breakdown of (a), (b), (c), (e) and (f) which we effectively moved, and you can check the Hansard record for that. I am just giving you advance notice for estimates that we would like some costings on that based on current practice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Sherry for giving us advance notice of that and, as usual, we will seek to cooperate and see what we can provide.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now return to opposition amendments Nos 9 and 10.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before we do that, I would like to say that this has been a messy process and I am thankful to all the parties for the way it has been handled. I think we have been reasonably understanding about how we have handled the process of the amendments. I am just wondering whether we are likely to see the amendment to Nos 6 and 8 before we conclude at 11 o'clock.
—We have just had word that the amended version is on its way to the chamber and, as soon as we see it, we will be able to circulate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that will make it difficult because we want to analyse it closely. I think it is going to be difficult to vote on it tonight, so I will make some comments on our amendments 9 and 10, which deal with partial rollovers, to save some time.

SPEECH.PARA: Unless the Democrat amendment is absolutely clear and goes very precisely to the exclusion of the tax collection for low and middle income earners in the same sort of language we had, we will want to have a close look at it before we enter into any agreement and vote on that. The Labor Party does not intend to be rushed nine minutes before this debate is due to finish at 11 o'clock on such a fundamental issue without some very close examination of what it is the Democrats are proposing. I seek leave to move opposition amendments Nos 9 and 10 together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Clause 10, page 10 (line 22), after paragraph (b.), insert:
or
(ba) only some of the contributions have been paid to a person other than a superannuation provider;
(10) Clause 10, page 10 (lines 24 to 26), omit paragraph (c), substitute:
(c) if:

PARA.TAB: (i) all of the surchargeable contributions were paid, or the pension or annuity began to be paid, to the member—the member is liable to pay the surcharge; or

(ii) if only some of the surchargeable contributions were paid to a person other than a superannuation provider—the member may direct the superannuation provider who is the holder of the remaining contributions to pay some or all of the surcharge, or may choose to pay the surcharge directly; or

SPEECH.PARA: I will make some comments about our amendments 9 and 10, which deal with the issue of partial rollovers. I make the point in relation to partial rollovers that we are attempting to clarify the position of this product in the bill before us.

Our amendment seeks to allow individuals to choose whether their tax surcharge liability is met by their rollover fund or by themselves. The bill appears to be silent on this issue—it does not address it at all. This absence is another sign of what we believe has been the ongoing saga and general shambles surrounding this package of legislation. We believe the government should have sought to clarify this position themselves.

How is a superannuation fund to know what to do with a liability arising from the surcharge? This amendment seeks to ensure that members have the right to choose how the surcharge liability is paid when the superannuation asset is partially rolled over.

They are the arguments. I have been relatively brief at this stage because we are aware of the time and we are seeking to make a little more rapid progress. I would be interested in the government's response to these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, we are speaking to your amendments 9 and 10 which are concerned with the amount of the surcharge on partial withdrawal. We will not be supporting the amendment. Noting that time is short, the advice that we have received from our officers is that they add to complexity and could lead to a significant increase in administration costs. The principle, of course, is that the liability follows the money and, on partial rollover, liability goes to the rollover fund. So, Senator, we do not think a case has been made out and, for the reasons I have stated, we will not be supporting the amendments you have moved.

—The Democrats will not be supporting this amendment. While I think Senator Sherry has made some very important points, as I said earlier, we think that the government should have to wear this since it has chosen not to take up those issues at this point in time. We will be voting against this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —That approach of the Democrats does disappoint us. We have had representations from individuals in industry about the issue of partial rollovers. We have found it a little bit frustrating in the process of dealing with this package of legislation and the way it has been put together over the last seven or eight months since the budget announcement. We want to try to make this legislation work and deal with some of the issues that have been raised with us by industry. We cannot deal with them all. In the previous amendment, the employee share issue was dealt with. I think I am detecting from Senator Allison that she agrees with the points we make but she is not prepared to support amendments which, we believe, correct it. That is very disappointing. We believe, if there is a problem that can be fixed—and there are many problems that need to be fixed with this package of legislation—and people who are going to suffer as a consequence of problems being left unresolved, it will cause harm and uncertainty for the individuals to be affected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This seems to the Greens to be a technical amendment to deal with the situation where some contributions are paid to a superannuation provider but not all of them. It provides some options for the taxpayer to pay tax directly and we are willing to support this amendment.
