SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to speak on the adjournment regarding the terrible situation that has developed in Newcastle following the announcement of BHP last week that it would proceed to close the steelworks. This announcement delivered a cruel blow to many thousands of workers and their families in Newcastle. The announcement has reverberated throughout the city and throughout the community. Clearly, people in that city now—workers and their families—are facing the very bleak prospect of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: As it has been reported in the papers—and I think it is true, notwithstanding the attitude of the government—this decision has really ripped the heart out of the city. It is a proud city that has been at the forefront of the manufacturing sector in this country all this century.

Since 1915 the steelworks have been the heart of Newcastle. Thousands upon thousands of workers through generations of families have devoted their working lives to that industry, to that company, and one would have expected that they could have been treated a bit more civilly than they were when that announcement was made.

It has been indicated that at least 2,000 jobs will be lost, with further jobs to go in other centres around Australia. Of course many more jobs will go and businesses will be threatened through the flow‐on effects of the closure of the steelworks. Thousands of family members are wondering and asking what will be their future. What hopes do they have for jobs for themselves and for their children? Indeed, what hopes do they have for a comfortable lifestyle in the future?

That is something the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and this government promised the battlers of Australia. Mr Howard said that what he was about was to make the battlers of this country—the people of this country—feel relaxed and comfortable. Certainly the people of Newcastle affected by this decision directly, and those likely to be affected in the future, cannot be feeling relaxed and comfortable now.

It has been a cruel and heartless announcement, as I said, delivered with little feeling. Ironically, as that announcement was made, the share price of BHP rocketed overnight. It surged some 69c. As one article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 May noted, it was somewhat ironic that, as many thousands of workers were going to lose their jobs, the executive salaries of the managing director and chief executive of BHP would substantially increase in value because of the fact that they have significant shareholdings in the company. As I said, it is rather ironic.

When one talks about battlers, you really have to recognise that the workers of Newcastle fit very much into that category. They are people who have devoted their working lives to this so-called great Australian company—a company that has been a beneficiary over the years of government programs and assistance, particularly through the steel industry plan, to enable it to become competitive and a world leader in a range of industries from mining and steel to petroleum and energy.

It is also important to ask: what has been the reaction from this government? The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) said the announcement was `regrettable'. Frankly, the government could have been far more responsive and far more sympathetic to the situation and could have taken action to at least seek some consideration by the company of the way in which it made this announcement and its impact.

Today we had in the Senate during question time the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) attacking the unions because they have responded to the call of their members and have taken some industrial action in support of retaining their jobs. We constantly hear attacks upon unions and upon trade unionists from this government. We hear from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) that if only we could reduce the role of unions in the work force then things would be better. That is what we have been promised. That is what the battlers have been promised—jobs and better pay. But what are they getting today? In Newcastle they are getting the sack and their unions are under attack by this government.

The major union in Newcastle, the Australian Workers Union—which of course was formed out of the old AWU, and the union at Newcastle, FIME—is in there supporting the workers of Newcastle and their families, just as unions have done for over 80 years. They will continue to be there. They will continue to give that support both during this crisis and, no doubt, afterwards if people ultimately do lose their jobs. Unions are about providing support throughout the working lives of the people of this city, as indeed in all other locations around the country.

This will not be the last time I speak on this issue. This is an issue that is not going to go away. It is one that clearly the government has to face up to. In closing, I want to refer to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 1 May which referred to the union leader of the AWU in Newcastle, Mr Maurie Rudd. Mr Rudd was told some months ago that he had an inoperable brain tumour. Notwithstanding that complaint where his life is, as he acknowledges, fading away, he is back at work and he is leading the union and its members in their campaign to try to get the company to review its decision. The article says:

. . . his more immediate pain comes from what he sees as a betrayal of the workforce. For 10 years he told the workers that they would have to wear the pain of restructuring if the steelworks was to survive.
He often urged militant members to be patient when they wanted to strike. He believed BHP was committed to staying in Newcastle.
But when it became clear to him three months ago that BHP would not go ahead with a promise to build a new state‐of‐the‐art steelmaking arc furnace, he feared the worst.
"I feel very despondent about the dishonesty of BHP. It is a killer what they have done to this town," he says.
Typically, Mr Rudd has not abandoned hope. Just as he has refused to give up the fight for his life, he is determined to fight to the end to save the steelworks.

The workers of Newcastle and their families know that in Maurie Rudd they have someone who will continue to fight for their interests, for their future, to the end of his life. I hope that this government listens to people like Maurie Rudd and provides urgent support to the workers and their families of BHP at Newcastle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to discuss the issue of education, in particular future and OECD directions in higher education. While on Australian campuses students and academics are struggling to defend the last vestiges of a publicly funded and accessible higher education system, I think we can learn a lot by looking at the current international debate over higher education issues.

SPEECH.PARA: In the United States, for example, President Bill Clinton declared that at least two years of college would be `as universal in America by the 21st century as high school education is today'. Last week, the OECD considered a draft report into the future of higher education. The study, which examined several European countries, the United States, Australia, New Zealand and Japan, noted that higher education, once considered the domain of a privileged few or a `distant goal for a small minority', could soon reach 80 per cent or more of the population.

From 1985 through to 1994, enrolment among 18- to 21-year-olds jumped from 25 per cent to 40 per cent in Canada and from 19 per cent to 33 per cent in France. In the United States, enrolment of 26- to 29-year-olds rose from eight per cent to around 10 per cent. The study predicts `ever higher levels of students at all ages' who will be seeking additional education to adjust to evolving job markets.

The study also cites the need for increased financing to build new campuses equipped with computers and, of course, other high-tech equipment, but it says that simply raising student fees is not the answer to financing this sector. It states that `proposals for fees have provoked strong reactions in France, Germany and the United Kingdom', just as we have seen in Australia. The introduction of up‐front fees at Melbourne University was enacted through the means of a secret petition of councillors, not in the open forum of a meeting of council where views could be put and challenged.

The OECD researcher Skilbeck concluded that failing to widen educational opportunity will not only aggravate unemployment but will cause `an emerging dimension of inequality in our societies' and `many people will feel they did not get a fair chance'. I think many Australians feel that the coalition government is not giving them a fair chance when it comes to education. Up-front fees were one of the most sinister parts of the government's regressive reform of the higher education sector last year.

Australians are being offered the so-called `salvation' to universities in the form of the opportunity to charge up-front and full cost fees—remembering that these institutions have been starved for funding over the last 14 years. These universities are not adopting up-front and full cost fees with glee, seizing the so-called opportunity that the government has provided. They have often done so—that is, adopted fee policies—with remorse or discomfort.

Vice‐Chancellor Gavin Brown at Sydney University said that the decision to charge up‐front fees was not taken lightly and that in fact it was a decision taken with regret at the final passing of an era in which full public funding to our great universities was possible. It was also reported that the council passed the introduction of up-front fees because the only other choice was to shed staff. The budget cuts to university operating grants have not been nicks and cuts, as the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) has stated. They have actually been quite savage cuts, forcing universities to cut costs at the expense of education, in some cases cut staff and, of course, close down campuses. Sydney University now has these regressive fees and it also has had to sack hundreds of staff members.

So the willingness to have the opportunity of charging these fees is based on financial imperative, not on educational or social good. The introduction of these fees has been contentious. At Deakin University, the council decided to introduce up-front fees with a vote of nine against and 12 for. But what is interesting about this issue is that, when it was brought forward for debate, it was actually done in the absence of the elected student representatives. In fact, three student representative places were vacant at the time of the decision—and, of course, they may very well have changed the decision, if you are talking about a vote of 12 to nine.

Universities are making decisions on the introduction of up-front fees all around the country. I know that my alma mater, the University of Adelaide, will be considering the decision on Friday. I think the University of Technology of Sydney will be considering it in the next couple of weeks. The ANU has a council meeting in the near future.

I think these institutions are doing so without any clear indication as to the rules guiding the charging of these fees. It took until April for the minister for education to circulate even draft guidelines, yet university councils have been making—that is, introducing—these fee charging plans in the meantime. We have draft guidelines that are inadequate and do not even begin to address the fundamental issue of the $9,000 penalty. That penalty for those people who enrol above the so‐called 25 per cent quota will not act as a sufficient disincentive or penalty for breaching the guidelines, especially when you are charging a fee of around $110,000 in the case of Melbourne University, for example, for dentistry degrees.

We also have the experiences of postgraduate fees to show us where the path will lead. It is an experience that the Labor Party would be particularly ashamed of, given that they were primarily responsible for the deregulation of the postgraduate fee paying sector. They opened the gates of user pays with the HEAC, the HECS and up-front postgraduate fees, and now under the coalition government the horse has bolted. The 10th higher education council report on up‐front postgraduate fees found that target equity groups were disadvantaged in an up-front fee paying system.

In 1995, while women made up over 50 per cent of the population, less than 42 per cent of all fee paying postgraduate places were held by women. While indigenous Australians made up 1.4 per cent of the population, their representation in full fee paying arrangements was 0.5 per cent. While rural Australians made up 24.3 per cent of the population, their representation was just over 10 per cent. While isolated Australians made up 4.4 per cent of the population, only 2.2 per cent were represented in fee paying postgraduate courses. The most devastating figure of all is the representation of Australians from lower socioeconomic backgrounds in these courses. They make up one‐quarter of the nation's population, but comprise only 6.59 per cent of those enrolled in fee paying postgraduate courses, which is quite shameful.

We should also remember that when up-front fees were originally charged for postgraduate fee paying places, we were promised by the former government that they would be capped at 20 per cent of load. That does not even compare with the 25 per cent so-called cap that the minister has set down for this government in relation to undergraduate fee paying places. Claims by this government that the undergraduate HECS load will be maintained are also dubious. In this year alone we have seen 4,210 HECS liable postgraduate places sacrificed. So the government rhetoric that funding cuts to operating grants came without sacrificing student undergraduate numbers also rings hollow.

Only the Australian Democrats have been the party with a clear vision and a clear commitment in this area—that is, to a publicly funded and accessible education system. We have often been alone voting on these particular issues, but I would like to acknowledge that we have the community on our side. Many polls have shown recently—and, of course, throughout the last year while this debate has gone on—that the community is opposed to up-front fees. They are opposed to increased HECS and reduced operating grants, and the community still holds firmly the belief that education should be accessible to all.

I note an AVCC commissioned Newspoll last week showed that 73.18 per cent of those people who responded to the survey believed that higher education is very important in shaping the nation's future. Only 5.56 per cent did not believe that higher education was important. Some 94 per cent believe that we should be spending at least the same or more than our Asian neighbours on higher education, and 60 per cent believe that government spending on higher education is too low.

The coalition came into power on a pledge to address the funding clawback of 13 per cent to that sector over the 13 years of Labor rule. They have had the audacity, of course, now to implement a five per cent cut in just three years, on top of the funding decreases that they promised to fix. John Howard said, `Nothing saps the confidence and the faith of the people in their elected representatives more than the cynical repudiation of promises shortly after a change of government.' I put it to you, Madam President, that nowhere has there been a more blatant betrayal of promises and commitments to the electorate by this government than in the area of higher education policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the matter of the proposed changes to the role and function of the Victorian Auditor-General. The Commonwealth government has a role and responsibility in this matter which it is currently neglecting. The Kennett government's review of the Auditor‐General is an attack not only on the powers of Mr Baragwanath and future Auditors-General to act as a check on government, but also on the very fabric of the model of the separation of powers and accountable government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General has a central place in the accountability chain and has a fundamental watchdog role in the Australian system of government. The Auditor-General's office is responsible for the external audits of the financial affairs of the Victorian public sector and for the performance audits which assess the economy, efficiency and effectiveness of the management of public sector resources in the state. It therefore plays a key role in the accountability process of the government to the parliament and ultimately to the taxpayers and the public of Victoria.

Last year the Kennett government initiated the review into the Victorian Audit Act 1994 in line with national competition policy rules. That an accountability agency should be dealt with in this way was extraordinary. The move rang alarm bells in some sectors of the community, but so far the Commonwealth government has not commented. The report, handed down late last month, intends to considerably alter, to the detriment of the people of Victoria, the powers and role of the Auditor and threatens to materially weaken our system of responsible government.

An independent Auditor-General is an essential part of the accountability chain which helps parliament blow the whistle on government waste. There needs to be a constant vigilance on government waste by chief executives, by the Department of Fi nance, by government and through the office of the Auditor‐General.

The Australian National Audit Office and its state equivalents can and do save governments millions of dollars. The Auditor‐General also ensures government resources are used efficiently and reviews government contract arrangements to make sure that public money is not placed at unnecessary risk. The 1992 WA Inc. royal commission emphatically stated the importance of the Auditor-General in the chain of accountability:

The office of Auditor-General provides a critical link in the accountability chain between the public sector, the Parliament and the community. It alone subjects the practical conduct and operations of the public sector as a whole to regular, independent investigation and review. This function must be fully guaranteed and its discharge facilitated.

The Victorian Audit Act review report signals the end of the Auditor-General's exclusive right to report, and exclusive right to decide who reports for it, on the public sector. One of the central findings of the report is that the public sector audit office is separated from the Auditor-General's office and created as a government business enterprise—`business,' when we are talking about accountability. That business enterprise will be called Audit Victoria. Audit Victoria would operate on fully commercial terms under a board of management, providing audit and related services to the public sector in competition with private sector firms.

The institutionalisation of outsourcing and tenders for audits of government departments without the Auditor-General's absolute control would undermine and endanger the chain of accountability that operates in our system of government. This is not to say that the Auditor-General should never contract out any of its auditing requirements. The Victorian Auditor-General already makes significant use of private auditors. In 1995‐96, the Auditor‐General in Victoria paid a total of $5.8 million to private auditors, compared with a total expenditure of approximately $17.7 million.

The Auditor-General, however, must have the power to determine what functions, audits or inquiries should be outsourced and tendered. The Auditor-General must also have the power to reject a privately tendered audit should this need arise. In this way, the independence and accountability functions of the Auditor-General are not curtailed.

The 1992 WA Inc. royal commission—established in the wake of the allegations of corruption and illegal and improper conduct in the affairs, investment decisions and business dealings of the Labor government of Western Australia—reported on the essential nature of the independence of the Auditor-General from the government and the executive. The royal commission said:

The Auditor‐General is the Parliament's principal informant on the performance of the administrative system. The Parliament therefore has a special responsibility to ensure both that the independence and the effective resourcing of the Auditor‐General are secured . . .

While the Victorian report proposes to enhance the independence of the auditor by making him or her an independent officer of the parliament—which would be welcome if it was accompanied by the financial independence of the parliament—the extensive reduction of the auditor's powers with the audit program makes the increased independence farcical. The proposal that financial audits and performance audits be conducted by private auditing firms underestimates the scope of the Auditor-General's tasks and its function as a fundamental accountability agency.

The Auditor-General is no mere scrutineer of financial affairs of departments and agencies of government, notwithstanding the importance of this responsibility. A recognition of this fact highlights the inappropriateness of tendering or outsourcing many of the Auditor-General's functions. To do so places at risk the practices and principles of open, accountable and transparent government—a civic duty, not a business duty. It is a principle theme in recent inquiries and reports in Western Australia and the Commonwealth.
The 1992 WA Inc. royal commission in report No. 2 pointed to the scope of the auditor functions, which included more than merely auditing financial accounts. It said:

In auditing the accounts of an agency, the Auditor-General is expected to address . . . such matters as the agency's compliance with the law and the legislation and directions under which it acts and the controls it has to secure that compliance; the probity of official conduct in its financial affairs; the appropriateness of performance indicators; and, of no little importance . . . the adequacy of the records on which its management is based and carried into effect . . .

In our current system of government, the Auditor-General has an expanding and far‐reaching responsibility to `keep them honest,' one which relates directly to protecting the public purse. This must be borne in mind when considering any changes to the role of this agency and the structure of government.

The proposal to allow government departments to select their own auditor has serious implications for the independence of the auditor and the accountability of government departments to parliament. The Australian Democrats believe that the role and function of the Auditor-General's department in Victoria should not differ from those governing Auditor-Generals elsewhere in Australia. It is my concern and the concern of the Australian Democrats that the Victorian proposals will open the door once again, and even more so, to the eighties style of entrepreneurial government. There are enough alarm bells ringing in Victoria right now without that happening.

Rather than weakening the role of the Auditor-General, the auditor's powers should be widened and strengthened if the public is to obtain the benefit and protection that the Auditor‐General is capable of providing. The government should ensure that the Auditor-General is a properly resourced and independent accountability agency which can effectively act on behalf of the people of Victoria.

The Victorian report and proposals are out of step. Indeed, they are moving in the opposite direction to that which was strongly advocated and ultimately recommended by inquiries in Western Australia and the Commonwealth. The federal government should be concerned with these developments in Victoria if it is serious about government responsibility and accountability to the parliament and if it holds the Westminster system, or any system of separation of powers and accountability, with any regard. It is absolutely vital that the Auditor-General remain outside the control of the government of the day and be answerable only to the parliament if we are to ensure proper accountability.

The reform options proposed in the terms of reference include consideration of whether government departments should be able to choose their own private auditor. This would mean that government departments could bypass independent scrutiny through the appointment of a private auditor, which is a serious prospect. Those who follow my press releases would know that we are determined, if this situation is not addressed by the Commonwealth, to move amendments to any Auditor-Generals bill put before this Senate to protect Commonwealth moneys used by the Victorian government.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 28 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it possible using the Airservices Search and Rescue Service (SRS) delivery system to circle a group of survivors by dropping a sequence of raft strings.
(2) Is it possible to undertake the same manoeuvre with the Precision Aerial Delivery system (PADS).
(3) Using Australia's most common drop aircraft, Piper Navajo and Cessna 402, is it possible to drop four life rafts from a single aircraft using the SRS delivery system.
(4) How many life rafts can be dropped from a single aircraft using the PADS delivery system.
(5) Is the SRS delivery system compatible with the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) aircraft and dropping systems.
(6) Is the PADS delivery system compatible with RAAF aircraft and dropping system.
(7) How many aircraft types operating in Australia are capable of using the SRS delivery system.
(8) How many aircraft types operating in Australia are capable of delivering the PADS delivery system.
(9) How much did the 1995 search and rescue equipment delivery system tender cost and can a detailed breakdown of those costs be provided.
(10) What was the basis for the Minister's decision to disregard the findings of the of the 1995 tender evaluation committee's recommendation that PADS not be purchased.
(11) Is Airservices Australia obliged to undertake competitive tender processes when purchasing goods or services.
(12) What are the financial and legal procedures Airservices Australia is required to follow before entering into contracts for the purchase of goods or services.

(13) Were these financial and legal obligations met before Airservices Australia signed contracts to purchase the PADS system; if not, what financial and legal procedures were followed by Airservices Australia in relation to this contract.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Airservices has provided the following information:
(1) Yes.
(2) No. The PADS delivery system is a single unit drop only.
(3) Yes. The Standard Raft System (SRS) allows for any combination of one, two, three or four liferafts to be dropped as required.
(4) Three liferafts on three separate single unit drops using the aircraft types capable of releasing the PADS system.
(5) Yes.

(6) There is an inter‐operability agreement between Airservices and the RAAF for the existing SAR system. No agreement has been negotiated regarding the PADS equipment. As to whether the PADS equipment is compatible with RAAF aircraft and dropping systems, this is a matter for the RAAF to determine.
(7) There are approximately 40 aircraft types capable of using the SRS delivery system.
(8) There are approximately 7 aircraft types capable of delivering the PADS delivery system.

(9) The tender cost nearly $300,000. The principal components of the cost were labour $79,000, RAAF Airforce Research and Development Unit (ARDU) cost $71,000, travel $56,000, aircraft chartering and pilot hiring $39,000 and materials $27,000.
(10) The findings of the 1995 tender evaluation committee were dealt with by the Airservices Board in January 1996 and were not a matter for the Minister.
(11) Airservices tender procedures require competitive tenders for amounts in excess of $100,000 but these procedures provide for exceptions on sole provider, safety and public interest grounds.
(12) Airservices procedures for purchasing goods and services are contained in the Airservices financial and procedure manuals.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 28 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the tender evaluation process continue after that time and was Mr Grant's evidence to the committee incorrect.
(2) Did the tender evaluation committee complete the evaluation process.
(3) Did the tender evaluation committee recommend that the PADS system should not be chosen on the grounds of: (a) safety; (b) performance; and (c) economics.
(4) Can a copy of the tender evaluation report be provided.

(5) With reference to advice from Mr Peter Evans, General Manager Air Traffic Services, to the committee that Mr Peter Petroni, who replaced Mr Alan Terrell on the panel that evaluated the PADS system in August 1996, was one of three people who undertook a review of search and rescue in 1991: (a) did that review examine supply dropping issues; and (b) can a copy of the 1991 Search and Rescue Review report be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Airservices Australia has advised that the tender evaluation process was completed on 13 December 1995 when the tender evaluation committee (TEC) considered the Airforce Research and Development Unit (ARDU) report and completed a comparative assessment of the Precision Aerial Delivery System (PADS) and Airservices systems.
Also, on 13 December 1995 the Committee decided to recommend that no purchases of delivery systems take place.
The sequence of events described by Mr Grant on 22 October 1996 was therefore correct.
(2) Yes.

(3) Advice from Airservices is that the TEC decided to recommend that no purchases of delivery systems take place "as a result of the Search and Rescue Equipment Delivery System (SAREDS) Project". The TEC considered a number of factors in scoring the Airservices and tendered systems. These included safety, reliability, flexibility, training (ground), training (flying), maintenance, protection and environmental systems as well as cost
(4) Yes. A copy of the report has been provided to the Secretary of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee.

(5a) Airservices Australia has advised that the purpose of the review was to develop a strategic plan for future delivery of Search and Rescue (SAR) services. The review was not specifically required to examine SAR supply dropping issues. However, some demonstration drops were carried out during the course of the review.
(5b) Yes. A copy of the report has been provided in response to questions raised during the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee hearings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 29 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the matter of the Exeter Child Care Centre in Northern Tasmania and its efforts to obtain funding as to be able to relocate to an alternative and more suitable location nearby.

(2) Has action been initiated by the department to assist the Exeter Child Care Centre in covering the cost of purchasing alternative premises at a site opposite to where the centre is currently located.
(3) Is the Exeter Child Care Centre being considered in the process of allocating additional funding for those child care centres located in disadvantaged areas.
(4) What other criteria, apart from the receipt of operational subsidy, does the department rely on in assessing whether a long day child care centre is private or community‐based.
(5) Does the Minister consider the Exeter Child Care Centre is located in an area of disadvantage.
(6) When is it anticipated that a decision will be forthcoming as to whether the Exeter Child Care Centre will be considered eligible for additional funding.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. I met with representatives of the Exeter Child Care Centre on 10 October 1996.
(2) Yes. The Department has examined possible options for assisting the Exeter Child Care Centre. Funds are not available to purchase the alternative premises.

(3) No. Disadvantaged Area Subsidies are only available to centres in disadvantaged areas that experience viability problems as a result of the withdrawal of operational subsidy. Exeter Child Care Centre does not receive operational subsidy.

(4) The only criteria which differentiates between centres is whether or not a centre received funding under an approved child care growth strategy. Non‐profit centres established under an approved growth strategy are located in accordance with a Needs Based Planning Formula and are eligible for operational subsidies (until 30 June 1997) and capital.

(5) The Minister will only be required to make judgements about disadvantage for centres which have lost their entitlement to operational subsidy. Exeter Child Care Centre does not receive operational subsidy.
(6) The Department has examined possible options for assisting the Exeter Child Care Centre. Funds are not available to purchase the alternative premises.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 16 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) Did Australia abstain on the Malaysian sponsored resolution L37 in the United Nations (UN) General Assembly First Committee and Plenary; and (b) what is the rationale for the Government's vote.

(2) (a) Did the recent decision on the International Court of Justice state unanimously that there is a legal obligation on the part of the nuclear weapons states to enter into bonafide negotiations to eliminate nuclear weapons; and (b) did the L37 resolution call for negotiations for precisely that end.

(3) (a) Does the Australian Government believe that steps need to be taken before a weapons convention can be concluded; and (b) what are those intermediate steps are and what is the timetable for taking them.

(4) (a) How does the L37 resolution interfere with or go against the realisation of those intermediate steps; and (b) does the Minister concede that the L37 resolution in fact actually places additional pressure on the nuclear weapon states to proceed with intermediate steps, rather than impeding any of them.

(5) (a) Did the New Zealand Government vote in favour of L37 stating its consistency with intermediate steps; (b) did the United States (US), Iceland, Belgium and Austria argue for further bilateral negotiations; (c) does the L37 resolution prevent or hinder bilateral negotiations in any way; and (d) does the Minister not concede that the L37 resolution actually places more pressure on the nuclear weapons states to enter into bilateral negotiations.
(6) Did Australia vote for the L45 resolution on bilateral arms negotiations sponsored by the US; if so, how can L45 and L37 be seen as mutually exclusive.

(7) Did Australia vote against the Myanmar resolution L39 which called on the nuclear weapons states to `stop the qualitative improvement, development, production and stockpiling of nuclear warheads and their delivery systems' on the grounds that the resolution calls for a phased program of nuclear disarmament and for the eventual elimination of nuclear weapons within a time-bound framework and through a nuclear weapons convention because of the words `time-bound framework' and `nuclear weapons convention'.

(8) Is it the case that the Government has a rigid opposition to the words `time-bound framework' in resolutions dealing with nuclear disarmament issues and will vote against such resolutions no matter what else may be contained in such resolutions; if so, why.

(9) Does the Government concede that, regardless of the Australia' s attitude, strong support exists for a time-bound framework in the Non-Aligned Movement, the Non-Government Organisation community and in the global peace and disarmament movement.

(10) (a) Does the Government concede that its position on nuclear disarmament issues rarely differs from the US and, in fact, almost always supports the US position and voting pattern at the UN; and (b) can any examples on peace and disarmament issues where Australia has differed from the US position or voting pattern be provided.
(11) Why does the Government believe a time-bound framework is too prescriptive, when only the concept of a timebound framework has been suggested rather than the framework itself.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (l)(a) and (b) and (3)(a) and (b). Australia abstained in voting at the 1996 session of the United Nations General Assembly on the Malaysian-sponsored resolution concerning the advisory opinion of the International Court of Justice on the legality of the threat or use of nuclear weapons (resolution 51/45 M, in previous committee stage consideration called L.37). A key paragraph of the resolution (operative paragraph 4) calls on all states "to immediately fulfil this obligation by commencing multilateral negotiations in 1997 leading to the early conclusion of a nuclear weapons convention prohibiting the development, production, testing, deployment, stockpiling, transfer, threat or use of nuclear weapons and providing for their elimination." Australia did, however, vote in favour of the paragraph of the resolution (operative paragraph 3) which underlined the unanimous conclusion of the Court that there exists an obligation to pursue in good faith and bring to a conclusion negotiations leading to nuclear disarmament in all its aspects under strict and effective international control.

The Government is committed to the twin goals of preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons and working through progressive balanced steps towards complete nuclear disarmament. It was therefore sympathetic to the general aims embodied in this resolution.

There are, however, many steps to be taken on the road to the goal of nuclear disarmament before the question of a single nuclear weapons convention can be productively addressed. Whereas a multilaterally negotiated legal instrument may well be a focus of the final phases of the elimination of nuclear weapons, the Government believes it is more productive in present circumstances to continue to encourage the nuclear weapon states, particularly the United States and Russia, to maintain the current momentum of nuclear arsenal reductions, notably under the START (Treaty on Reduction and Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms) process. In this context, the Government notes and welcomes the recent agreement between the United States and Russia on guidelines for a further round of such reductions, known as START III, which will look toward further reducing strategic warhead stockpiles for both countries to some 80 percent below Cold War peaks. To attempt to force the pace by "multilateralising" nuclear disarmament prematurely would run the risk of impeding the concrete nuclear disarmament measures currently being undertaken by diverting attention from those negotiations. The Government does not consider it a realistic or productive expenditure of diplomatic capital to attempt to persuade the nuclear weapon states to adhere to a timetable for nuclear disarmament which does not take account of the global strategic environment. The latter factor will remain the key determinant of the pace of nuclear disarmament.

As was made clear in a statement accompanying its vote, the Government, for the reasons adduced above, would have preferred resolution 51/45M to focus attention on the immediate and intermediate concrete steps which will take forward the process of nuclear disarmament.

In addition to continuing nuclear arsenal reductions by the nuclear weapon states, a key next step on the road to nuclear disarmament is the early commencement of substantive negotiations on a convention banning the production of fissile material for use in nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices (known as a "cut-off" convention). This is widely acknowledged as the next logical step for multilateral negotiations after the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty and would be a major new addition to the process of nuclear disarmament and to strengthening barriers to nuclear proliferation. The Government is currently working hard in the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva to get "cut-off" negotiations under way and concluded as soon as possible in that forum. In parallel with this activity, the Government will: continue to encourage full implementation of the Treaty on Further Reduction and Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms between the United States and Russia (START II), and further nuclear reduction through, for example, START III; work for widespread adherence to the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty; promote the strengthening of International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards; and support the enhanced Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty review process which commences this year.

(2)(a) and (b) In its Advisory Opinion on the legality of use or threat of nuclear weapons handed down on 8 July 1996, the International Court of Justice said, inter alia, that "there exists an obligation to pursue in good faith and bring to a conclusion negotiations leading to nuclear disarmament in all its aspects under strict and effective international control". This aspect of the Court's Opinion was agreed unanimously and did not refer to the specific concept of a single nuclear weapons convention. The United Nations General Assembly resolution referred to in paragraph (1) of the question was considerably more prescriptive and specific in its treatment of the issue, as indicated in the first paragraph of the answer to paragraph ( 1) of the question.

(4)(a) and (b) As the answers to questions (l) and (3) above make clear, the Government does not support calls for a timebound framework for nuclear disarmament as embodied in the resolution. The Government believes it is more productive to focus on promoting practical, realistic steps towards the ultimate elimination of nuclear weapons. It considers that calls for a prescriptive timebound approach to the disarmament process are patently not realistic, and therefore do nothing to advance the cause of disarmament in any concrete or practical way. What is required to advance the cause of nuclear disarmament is the patient and dogged pursuit of the various inter-locking steps on the path to the complete elimination of nuclear weapons. The Government believes that it is more productive for the international community to concentrate on actually achieving further concrete progress towards nuclear disarmament rather than seeking to debate an artificial timetable for the achievement of a single nuclear weapons conven tion to which the nuclear weapon states are opposed at this Stage.

(5)(a) New Zealand voted in favour of resolution 51/45 M, noting in particular its reference to the unanimous finding of the International Court of Justice of the obligation to pursue and conclude negotiations leading to nuclear disarmament. New Zealand was of the view that the resolution reinforced this obligation and was consistent with New Zealand's advocacy of the pursuit of negotiations on a phased programme of disarmament leading to the elimination of nuclear weapons. As noted above, Australia also voted in favour of this particular aspect of the resolution but, for the reasons set out above, was unable to support the resolution as a whole

(5)(b) The United States voted against resolution 51/45 M, criticising what it called the resolution's selective quotation from the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty Review and Extension Conference principles and objectives document, and its attempt to turn an advisory opinion into a legal edict requiring the immediate commencement of negotiations and their rapid conclusion in a multilateral forum. It was the view of the U.S. that the Court, in calling for the conclusion of negotiations, had added nothing to the obligation under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, which the U.S. took seriously. The U.S. representative noted President Clinton's pledge to the United Nations General Assembly in September 1996 that, as soon as the Russian Federation ratified the Treaty on Further Reduction and Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms (START II), bilateral discussions on further reductions in strategic forces would begin. The U.S. remained convinced that this bilateral effort was the sensible approach in current circumstances and the one most likely to achieve concrete results. The U.S. took the view that a multilateral negotiating forum was not conducive to taking forward what was an extremely intricate process of nuclear disarmament involving careful trade-offs, specialised verification arrangements and sensitive security calculations.

Iceland abstained in voting on resolution 51/45 M, saying that it did not give a balanced and even-handed picture of the Court's Opinion and attempted to subordinate bilateral nuclear arms negotiations to the work of the Conference on Disarmament. According to Iceland, the resolution could only diminish the value of the Court's Opinion.
The Government is not aware of any specific references to bilateral negotiations in the statements of Austria and Belgium at the time of the vote.

Austria abstained in voting on resolution 51/45 M. In so doing, Austria urged further acceleration of the process of nuclear disarmament towards the ultimate realisation of a nuclear weapons convention, but noted that a number of intermediate but very concrete steps (such as "cut-off") had to be taken first. Austria was concerned that the resolution did not reflect this reality.

Belgium voted against the resolution. In so doing it entered a statement also on behalf of Luxembourg and the Netherlands, explaining that it was not voting against the Opinion of the International Court of Justice, but that the resolution, in quoting selectively from the text of the Court's Opinion, was not a serious enough approach to the Advisory Opinion and fostered polemical debate about nuclear disarmament.

The account of national positions given in answer to Questions (5)(a) and (b) above is based principally on their explanations of vote at the time of voting on the draft resolution in the First Committee of the UN General Assembly on 14 November 1996, as recorded in the summary of proceedings published by the UN Secretariat Department of Public Information (Document GA/DIS/3072 of 14 November 1996).

(5)(c) and (d) As the balance of recommendations of the Canberra Commission on the Elimination of Nuclear Weapons makes clear, the nuclear weapon states will continue for some time to bear the major responsibility for steps to reduce further their nuclear stockpiles, with a view to their ultimate elimination. By focusing exclusively on the possible end-point of what will by necessity continue to be a complex process of bilateral and plurilateral negotiations, 51/45 M ignored this fact, thereby misrepresenting the road ahead for nuclear disarmament. Australia will continue through private dialogue to encourage the nuclear weapon states, and the United States and Russia in particular, to continue the good progress they have made to date in reducing their arsenals. See also answer to paragraphs (1)(a) and (b) and (3)(a) and (b) of the question.

(6) Australia voted in favour of the resolution jointly sponsored by the United States and Russia at the 1996 United Nations General Assembly concerning bilateral nuclear arms negotiations and nuclear disarmament (resolution 51/45 R). The Government saw clear differences between this resolution and resolution 51/45 M discussed above, notably in the latter's focus on a call for time-bound multilateral negotiations leading to conclusion of a nuclear weapons convention.

(7), (8) and (11) Australia voted against the Myanmar-sponsored resolution at the 1996 United Nations General Assembly on nuclear disarmament (resolution 51/45 O, known as L.39 in previous committee consideration). The Government saw important differences between this resolution and the Malaysian-sponsored resolution discussed above (51/45 M).

As noted above, Australia is fully committed to the ultimate elimination of nuclear weapons. Our priority in this area is to focus on practical, realistic steps to achieve the elimination of nuclear weapons, which may at a future point include a nuclear weapons convention. In this respect we consider that calls for a prescriptive timebound approach to the disarmament process as espoused in resolution 51/45 O are patently not realistic in current circumstances, and therefore do nothing to advance the cause of disarmament in any concrete or practical way. In the Government's view, it is unproductive to advocate the sort of tight linkage that holds one negotiation or process hostage to the conclusion of another. This tends to be the result, intended or otherwise, of the efforts of the proponents of the time-bound framework concept. The Government is firmly of the view that it is more productive for the international community to concentrate on actually achieving further progress towards nuclear disarmament rather than seeking to debate an artificial concept or timetable. Such debate is currently delaying the start of negotiations on a "cut-off" convention in the Conference on Disarmament. It was for these reasons that Australia voted against the resolution.

(9) The Government acknowledges that there is support amongst the Non-Aligned Movement group of countries and some non-governmental organisations for time-bound nuclear disarmament. It understands the prima facie attractiveness of this concept for those dedicated to the goal of the elimination of nuclear weapons. However, for the set of reasons elaborated in response to the questions above, the Government, while sharing the dedication to the goal of nuclear disarmament, continues to be of the view that calls for a prescriptive time-bound process to achieve nuclear disarmament do not in fact take the world any closer to achieving this goal.

(10)(a) and (b) Australia's policy positions with regard to arms control and disarmament issues are arrived at independently and with Australia's national interests first and foremost in mind. Regarding comparison of United States and Australian voting patterns at the United Nations on disarmament-related issues, Australia supported the great majority (11 of 15) of nuclear disarmament-related resolutions at last year's General Assembly. Australia voted in favour of the following resolutions which did not receive U.S. support: resolution 51/43 entitled Conclusion of Effective Arrangements to Assure Non-Nuclear Weapon States Against the Use or Threat of Use of Nuclear Weapons; resolution 51/45 B entitled Nuclear Weapon-Free Southern Hemisphere and Adjacent Areas; resolution 51/45 C entitled Convening of a Fourth United Nations Special Session on Disarmament; resolution 51/45 I entitled Bilateral Nuclear Arms Negotiations; resolution 51/48 entitled Risk of Nuclear Proliferation in the Middle East; and resolution 51/51 entitled Declaration of the Indian Ocean as a Zone of Peace.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Assistant Treasurer representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to section 23 (pa) (1b) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as recently amended:

(1) Is the effect that for a bona fide prospector who sells a right to mine for $1 in excess of the market value as at 7.30 pm on 20 August 1996: (a) the whole of the income derived will not qualify for the exemption; and (b) the income up to market value will be exempt from tax, but not the income above market value.
(2) Do bona fide prospectors, so qualified at 20 August 1996, now have tax exemption on income until 20 August 2001, that exemption to apply to market value as at 7.30 pm on 20 August 1996.

(3) Does the Australian Taxation Office have, or will it develop, criteria for the acceptance of appropriate valuations for the purpose of complying with section 23 (pa) (1b); if they are established, what are those criteria.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes.

The intention of the amendment is that only the amount of income which is in excess of the market value as at 7.30 pm on 20 August 1996 is to be made subject to income tax. The words used in the amendment do not produce this result. A technical amendment to give the intended effect was introduced into Parliament on 26 March 1997 in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No 3) 1997.
(2) No. The proposed technical amendment referred to above will, however, ensure that this is the case provided:

PARA.TAB: the income is in relation to the sale transfer or assignment of rights which were acquired before 7.30 pm on 20 August 1996, and
the person also qualified as a bona fide prospector at the time the income was derived.

ANSWER.PARA: (3) The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) has stated, in Taxation Determination TD 11 that where the market value of an asset needs to be determined, taxpayers can choose to either obtain a detailed valuation from a qualified valuer, or compute their own valuation based on reasonably objective and supportable data. The ATO has also stated that it may challenge valuations where appropriate.

The ATO stated that it has provided guidance to taxpayers on the concept of market value in numerous public rulings, including IT2378 which deals with disposal of mining rights. In all of these rulings the ATO has referred to market value as the value determined by an open and unrestricted market of willing (but not anxious) informed, independent buyers and sellers.

The ATO advised that where persons hold rights to mine and also held them at 20 August 1996 and those persons are likely to sell those rights in the next five years it is presumed that those persons would obtain valuations of those rights at their earliest opportunity. The ATO advised that such action is the best chance a person has of protecting their exemption position.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 January 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the granting of monopolistic trading rights to private companies under State law consistent with the competition policy agreements entered into with the States in 1995.
(2) Is the granting of the exclusive monopolistic rights to operate casinos in each capital city and some regional centres granted by the States consistent with the competition policy agreements.

(3) Would the Government be seeking to ensure that the statutes underpinning these rights are reviewed under the regulation review provisions of the competition policy agreements to ensure that they cease to be anti‐competitive.

(4) Which other countries have provided for either an exclusive monopolistic approach to the granting of casino licensees in a single geographic area, or for the granting of several licences in a single geographic area.

(5) What guidelines or procedures, if any, are in place to ensure that proposals by monopolistic operators in casinos to build up substantial cross‐ownership in other areas of industry, particularly other aspects of the gambling industry (for example, privatisation of TABs), are reviewed to prevent the substantial lessening of competition in the industry.

(6) For each of the 14 Australian casinos, for the past 10 years, have any directors or companies holding a substantial or controlling interesting in the casinos held any office within, or made any political donations to, a federally‐registered political party; if so: (a) who; (b) which parties; and (c) what amounts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1 & 2) The granting of monopoly trading rights under state laws is not inconsistent with the Competition Principles Agreement. The Competition Principles Agreement does not invalidate the operation of State laws. Nevertheless, as such laws may restrict competition in the regulated area, the Competition Principles Agreement requires that the laws be reviewed and reformed if appropriate.

(3) The Commonwealth, States and Territories have prepared regulation review schedules as required under the national competition policy reforms. These schedules include a total of more than 1500 pieces of legislation which will be reviewed before the year 2000.

The States and Territories are responsible for regulating gaming activity and have scheduled reviews of the relevant legislation, including casino control legislation. Legislation of this type restricts competition in a variety of ways and will be assessed to determine whether those restrictions are necessary to achieve the objectives of the legislation and are in the public interest.

The conduct of the reviews is a matter for the State or Territory concerned. Nevertheless, the review program is part of the agreed reforms which are conditions for the States and Territories to receive Competition Payments from the Commonwealth. Assessment of whether a State or Territory has complied with these conditions will be undertaken by the National Competition Council.
(4) I have no detailed information on the regulation of casinos in other countries.

(5) The Trade Practices Act prohibits the acquisition of assets which would otherwise give rise to a substantial lessening of competition. State gaming legislation may also be applicable in particular circumstances.

(6) The detailed information needed to answer this question is not readily available to the Government in a consolidated form. I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of time and resources that would be necessary to research all the information sought.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 14 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Commonwealth's role in the protection and management of the Ningaloo Marine Park.

(2) Do ships carrying petroleum products as cargo pass within the boundaries of the Ningaloo Marine Park; if so: (a) how many on an annual basis; and (b) under what environmental protection conditions.

(3) (a)Who monitors these shipping movements within the Marine Park; and (b) who is responsible for enforcing compliance with laws and conditions that apply to such shipping within the Ningaloo Marine Park.
(4) What emergency or disaster plans exist to cope with any oil spill within the Ningaloo Marine Park.
(5) Is the Minister aware of the recent series of articles in the West Australian about growing community concerns over the pace and type of development being proposed for the Ningaloo/ Exmouth area.
(6) Have the various plans and proposals being put forward for tourism, mining and aquaculture developments in the Ningaloo/Exmouth area been examined from an environmental perspective
(7) What is the Government's views on those plans and proposals.
(8) Is the Minister concerned that these and other similar development proposals will, or may, have significant long-term impacts on the Ningaloo Marine Park and adjacent terrestrial environments.
(9) What form of environmental assessments or other involvement will the Commonwealth undertake in relation to these and similar proposed developments.

(10) Can an undertaking be given to the Senate and to the local and Australian community that no developments in the Ningaloo Marine Park and adjacent terrestrial environments will proceed without full and open Commonwealth involvement and Assessments

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Ningaloo Marine Park comprises two separate areas. The Western Australian State waters consist of a coastal strip and the sea, for a distance of three miles offshore, with a total area of 2240 square kilometres which is managed by the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management (CALM). The Ningaloo Marine Park (Commonwealth Waters) consists of an area extending seaward from the State waters' boundary, out to the edge of the continental shelf, and com prises some 2326 square kilometres of open ocean. Protective legislation relating to the Commonwealth Waters area is the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. With the agreement of the Western Australian Minister for the Environment, a number of CALM officers have been appointed as wardens under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, in order to provide protection for the Commonwealth area.

The Commonwealth Waters area is managed on a day to day basis by CALM, under the provisions of a Memorandum of Understanding which was signed in September 1994 by CALM and the then Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. The joint management process, including funding input from the Commonwealth, is implemented through a Ningaloo Marine Park Liaison Committee which meets at six monthly intervals to coordinate the management functions of the Ningaloo Marine Park.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 10 December 1996, (House of Representatives Official Hansard page 8106) in relation to an epidemiological study by Dr Bruce Hocking et al which demonstrated increased incidence of, and death from, acute leukaemia in children in suburbs close to television towers in Sydney:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what basis did the Minister, in effect, dismiss the Hocking study by his answer `one of the things that makes this difficult is that we are talking about a type of childhood leukemia called acute lymphoblastic leukemia, this is a leukemia that appears in clusters.

(2) Is it not very clear from the study that the increased incidence of acute leukemia was uniform across all of the suburbs proximate to the television towers and is this not a strong argument against the `cluster effect' notion.

(3) In the light of the Minister's remarks that it `was still far too early for research to show any sort of causation', will further studies be carried out in the area surrounding the television towers in Sydney.
(4) On what basis is it concluded that `the telecommunication towers emit a pencil beam and as such they are quite different to the other two and are of no concern'.

(5) Can details be provided of how much of the $4.5 million set aside late in 1996 by the Government for research and public information will be provided through the National Health and Medical Research Council in each of the years 1997, 1998, 1999 and 2000 for independent research in Australia.
(6) How much of this fund will be spent on public information in each of those years and how much on World Health Organisation Contributions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The basis of this question is incorrect and unsubstantiated. The Minister did not dismiss the study. The statement was based on:
(a) fact
(b) personal communication with Dr Hocking
(c) his medical training
(d) his personal and family experience with a leukemia cluster.

(2) The Minister is advised that the study does not state that leukemia is uniform across the proximate suburbs. The study does state that there is no statistically significant heterogeneity within the municipalities. This does not exclude clustering, because the number of cancers may be too small to yield statistically significant results even if there is clustering, the geographic information may be insufficient or the cluster may cover all three municipalities.

(3) The draft agenda for research into radiofrequency radiation being developed by the Research Working Group of the Committee on Electromagnetic Energy Public Health Issues is likely to recommend further research into the epidemiology of childhood leukemia. This agenda will be released shortly for public consultation and input on the need for further research around the television towers will be welcome.
(4) This is concluded on the basis of discussions with Dr Hocking.
(5) The research component for the NHMRC will be given a minimum of $700,000 per year for four years (plus $350,000 for 1996/97).

(6) The remaining $300,000 (plus $150,000 for 1996/97) will be for participation in a World Health Organisation project ($100,000) and the Electromagnetic Energy Information Program ($200,000). Expenditure needs on the information program will be assessed annually with any unused/surplus funds being allocated to the research component.

(4) Is the environmental impact assessment document, that was prepared as a public environmental review, a satisfactory basis for decision-making in an area which impinges on an internationally significant, Ramsar registered wetland area.
(5) What action will the Commonwealth Government take to ensure that environmental assessment consistent with Commonwealth standards and international importance of the area is undertaken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No

(2)-(5) My Department has obtained a copy of the Public Environmental Review and is currently reviewing the document and preparing a submission to the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority. I will be briefed as to any Commonwealth concerns regarding the proposal when the document is assessed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Government commissioned inquiry into the role and functions of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), undertaken by Mr Bob Mansfield, and to the fact that the Government has still not made public its position in relation to that report, although it has given support for, and actually called on the ABC to, implement several sections of the report, including outsourcing, divestment of international broadcasting and the sale of real estate:

(4) In the time since the Mansfield report, The challenge of a better ABC, was handed down to the Government, has the Minister sought to meet with, or speak to, the Chair of the ABC Board, Mr Donald McDonald on several occasions.
(5) (a) How many times has the Minister contacted the office of the Chair of the ABC Board; (b) has Mr McDonald returned the Minister's calls; and (c) on how many occasions.

(6) (a) If the Minister and Mr McDonald have spoken, what was the nature of their conversation; (b) was the Mansfield report discussed in any way; (c) were specific recommendations discussed; (d) was the position of the ABC board in relation to the Mansfield report discussed; and (e) was the position of the Government in relation to the Mansfield Report discussed.

(7) Has the Minister sought to meet with the ABC's National Advisory Council (NAC) since the cancellation of a meeting scheduled for 12 November 1996; if not, when does the Minister intend to meet with the NAC.
(8) Does the Minister stand by the position of the Coalition policy statement Better Broadcasting, which states that the coalition is supportive of the role and the work of the NAC.
(9) With reference to a meeting scheduled for 25 February 1997 between the Minister and the Friends of the ABC: why did the meeting not take place at this time.

(10) (a) Does the Minister stand by the coalition's statement in its policy statement Better Broadcasting that the Friends of the ABC play `an important role in providing community feedback on ABC activities' and that `the Coalition welcomes their views and will continue to encourage them to take an active interest in ongoing issues affecting the ABC' or is the Minister's refusal to meet with the Friends of the ABC a rebuttal of this previous position; and (b) if the Minister stands by the policy statement, when will the meeting with the Friends of the ABC take place.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) No
(b) As I have stated on numerous occasions, the Government will consider its response to the Mansfield recommendations in the context of the 1997/98 Budget.
(3) I have previously indicated that there will be no further funding cuts to the ABC beyond the ongoing reductions announced by the Government in July last year.

(4) As Minister with portfolio responsibility for the ABC, I naturally have occasion to telephone and/or meet with the Chairman of the ABC on a regular basis. The subjects discussed cover the full range of issues relating to the ABC, including the Mansfield Report, funding issues and any other significant items.
(5) See (4) above.
(6) (a)—(d). See (4) above
(e) See 2(b) above

(7) Regrettably, I was unable to meet with the NAC on 12 November, due to other commitments. I was disappointed that I was unable to keep that appointment, and look forward to the opportunity to meet with the members of the NAC in the near future.

(b) See (9) above. Any future requests for meetings by the Friends of the ABC will be considered in the context of my Parliamentary schedule and other commitments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 6 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does Australia Post pay sales tax on business activity pursuant to section 16 of the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989.

(2) (a) Has Australia Post sealed off the fire escape door to the arcade at the Manly Post Office in Sydney, and consequently put in danger its staff and members of the public in the event of fire; and (b) is such action contrary to the by‐laws of the building's body corporate and State fire prevention laws.
(3) What are the criteria layed down by Australia Post for the sale of stamps to newsagencies at a discount price.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice from Australia Post is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes—Australia Post has since May 1987 been subject in full to the provisions of sales tax legislation in force.

(2) An entrance door at the Manly Post Office was closed off as part of a Retail Shop fit out in approximately April 1996. The door in question was not a fire escape exit, and the remaining egress doors are within approved Building Code of Australia guidelines. The works, which were approved by the owner of the premises, do not contravene any State Fire Protection laws.

(3) Australia Post's national retail network consists of some 4,000 corporate and licensed outlets providing a full range of postal services, supplemented by over 900 Postpoint merchandising units and 11,000 licensed stamp vendors. Network configuration is determined by issues such as the local demand for postal services, commercial viability considerations and legislated community service obligations.
Newsagents, subject to the network configuration issues mentioned above, may receive stamps at a discount under the following circumstances:
a licensed post office may be operated in conjunction with a newsagency. Licensees purchase stamps from Australia Post at a 12% discount. The stamps must be resold at face value;
Postpoint operators are licensed to purchase stamps from Australia Post at a 5% discount. The stamps must be resold at face value. In addition, Newsagents may operate as Licensed Stamp Vendors.
Licensed stamp vendors receive no discount on the purchase of stamps from Australia Post. Typically, they make stamps available as an additional service to their customers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 7 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) What are the qualifications of the members of the Australian Radiation Laboratory (ARL); and (b) what expertise do they have by which to advocate public health standards.
(2) Does the ARL currently engage: (a) biochemists; (b) epidemiologists; and (c) toxicologists.
(3) Is it the responsibility of ARL to assess the possibility of public health risk arising from devices from electromagnetic fields generally.
(4) (a) Does ARL test electromagnetic emissions from mobile phones used in Australia; and (b) are these results made public; if so, what are they.
(5) What research programs does ARL currently conduct in the matter of public health in relation to electromagnetic fields and what proposals do they have for future research work in this area.
(6) What current proposals or programs does ARL have aimed at protecting the interests of Australian manufacturers' access to overseas markets in relation to electromagnetic radiation standards.
(7) Does ARL conduct industry based inspections; if so, what is the system for doing so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The ARL employs a total of 29 professional staff with training and qualifications in health and medical physics, radiation metrology, environmental chemistry, environmental physics, statistics, computer modelling and radiation protection. Slightly more than half have post‐graduate degrees in one or more of the above disciplines.

PARA.TAB: (b) The ARL is actively involved in national and international bodies concerned with the setting of occupational and public radiation health standards. It co‐ordinates the work of the Radiation Health Committee, the body which develops national Codes of Practice and guidance on radiation health issues. Internationally, its staff have close links with the International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP), the International Commission on Non‐Ionising Radiation Protection (ICNIRP), the International Radiation Protection Association (IRPA), the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), the United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation (UNSCEAR) and the World Health Organisation (WHO). Its expertise and awareness of world‐wide perspectives on radiation health questions is augmented substantially by its contributions to these bodies.

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The ARL does not directly employ bio‐chemists, toxicologists or epidemiologists but its staff are well experienced in relevant aspects of epidemiology and human physiology.
(3) It is a responsibility of ARL to assess health risks associated with electromagnetic radiation generally.

(4) ARL does not test mobile phones on a routine basis. It has, however, measured incidentally, the radiation fields from some models and confirmed that they do not breach Australian standards. These results have not been published.

(5) Over the past few years, the ARL has conducted research into low frequency electromagnetic field levels associated with power distribution, the effect of incorrect classification of exposure levels on the significance of epidemiological studies and has provided the dosimetry measurements for an animal study on the effects of ELF (extremely low frequency) and of RF (radiofrequency) radiation on a strain of cancer‐sensitive mice. It is currently trialling, and will shortly commence, a nationwide study of environmental levels of RF in urban and rural regions, covering all frequencies from AM radio through to the microwaves used for mobile phones.
(6) ARL has no proposals or programs aimed at protection of Australian manufacturers' access to overseas markets.

(7) ARL frequently carries out, at the request of their operators, measurements of RF radiation in industrial applications and in the neighbourhood of facilities such as radar equipment at airports, satellite transmission dishes, TV broadcast transmitters, oil rig communication transmitters and various defence installations to assess compliance with Australian requirements. Measurements of this nature are reported to the clients requesting them. ARL has also measured the emissions from a wide variety of video display terminals available on the Australian market. ARL maintains the only facility in Australia for the calibration of RF hazard meters and calibrates about 250 such instruments each year for the industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 13 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are alkylphenol ethoxylates (APE's) banned in Switzerland and are they being phased out in other European countries.
(2) Are APE's in use within Australia; if so, in what ways.
(3) Are there any restrictions over the use of APE's in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Switzerland has phased out the use of alkylphenol ethoxylates. The Paris Commission, established to administer the Convention for the Prevention of Marine Pollution from Land-based Sources that came into force in 1978 and has since been ratified by most European countries, has recommended that nonylphenol ethoxylates be phased out as cleaning agents by the year 2000. Other alkylphenol ethoxylates are not included in the Paris Commission recommendation.
(2) Alkylphenol ethoxylates have a variety of uses in Australia, including in detergents, shampoos, shaving creams and other cosmetics, the spermicide nonoxynyl-9, paints, and pesticide formulations.

(3) There are no specific restrictions over the use of alkylphenol ethoxylates in Australia, but scientific and regulatory developments are being closely monitored. Australian suppliers are evaluating replacement chemicals, and local production of possible alternatives is under development.
