TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 19 March 1997:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Has the Government evaluated the loss to the Tasmanian community and overseas AusAID students of the AusAID office in Hobart?
(2) (a) How much money is saved in closing the office; and (b) what are the losses in service, promotional opportunities for AusAID and effectiveness that result from the closure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, on notice, on 18 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that Warwick Shire Council has offered a `high security' water allocation of 500 megalitres a year out of a town water supply of 32 000 megalitres a year to Danpork Australia for the purposes of establishing a 10 000 sow piggery near Warwick on the Darling Downs.
(2) Is the Minister aware that this represents one‐sixth of the town's nominal water allocation.
(3) Is the Minister aware that, up until early 1996, Warwick Shire suffered from severe drought which could recur in the future.
(4) Is the Minister aware that the residents of Warwick Shire had their water use restricted during the drought period, and that this could occur again in the future.
(5) Is the Minister aware of section 100 of the Australian Constitution which enshrines residents' rights to reasonable use of water from rivers and tributaries.

(6) Does the Minister agree that, by granting a 500 megalitres high security water allocation every year to a massive piggery and abattoir in a shire regularly hit by drought, the council is likely to give residents' water needs second priority to the piggery in a time of drought.
(7) Does the Minister agree that, should this occur, the council's action would lead to a breach of the constitution.
(8) What action will be taken to avoid this breach occurring.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the Constitution responsibility for water resource management including water allocation is a matter of the State and Territory governments. The Warwick Shire Council in Queensland has responsibility for the water resources and planning within its jurisdiction. This is not a matter of Commonwealth responsibility, however, I have been advised that Warwick Shire Council is negotiating with Danpork Australia to allocate a small portion of the Council's town water. The available water for urban use is in the order of 4_250 megalitres a year, made up from an allocation from Leslie Dam, which is under the jurisdiction of the Queensland Department of Natural Resources, and the Council's Connelly Dam. The urban consumption rate of Warwick Shire prior to the introduction of consumer meters was 2 500 megalitres a year and is currently 2_000 megalitres a year, resulting in a saving of 500 megalitres a year. This leaves the Council with 2 250 megalitres a year of available water.
(2) Using the figures in the response to Question (1) the proposed allocation would be approximately twelve percent of the town's nominal urban water allocation.
(3) Yes.

(4) It is current management practice in towns in urban areas in Queensland during drought periods to restrict water consumption. I have been advised that Warwick Shire Council was placed on restrictions during the recent drought, however, at the lowest point during the drought the town supply reserve was sufficient for a further two years.

(5) Yes. Section 100 of the Australian Constitution reads: The Commonwealth shall not, by any law or regulation of trade or commerce, abridge the right of a State or of the residents therein to the reasonable use of the waters of rivers for conservation or irrigation.
(6) Given the recent savings in town water consumption and the available supply of almost double the current urban demand, there would appear to be little threat to residents' water needs.

(7) The Constitution refers to actions by the Commonwealth, not to actions by local government, and the arrangements for managing the Warwick town water supply could not, in my view lead to a breach of the Constitution.

(8) As indicated above, this is not a matter in which the Commonwealth has any jurisdiction. Nevertheless, I am informed that Council, in consultation with Queensland Departments, has undertaken a thorough planning process. This concluded that there are sufficient reserves of urban water supply to allow for the transfer of 500 megalitres of town water to Danpork Australia if required.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Zoos and Wildlife Sanctuaries: Code of Conduct

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 19 March 1997 :

QUESTION.PARA: Is there a national code of conduct in relation to the facilities provided for animals in zoos and wildlife sanctuaries.
What role does the National Consultative Committee on Animal Welfare (NCCAW), or any other federal body, play in ensuring any code of conduct or guidelines are adhered to.
Has the NCCAW been made aware of any concerns over the operation or facilities of any Australian zoos; if so, can details be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: There is no national code of conduct relating to the facilities provided for animals in zoos and wildlife sanctuaries.

Individual State and Territory Governments which have legislative responsibility for zoos, have developed, or are in the process of developing sets of guidelines for the keeping of animals in zoos and wildlife sanctuaries.

NCCAW is solely an advisory body to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, bringing together representatives from State and Territory Governments, animal welfare organisations and the National Farmers Federation (NFF). Neither it nor any other federal body is involved in ensuring codes of conduct or guidelines are adhered to.

As mentioned above State and Territory Governments have prime responsibility for animal welfare issues. However, in some States the National Parks and Wildlife administer legislation relating to wildlife sanctuaries.
NCCAW has not been made aware of any concerns over the operation or facilities of any Australian zoos.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 19 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there any restrictions on the caging of any Australian native birds for breeding; if so, what are they.
(2) What codes of practice are in force to ensure the welfare of caged birds.
(3) Is it legal to keep caged kookaburras for pets or breeding in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) State and Territory Governments have primary responsibility for conservation and management of wildlife, including native birds. The Commonwealth has responsibility for the management of wildlife on Commonwealth lands and for control of the export of native wildlife or products derived from native wildlife . All States and Territories have legislation controlling the keeping of Australian native birds.
(2) State and Territory legislation concerning the keeping of caged birds varies between jurisdictions, but generally the controls aim to ensure a high standard of animal welfare.
(3) The keeping of caged kookaburras, or any other Australian native animal, is a matter for State and Territory wildlife authorities and is outside the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 November 1996 (Hansard page 5793) Senator Reynolds asked me a question without notice concerning whether any modelling had been carried out on the additional longer term costs to the pension system or the reduction in national savings of the new deeming provisions on superannuation for people aged 55 and over. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Currently people below age pension age generally have superannuation assets exempted for means

test purposes. However, with the superannuation preservation age generally set at age 55, most early retirees have the opportunity to access their superannuation from age 55. There is evidence from ABS surveys and from DSS case records that an increasing number of people aged between the preservation and age pension ages are leaving substantial funds in superannuation rollover funds. Because superannuation assets are exempt from both the income and assets tests, these people may also be obtaining social security payments, such as new start allowance, but may nonetheless also be drawing on the earnings and capital in their superannuation rollover funds to boost income in early retirement.

The national savings effects of means testing the superannuation assets of those aged 55 and over and on income support for at least 9 months have not been modelled by the Retirement Income Modelling Task Force. The current exemption of such assets from the social security means test has led to insufficient social security data upon which to do so.
